Documents: 2022 1st SA Allocation Strategy Paper FINAL.pdf##554262##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/ETH-AllocDocs_2022_437_653.pdf##

AllocationSummary: This allocation is mainly for prepositioning of funding for ‘48-hour response’ by allowing partners to respond timely to multiple crises across the country. The EHF and partners will remain agile and relevant when supporting the most vulnerable communities affected by multiple shocks. OCHA and relevant cluster coordinators (i.e. ES/NFI, Health and WASH) will identify partners with recommended projects in Afar and Oromia to receive a top-up for emergency contingency budget under Envelope 3.

This second reserve allocation aims to initiate the construction of IDP relocation sites in Weleh, Wag Hamra Zones, and Jara, North Wello Zone, in the Amhara Region in line with urgent needs indicated in the North Wello and Wag Hamra Mini Response Plans.

This allocation gives a critical consideration to underfunded clusters and the ERC’s underfunded priority areas. The main objectives are to complement the previous pooled funds allocations in terms of cluster and to provide comprehensive services to vulnerable communities affected by the conflicts, insecurities, and drought across the country. EHF’s commitment to further strengthen AAP, Gender, PSEA and disabilities in humanitarian responses will be reinforced through second round of seeds funding to support the works of the cross-cutting networks or working groups.

As recalled during the High Level Pledging Event on the Horn of Africa on 24 May, the urgency to further scale up the response in   drought-affected southern and eastern Ethiopia remains high. Despite recent rainfall in parts of these areas, the humanitarian condition   of the affected population – including pastoralists and agro-pastoralists – remains extremely dire as their livelihoods have been severely   affected. Communities are suffering the impacts of five consecutive poor rainy seasons, coming on top of conflict and insecurity, high   food prices and other drivers of needs including most recently off-season floods and a cholera epidemic. Access to basic needs, such as   food and water, for many households is expected to continue to be extremely limited and continues to require urgent humanitarian   assistance. In a context that continues to evolve and compounded by recent droughts and floods, it is estimated that 13 million are in   dire need of humanitarian assistance1  .  To bolster the humanitarian response in these areas, the Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) is activating a $17 million Reserve Allocation   to prevent further deterioration in food security, water supplies and sanitation, as well as support the initial rebuilding of essential   livelihoods and enhance safety and dignity of populations. The use of Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance (MPCA) and partnerships with NGO   partners will be strongly emphasized. This allocation also complements and builds on a parallel CERF allocation focusing on similar life-saving needs to maximize geographical and sectoral complementarity
Documents: EHF 1st RA Allocation Strategy Final.pdf##266698##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/ETH-AllocDocs_2023_481_805.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Following the improved security situation and access in parts of northern and western Ethiopia, IDPs are gradually returning or relocating, which in turn permits a conducive context to deliver much-needed assistance. The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) will provide $35 million in assistance via an area-based integrated package to those IDPs who have voluntarily returned or relocated, many of whom are lacking basic resources. Cash programming is highly encouraged. The best-placed direct responder will be prioritized with at least thirty per cent of funding allocated to local and national NGOs. This allocation will contribute to support voluntarily and dignify return of IDPs through a harmonized and coordinated approach.

Documents: EHF 2nd RA Allocation Strategy Final.pdf##239141##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/ETH-AllocDocs_2023_511_868.pdf##

AllocationSummary: At the start of 2024, humanitarian partners are gearing up to mount a widescale response to El Niño driven drought in Ethiopia, in addition to dealing with the continuing impacts of past droughts, floods, conflict and economic shocks. Early action is needed to prevent deterioration and widespread suffering. Conflict and insecurity in several parts of the country has given rise to new and growing protection concerns, including displacement, destruction of social infrastructure, and gender-based violence. The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) is launching a standard allocation of US$30 million to kickstart the response to newly prioritized humanitarian needs1, targeting locations in Afar, Amhara, Oromia, Somali and Tigray regions that meet the following criteria: 1) drought-affected, 2) hotspot woredas, and 3) no or limited operational presence. The allocation complements the $17 million CERF allocation that provided support to the drought response in early 2024. The allocation also supports the humanitarian scale up in East and Kelem Wellegas in Western Oromia where there are ongoing new displacements due to active conflict and significant gaps have been identified in the response. The allocation adopts an area-based approach, promoting an intersectoral response to save lives. It will advance localization through funding NNGOs as directly as possible, and prioritizing consortia/partnerships that add value in terms of capacity-strengthening and ensuring an intersectoral approach. Special consideration is given to supporting survivors of GBV, including children, in Amhara, Benishangul Gumuz and Oromia regions. Additionally, all partners must promote gender equality, age-appropriate activities, inclusion of vulnerable groups, and mainstreaming protection.

AllocationSummary: This allocation is being launched in response to the recently finalized ‘Priority Humanitarian Response and Critical Funding Gaps’ document (June 2024) – prepared by the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG) under the auspices of the HCT and Government EDRMC – which seeks close to US$1bn to address humanitarian priorities and critical gaps over the next three months, including to secure relief commodity pipelines up to the end of 2024. This product is a complement to the $3.2bn Humanitarian Response Plan and presents critical gaps in the ongoing response, which this allocation aims to address.  Strategic priorities:  1: Address urgent gaps in the malnutrition response across prioritized woredas in Amhara, Oromia and South Ethiopia, including in hard-to-reach areas, through an intersectoral approach.  2: Respond to unmet needs of internally displaced people in Amhara, Oromia and Tigray through an integrated and multi-sectoral approach.  3: Implement readiness actions for potential new population movements in Amhara, Oromia and Tigray.

AllocationSummary: The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) will make a USD $7 million anticipatory action allocation in response to projected poor rains due to La Nina during the October-December season in south and south-eastern parts of Ethiopia. August forecasts reveal that 8.6 million people across 125 woredas in Oromia, Somali and South Ethiopia regions, are expected to face 'severe' (1-in-5 year) drought conditions. This first-of-its-kind allocation aims to provide assistance before the drought's full impact is felt, protecting livelihoods and preventing a nutrition crisis.    This allocation marks a pioneering step for CBPFs engagement in AA in Ethiopia and the region, at large, by leveraging best practices from past AA initiatives. It draws on strengthened planning around a drought AA framework which has identified triggers, activities, and timelines.

AllocationSummary: The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) plans a USD $7 million allocation in response to urgent lifesaving needs in the contested areas as outlined in Multisectoral Inter-Agency Rapid Assessments conducted in July/August 2024. Following these assessments, the HCT made a collective policy decision that the operating environment is permissive for scaled-up and sustained aid operations and durable solutions. Since the northern Ethiopia conflict ended with the Pretoria Agreement in 2022 access to essential basic services has been constrained due to the absence of civil administration (the Ethiopia National Defense Force – ENDF - with support of the Federal Police, is currently the administrator of the contested areas). Due to the conflict, the populations of the contested areas were displaced multiple times. Spontaneous as well as organized returns have been occurring from both those displaced towards the Tigray and Amhara regions. This allocation will provide lifesaving humanitarian assistance to IDPs, returnees and the host communities based on vulnerability. The allocation adopts a conflict sensitive approach and partners will be required to submit risk assessments. It prioritizes NGO partners, including national NGOs, with established presence in these areas, complementing a parallel CERF Underfunded Emergencies allocation for UN agencies that is under development.

AllocationSummary: The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) launches the 2025 First Standard Allocation, amounting up to US$17 million, to address the most urgent and life-threatening humanitarian needs resulting from the compounding effects of conflict, displacement, food insecurity and protection risks across Ethiopia. The allocation prioritizes critical needs in multi-sectoral and sector-specific response in areas with the highest severity of needs, particularly in Nutrition, Health, WASH, Agriculture, Gender-Based Violence (GBV) and Education sectors.  Informed by the 2025 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP), inter-sectoral severity analysis and the 2025 Priority Humanitarian Response and Critical Gaps Report, this allocation focuses on delivering timely, needs-driven and vulnerability-focused assistance. The allocation targets highly vulnerable people in regions most affected by conflict and climate-induced shocks, including malnourished children and pregnant and lactating women, out-of-school children and GBV survivors facing escalating risks due to insecurity and service disruptions. Through timely and flexible funding, the EHF will sustain essential life-saving humanitarian services.  The standard allocation will be launched in parallel with the 2025 EHF Second Reserve Allocation which aims at reaching affected people in Tigray and is facilitated through the time-sensitive reserve allocation modality based on time-critical needs.

AllocationSummary: The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) is launching the 2025 Second Reserve Allocation of up to US$6 million to address critical, life-threatening humanitarian needs in the Tigray Region of Ethiopia. This allocation responds to deteriorating conditions linked to sustained displacement, funding shortfalls, collapsing service pipelines and heightened vulnerability ahead of the rainy season.   As of early April 2025, Tigray hosts more than 20% of Ethiopia’s IDP population and more than 40% of its returnees1. With approximately 700,000 internally displaced people facing severe gaps in shelter, WASH, nutrition, health and protection services, this allocation prioritizes a multi-sectoral response targeting the most affected people in collective sites and underserved areas. It aims to mitigate the risks of disease outbreaks, malnutrition and protection contravention, particularly gender-based violence—through integrated area-based interventions.  Timely and flexible support through this allocation will help partners sustain essential life-saving services, scale up preparedness efforts and prevent further deterioration in one of the most complex operating environments in the country. The allocation is launched in parallel to the 2025 First Standard Allocation that addresses priority needs in other parts of the country. The reserve allocation modality with pre-identified partners has been selected to ensure timely delivery of assistance to people affected by critical humanitarian needs.

AllocationSummary: The Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund (EHF) launches the 2025 Third Reserve Allocation, amounting to US$16.5 million, to address the most critical humanitarian needs of internally displaced people, returnees and refugees across Ethiopia.   The allocation focuses on three strategic priorities. Firstly, it aims to deliver multisectoral support in prioritized sites for internally displaced people, including collective centres in Amhara and Tigray, and informal settlements in Somali and Oromia, with particular emphasis on border conflict-affected zones. Secondly, it provides time-bound humanitarian assistance – in areas of voluntary return of internally displaced people to Eastern Tigray and Western Oromia, where conditions meet humanitarian principles and access to basic services remains constrained. Finally, it will aim to support unregistered refugees living near host communities, providing a six-month humanitarian package to support their transition into formal refugee camps under UNHCR’s mandate.

AllocationSummary: Cette première allocation standard de 4 millions de dollars américains (USD) du Fonds Humanitaire d´Haïti, qui fait partie du Fonds Humanitaire pour l’Amérique latine et les Caraïbes (LAC HF), représente un soutien crucial dans un contexte humanitaire en constante détérioration. Le premier volet de cette allocation vise à soutenir à la fois les populations déplacées et les communautés hôtes de la Grande Anse, en répondant à leurs besoins vitaux, en préservant la cohésion sociale et en évitant que la pression sur les services de base ne pousse les personnes déplacées à fuir vers des sites spontanés. Un second volet se concentrera sur l’opérationnalisation de la protection transversale dans les communautés touchées par la violence armée dans la zone métropolitaine de Port-au-Prince (ZMPAP).     Cette allocation sera principalement destinée aux ONG locales, nationales et internationales, avec un accent particulier sur la localisation : au moins 40 % des fonds seront directement ou indirectement attribués aux ONG locales ou nationales. Les ONG internationales désireuses de soumettre un projet devront établir des partenariats avec des organisations locales et nationales afin de favoriser l'échange de compétences et de capacités.

AllocationSummary: Le Fonds humanitaire régional pour l’Amérique latine et les Caraïbes (RHPF LAC) lance une allocation de réserve de 500 000 de dollars américains (RA1-2025). Cette allocation vise à soutenir la préparation et la réponse à la saison cyclonique, notamment dans le Grand Sud, avec la possibilité de mobilisation de stocks et des activités à d’autres zones du pays si nécessaire. L’allocation inclura également des activités de relèvement précoce en soutien aux populations touchées. L'allocation sera principalement destinée aux partenaires ONG locaux, nationaux ou internationaux, avec un accent particulier sur la localisation : au moins 40 pour cent des fonds seront directement ou indirectement attribués aux ONG locales ou nationales. Les ONG internationales désireuses de soumettre un projet devront établir des partenariats avec des organisations locales et nationales afin de favoriser l'échange de compétences et de capacités.

AllocationSummary: Cette première allocation standard de 2025, d’un montant de 4 millions de dollars américains (USD) du Fonds Humanitaire Régional pour l’Amérique latine et les Caraïbes (RHPF LAC) en Haïti, constitue un appui essentiel dans un contexte humanitaire marqué par la montée de la violence armée et les déplacements massifs de population. Elle vise à répondre aux besoins urgents des personnes déplacées et des communautés hôtes dans les départements du Centre et de l’Artibonite, à travers une assistance multisectorielle incluant l’accès à l’eau potable, l’assainissement, l’abri, la santé, l’éducation, la nutrition, la sécurité alimentaire et la protection, tout en renforçant la résilience et la cohésion sociale afin d’éviter l’expansion des sites de déplacement spontanés.    Un accent particulier est mis sur la localisation : au moins 40 % des fonds seront directement ou indirectement attribués aux ONG locales ou nationales. Les ONG internationales souhaitant soumettre une proposition devront travailler en consortium avec des partenaires locaux afin de favoriser l’échange de compétences et le renforcement des capacités.    Cette allocation s’inscrit en complémentarité avec le financement du CERF, afin d’assurer une réponse coordonnée et à fort impact pour les populations les plus vulnérables.

AllocationSummary: This allocation aims to support response to address priority unmet humanitarian needs among out-of-camp IDPs and vulnerable returnees in underserved locations of Iraq through a focused and accelerated allocation process. The allocation will use the reserve allocation modality to strategically support humanitarian response in areas (i) where significant response gaps exist, and (ii) where the severity of needs is the highest, as identified by the 2021 HRP gap analysis and 2022 HNO inter-sectoral needs analysis. Given the limited funding available, the allocation will use a targeted multi-sectoral approach to maximize its impact in specific underserved areas and areas of high severity needs.     This allocation will strengthen ongoing responses in health, multipurpose cash assistance, protection, and WASH clusters to reduce reliance on negative coping mechanisms among targeted groups. The allocation will also support IHF’s continued pursuit of the Grand Bargain commitment on localization through promoting submissions from national and international NGOs (INGOs) as first responders. INGOs are further expected to invest in building the capacity of national NGOs with whom they will partner. In line with the Fund’s second strategic objective for 2021, the allocation aims to channel funds to underfunded areas of humanitarian response, through prioritizing projects that mainstream gender (especially women and girls), and address the specific needs of persons with disability, and gender-based violence (GBV).
Documents: IHF 2021 1st Reserve Allocation Strategy_FINAL.pdf##419473##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/IRQ-AllocDocs_2021_371_449.pdf##

AllocationSummary: This allocation aims to provide vulnerable returnees and out-of-camp IDPs in Iraq in underserved locations with targeted protection assistance, improved access to essential health and WASH services, and emergency livelihood support through humanitarian partners investing in localized response. The allocation has an overall objective to address issues driving an increase in severity of humanitarian needs in Iraq over the past year, such as increased protection concerns, deteriorated access to key Health and WASH services, and loss of income, which result in increased negative coping mechanisms. It will jumpstart the implementation of key recommendations from the recently completed 2020 HRP gap analysis of the ICCG, through strategically targeting returnees in severe need and out-of-camp IDPs in underserved locations with focused sectoral response prioritized under the 2021 HRP. Beyond immediate operational priorities, the allocation will support the IHF’s continued pursuit of the Grand Bargain commitment on localization through promoting multi-NGO consortia as a preferred funding modality, aimed at enhancing the participation and capacity of national partners. Finally, in line with the Fund’s second strategic objective for 2021, the allocation aims to channel funds to underfunded areas of humanitarian response, through prioritizing projects which mainstream gender (especially women and girls), specific needs of persons with disability, and GBV.
Documents: IHF 2021 1st Standard Allocation Strategy_FINAL_Timeline extended.pdf##355828##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/IRQ-AllocDocs_2021_326_486.pdf##

AllocationSummary: In cognizance of the significant residual humanitarian needs among extremely vulnerable Iraqis, against the context of response transition, this last allocation of the Iraq Humanitarian Fund (IHF) will support vulnerable internally displaced persons (IDPs) living outside camps and returnees in acute need in accessing: 1) immediate income sources to meet basic needs and reduce reliance on negative coping strategies; 2) specialized protection services; and 3) water and sanitation services focusing on minimal service provision to address life-threatening needs and sustainable community-level solutions.     Leveraging the Fund’s comparative advantage of timeliness and flexibility, and its wide network of partners, the allocation will help address the core drivers of vulnerability among these groups through high-impact, short-term interventions. By targeting nine districts that host the highest numbers of targeted population groups in acute need, yet with significant response gaps, the allocation will maximize the impact of limited funding available. The tight sectoral and geographic focus complements ongoing and planned interventions by other donor and international agency initiatives.    The allocation will also support the continued pursuit of the Fund’s commitment to localization, through promoting participation and capacity-strengthening of national partners, as well as other cross-cutting priorities including gender and age considerations, disability inclusion, protection mainstreaming, and accountability in all partner programming.

AllocationSummary: Considering the alarming child protection and SGBV issues that are observed in EJC as well as the challenges around coordination, Tdh is highly worried about the negative consequences for children in EJC and their families of suspending its operations. Similarly, camp residents themselves are voicing their significant concerns in relation to Tdh’s possible (temporary) departure and the subsequent loss of access to the services. Tdh has over the past months approached several donors to seek funding to sustain its interventions in EJC. Concretely, Tdh has together with DRC approached ECHO, who have indicated that funding may likely be available as of January 2020 and who will visit EJC later in the month. Also, Tdh will apply for the second allocation of the JHF once made available – funding for this would however also not be available before January 2020.     The HC has received a request from Terre Des Homme-Lausanne to activate the Reserve window to fill the funding gap for two  months for their ongoing activities in the Emirati Camp.     The HC has endorsed the activation of the Reserve Allocation window to sustain the activities in the camp.

AllocationSummary: This reserve allocation of US$ 500,000 aims to respond to critical needs of Palestinian Refugees from Syria (PRSs) residing in Jordan.    As PRS are excluded from the international humanitarian and donor response to the Syrian crisis in Jordan, UNRWA remains the main actor contributing to a protective environment for PRS, by maintaining their access to basic services and ensuring their basic human rights are fulfilled.     In Jordan, UNRWA strives to continue providing assistance to PRS recorded with the Agency to enable them to meet their basic needs of food, non-food items and shelters, as well as to cope with sudden crises and emergency, while strengthening their resilience.

AllocationSummary: a)	Multi-sector Needs Assessment: ($450,000) / REACH & IOM)  The Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) tasked OCHA to undertake a Multi Sector Needs Analysis (MSNA) exercise to provide a comprehensive evidence base of multi-sectoral needs amongst different population groups in Lebanon to help understand the scale and severity of the current crisis. It is the intention of the Humanitarian Coordinator to use the LHF Reserve modality to co-fund the proposed MSNA, which will aim to achieve the following objectives:    1. Inform humanitarian-development response options for 2021/2 planning, through the provision of comprehensive, multi-sectoral household data  2. Provide inter-sectoral analysis of the severity of humanitarian needs among crisis-affected populations in Lebanon, including the calculation of People in Need and severity calculations to enable inter-sectoral prioritization and programming  3. Improve the quality of humanitarian data in Lebanon for use by humanitarian and development actors    Already in progress, initial findings from the MSNA will be available by October 2021, and full analysis published at the end of the year. The Assessment will support a revision of the 12-month coordinated multi-sectoral Emergency Response Plan (ERP) currently under preparation to address the needs of the most vulnerable among the Lebanese, Palestine Refugees from Lebanon (PRL) and migrants affected by the crisis, in complement to the LCRP as the framework to address the impact of the Syria crisis in Lebanon. As an HCT-owned and led assessment, the MSNA process will continue to involve all relevant stakeholders at both strategic and operational levels to avoid duplication and ensure complementarity with ongoing assessments, including the Vulnerability Assessment of Syrian Refugees in Lebanon (VASyR) and the planned Lebanon Vulnerable Assessment Panel (LVAP).     b)	Strengthened national NGO Coordination and engagement in ‘Whole of Lebanon’ response: ($100,000 / Lebanon Humanitarian and Development Forum)  To support the continued engagement of national responders in all levels of a coordinated ‘Whole of Lebanon’ response, $100,000 will also be made available to support the Lebanon Humanitarian and Development Forum (LHDF).   As the humanitarian community seeks to respond to emerging needs among previously unsupported caseloads, the LHDF and its membership will play a critical role in ensuring the full engagement of local and national partners in the response.  Funding will also support the ongoing work of the Forum in facilitating its core coordination, capacity building, advocacy, PSEA and community help desk and hotline activities, as well as to play a role in supporting local partners submissions to the LHF. Funding will also support LHDF to work with members in mainstreaming key cross-cutting issues (notably gender, AAP and PSEA) among LHF local partner programming.

AllocationSummary: The proposed LHF Reserve Allocation amounting to US$ 6 million will aim to support partial continuation of services in 65 hospitals (32 public and 33 private) accounting for nearly 7,500 functional beds across Lebanon. Among private hospitals (those identified as providing essential health services), only those prioritized would be supported with 25 per cent of requested needs. In addition, all Primary Health Care Centers (PHCCs) and dispensaries will be partially supported as they also provide essential health services and serve as entry points for other critical services such as nutrition and protection. These facilities serve around 2 million people annually, including Lebanese, Refugees and Migrants. A small portion will also be allocated to cover 100 per cent of needs for cold chain storage comprising a central warehouse and distribution sites at district level which maintain safe storage of essential health commodities (vaccines and critical medicines such as insulin). WFP will be the recipient agency and, as lead of the Logistics Sector, will coordinate with all relevant actors including WHO to ensure support to all relevant health facilities

With reports indicating increasing number of people seeking GBV services, growing numbers of children out of school with little prospect of return and an increased trend of child labor and street connected children as a result of the deteriorating situation in Lebanon, this allocation will enable humanitarian partners to respond to these profiles of people severely impacted

AllocationSummary: Lebanon is facing its most severe conflict escalation since the 2006 Lebanon War, directly affecting and/or displacing over one million people. The intense military escalation and rapidly deteriorating humanitarian situation is putting the lives of hundreds of thousands of people at risk, including Lebanese, displaced Syrians, Palestine refuges and migrants. Most displaced people require urgent assistance having had to flee their homes rapidly without the basic items they need for daily life.     The Lebanon Humanitarian Fund (LHF) is launching a $10 million emergency allocation to address the immediate lifesaving needs of those most impacted by the conflict, with a focus on delivery of timely, flexible aid to those recently displaced, including those in collective shelters across Lebanon. Assistance will be delivered by best-placed NGO partners providing multi-sectoral services to those most vulnerable profiles of people including people with disabilities, women at risk of gender based violence and children at risk.  This allocation, alongside a $10 million CERF disbursement, will kick-start funding for the $424 million Flash Appeal launched on 1 October 2024, enabling coordinated, rapid, and multi-sectoral interventions through NGO partners to address urgent life-saving humanitarian needs across core lifesaving sector.

AllocationSummary: Two weeks after the cessation of hostilities was announced on 27 November 2024, Lebanon continues to grapple with an increasingly complex humanitarian situation. The scale of damage, of people displaced and returning to their communities in conflict-affected areas means that urgent needs continue to unfold. As winter approaces, needs are becoming increasingly acute, compounding the barriers people already face in accessing services.  Since 8 October 2023, the conflict has killed 4,047 civilians, including at least 290 children and 790 women, injured 16,638 and directly impacted more than 1.3 million people.    The Lebanon Humanitarian Fund (LHF) is launching a $30.7 million emergency allocation to supplement $12 million allocated in October to upscale and expand humanitarian response to all those impacted by the crisis. The allocation will deliver flexible, timely multi-sectoral interventions through NGO partners to address immediate and life-saving humanitarian needs. Funding will support all population groups – Lebanese, Syrian and Palestine refugees and migrants - those remaining in areas of displacement, those in transition trying to return home but unable to do so, those returning home and those who never left conflict-affected areas. Support will prioritize locations most impacted by the conflict considering revised displacement figures with flexibility provided to allow for the fluidity of the context.   To ensure a timely allocation process, the allocation will support pre-identified partners chosen via an inclusive consultation process informed by sub-national inputs to ensure the delivery of a contextualized response.  In line with the LHF’s approach, the allocation will promote a localized and community-driven response supporting local NGOs and community-based organizations’ access to funding through streamlined, contextualized processes and strengthened equitable partnership.
Documents: 2024 2nd Reserve Allocation F..pdf##1179445##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/LEB-AllocDocs_2024_1379_1179.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Lebanon is facing its most severe conflict escalation since the 2006 Lebanon War, displacing over one million people, and with 700 people killed by Israeli strikes from 23-25 September alone, including 50 children and 94 women. The intense military escalation and rapidly deteriorating security situation is putting the lives of hundreds of thousands of people at risk, including Lebanese, displaced Syrians, Palestine refuges and migrants. Most displaced people require urgent assistance having had to flee their homes rapidly without the basic items they need for daily life.     The Lebanon Humanitarian Fund (LHF) is launching a $10 million emergency allocation to address the immediate lifesaving needs of those most impacted by the conflict, with a focus on delivery of timely, flexible aid to those recently displaced, including those in collective shelters across Lebanon. Assistance will be delivered by best-placed NGO partners providing multi-sectoral services to those most vulnerable profiles of people including people with disabilities, women at risk of gender based violence and children …  This allocation, alongside a $10 million CERF disbursement, will kick-start funding for the upcoming $250 million Flash Appeal, enabling coordinated, rapid, and multi-sectoral interventions through NGO partners to address urgent life-saving humanitarian needs across core lifesaving sector.

The Lebanon Community Accountability Platform represents a transformative step in advancing Accountability to Affected People (AAP) by centralizing community feedback and integrating it into the humanitarian decision-making process. As a collective, inter-agency initiative, the platform is designed to enhance transparency, foster trust, and ensure humanitarian responses are guided by the voices and needs of affected populations.    The platform will harness aggregated data, real-time insights, and a robust referral mechanism to foster cross-sectoral collaboration, enhance service delivery, and institutionalize community engagement across all sectors. This initiative aligns with the 2024 priorities outlined in the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) Compact and supports the joint HCT-UNCT commitment to inter-agency PSEA.    At the HCT meeting on 11 December 2024, the Humanitarian Coordinator confirmed the agreement to establish a common platform for collective AAP. This decision followed both discussions at the HCT and technical-level consultations to finalize details.  Additionally, it was agreed to create a dedicated technical working group, chaired by a PSEA/AAP Coordinator, to guide the platform's implementation.    Through catalytic funding from the Lebanon Humanitarian Fund (LHF), this platform aims to operationalize a sustainable, unified approach to accountability, strengthening trust and transparency within the humanitarian community and ensuring affected populations remain at the center of the response.

AllocationSummary: A total of US$6 million  will be made available from the Myanmar Humanitarian Fund (MHF)  under this Second Standard Allocation in 2019, to respond to essential humanitarian activities of displaced and host communities affected by protracted crisis in Myanmar. This MHF allocation will prioritize urgent life-saving activities in the most crisis-affected states across Myanmar, including Rakhine, Kachin and Shan States and the South-East part of Myanmar, in line with the 2019 Myanmar Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). In addition, the food security sector has prioritized agriculture support for flood-affected farmers in Kachin and the South-East, seriously affected by monsoon rains in 2019. In this occasion, the allocation will exclude multisector interventions related to conflict-affected people in Chin State and south-eastern Myanmar, which are being supported by one-year projects through the First Standard Allocation, early this year.

AllocationSummary: The objective of this allocation is to scale up the response to the protracted humanitarian crises in Myanmar, in line with the 2020 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). The allocation responds also to the critical underfunded situation of humanitarian requirements by mid-June 2020. As of 20 June, only 23 per cent of the 2020 HRP requirements, including the revised COVID-19 Addendum, have been met up to now (29 per cent in the case of the mentioned addendum), which is very low in comparison with donor contributions against the HRP in previous years for the same period (50 per cent in 2019 and 40 per cent in 2018).    This standard allocation will make available US$7 million to support coordinated humanitarian assistance and protection, covering displaced people and other vulnerable crisis-affected people in Chin, Rakhine, Kachin and Shan states. The allocation will not include stand-alone interventions related to the COVID-19, which has been already supported through a Reserve Allocation launched in April 2020, resulting in ten funded projects amounting a total of $3.8 million that are already being implemented. Nevertheless, COVID-19 related actions may be mainstreamed throughout the response to the humanitarian needs. In addition, activities in Kayin State will not be included in this allocation, due to the ongoing projects and level of funding as per HRP requirements.

AllocationSummary: In view of the underfunded situation of humanitarian requirements identify by the Myanmar HRP 2021 and the additional humanitarian needs caused by the developments since 1 February 2021, this allocation is launched to catalyze additional resources for the humanitarian response in key geographical areas and sectors with low funding level and increased needs.    This standard allocation will make US$10 million available to support coordinated humanitarian assistance and protection, covering displaced people and other vulnerable crisis-affected people in Chin, Rakhine, Kachin and Shan states and the south-eastern part of Myanmar, in line with the Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) 2021. The allocation will address the underfunded situation of humanitarian requirements. COVID-19 related actions will be mainstreamed throughout the response to the humanitarian needs. In areas identified by the HRP, additional emergency response for people with humanitarian needs as a consequence of the new context since 1 February 2021 will be considered, as per needs assessment and analysis provided during the prioritization process.

AllocationSummary: The overall objective of this allocation is to provide lifesaving humanitarian assistance to IDPs and host communities affected by conflict in hard-to-reach and under-served locations across the Northwest and Southeast, Rakhine, and Kachin. The allocation prioritizes townships where needs are relatively high or not adequately covered by the MHF 2022 second reserve allocation, second round CERF 2022 UFE allocation and allocations from other pooled funds such as the Access to Health Fund, and the Livelihoods and Food Security Fund (LIFT). Faced with access challenges, partners are encouraged to provide multi-sectoral assistance packages to maximize use of every window of opportunity to deliver assistance. People affected by intensified conflict since the military takeover, especially people recently displaced in the third and fourth quarters of 2022 will be prioritized for assistance. Protracted IDPs in hard-to-reach, under-served and acutely affected areas will also be considered for multi-sectoral assistance.

AllocationSummary: This allocation aims to provide multi-sectoral assistance to people in need in hard-to-reach conflict areas and under-served locations to improve their wellbeing and the dignity of their living conditions.  Many of those displaced and their host communities in conflict areas have little or no access to basic life sustaining items and services. The MHF will promote support to national and local partners to reach these groups through the expansion of existing networks which are already assisting communities, leveraging their relationships, access and local knowledge to contribute and improve life-saving, multi-sectoral responses to people in need in Myanmar.
Documents: MHF_2022_RA2_Allocation Strategy_26Jul2022.pdf##277233##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/MM-AllocDocs_2022_425_585.pdf##|||MHF_2022_RA2_Annex 1_Prioritization Matrix_26Jul2022.pdf##296688##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/MM-AllocDocs_2022_425_587.pdf##|||MHF_2022_RA2_Annexes 2-7_26Jul2022.pdf##391898##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/MM-AllocDocs_2022_425_588.pdf##|||MHF_2022_RA2_Annex 8_Q&A_26Jul2022.pdf##229419##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/MM-AllocDocs_2022_425_589.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The passage of Cyclone Mocha left a trail of destruction across multiple states and regions in Myanmar’s west, affecting an estimated 5.4 million people, 3.2 million of whom are considered highly vulnerable. After years of protracted conflict, compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic, affected people in the hardest-hit communities have very weak coping capacity and reduced ability to recover from the storm’s multi-faceted impacts without immediate, lifesaving assistance. This allocation provides time-critical funding to select partners with sustained access and a proven ability to deliver timely aid in affected areas to help kickstart emergency response activities that will save lives and alleviate suffering.    Through this allocation, the MHF aims to provide critical support through Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA), where appropriate and feasible, and/or the delivery of emergency Health, Shelter/NFI and WASH supplies to displaced and vulnerable people. Current levels of funding for these clusters cannot effectively cover emerging needs, making this allocation both timely and indispensable in preventing a further deterioration in an already dire humanitarian situation.     Underfunding, import restrictions and poor access have compromised the ability of humanitarians to stockpile and pre-position emergency supplies over the past two years. Against this challenging logistics backdrop, the allocation prioritizes the distribution of CVA and/or locally-procured relief items, including emergency shelter kits and NFIs, medicines and medical supplies as well as safe water and hygiene items, among other commodities, to facilitate a quick response and avoid bureaucratic hurdles around imports. Any surplus relief items after the Cyclone Mocha response will be strategically pre-positioned to facilitate responses to seasonal flooding and storms over the course of the monsoon season which runs from May through October, enhancing response preparedness.      While preliminary analysis has identified Health, Shelter/NFI and WASH as priority clusters for the disaster response, these clusters are also among the most underfunded in the 2023 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). According to OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS), as of 15 May, these clusters face a combined funding shortfall of about $303.1 million. WASH has only secured $2.6 million (2 per cent of required funding) and Health has received just $700,000 (less than 1 per cent of required funding), while Shelter/NFI has yet to receive any funding through the 2023 HRP.

Intensifying conflict, the active monsoon season and the premature closure of displacement camps by the de facto authorities, will see more people on the move, new vulnerabilities and the aggravation of pre-existing needs. The passage of Cyclone Mocha has only worsened an already dire humanitarian situation in Rakhine, the Northwest, and Northeast, triggering fresh displacement, damaging or destroying homes and community infrastructure, and disrupting already fragile livelihoods. At such a critical juncture, this allocation provides timely funding to the partners who are best-placed to enable a swift response to worsening humanitarian conditions, helping to prevent a further accumulation of unmet needs and growing reliance on negative coping mechanisms.     Through this allocation, the MHF aims to provide a comprehensive package of multi-sectoral assistance to people in need. Using an area-based approach, this allocation prioritizes hard-to-reach townships where displacement, needs and response gaps are highest, across the Northwest, Southeast, Northeast and Rakhine. It aims to improve access by directing funding to local partners and incentivizing partnerships with these organizations through sub-granting to reach more people, more quickly. Additionally, the allocation encourages the use of Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA), where appropriate and feasible, to help overcome access challenges and promote the safety and dignity of affected populations.     So far this year, the 2023 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) has only received US$74.9 million (10 per cent) of the $764.3 million total funding requirement. Amid continued underfunding, the disbursement of $18.25 million through this allocation – nearly a quarter of the funding secured against the 2023 HRP so far – will provide a much-needed injection of resources for humanitarian partners. This will help kickstart lifesaving response activities and channel increased funding to local organizations who have superior access and a proven ability to reach people in need but who face resource mobilization challenges.     In line with the strategy and priorities of the 2023 HRP, all projects funded under this allocation must ensure that the centrality of protection and disability inclusion are integrated into their proposals and activities. The Fund will promote the mainstreaming of explosive ordnance risk education as well as mental health and psychosocial support, encouraging partners to meaningfully incorporate relevant activities in their projects.

AllocationSummary: Since 26 October, fighting between the Myanmar Armed Forces (MAF) and various ethnic armed organizations (EAOs) has significantly intensified in northern Shan, displacing more than 23,000 people, a figure likely to increase in the days and weeks to come as active fighting is expected to persist, including the use of heavy weapons and airstrikes. This sudden and significant increase in humanitarian needs and protection risks is quickly outstripping the limited resources of partners in northern Shan, as the state has not been prioritized for funding in recent years, including through previous CERF and MHF allocations. As such, a swift injection of additional funding is required to enable partners to deliver a response at scale and to prevent an accumulation of unmet needs amid a rapidly worsening humanitarian situation.     Against this backdrop, this allocation provides timely funding to pre-selected partners best-placed to quickly scale-up assistance to new IDPs affected by the recent escalation in conflict. Based on a preliminary analysis of needs and the prevailing access situation, this allocation will promote the provision of Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA) and the local procurement of critical relief supplies, including food, medicines and medical supplies and NFIs, to ensure that assistance is quick, safely accessible and tailored to people’s needs. Additionally, given the rise of health and protection needs and risks, this allocation will support the provision of critical health and protection services, including mobile health clinics and mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS).
Documents: MHF 2023 Fourth Reserve Allocation Strategy.pdf##303020##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/MM-AllocDocs_2023_514_875.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Cyclone Mocha wrought devastation across Rakhine, the Northwest and Kachin. It caused significant damage to community infrastructure, disrupted vital services and undermined already fragile livelihoods, leaving a long road to recovery for affected populations with limited coping capacities to deal with this crisis within a crisis. At this critical juncture, MHF support is pivotal to help save lives, alleviate suffering, and restore critical services, infrastructure and livelihoods.     This $5 million allocation provides timely funding to pre-selected partners with sustained access and a proven ability to deliver aid in cyclone-affected areas of Rakhine, the Northwest and Kachin. The allocation strategically complements the MHF’s First Reserve Allocation for Cyclone Mocha, expanding the sectoral scope of the MHF-funded response while also supporting the transition to early recovery. It also strategically aligns with the prioritized activities and geographic scope of the Cyclone Mocha Flash Appeal.     The allocation prioritizes a combination of cash and in-kind assistance to improve access to education, protection and nutrition supplies and services for vulnerable children. It will also provide critical livelihood support and help jump-start early recovery efforts that will boost the local economy, generate income and rehabilitate essential community infrastructure. Additionally, it will add value by promoting the centrality of protection, helping scale-up child protection and Explosive Ordnance Risk Education responses while mainstreaming the prevention and response to gender-based violence.

Across Myanmar, intensified conflict along with heavy monsoon rains and flooding have triggered rising needs and displacement. This deterioration in the humanitarian situation comes as the most vulnerable are still reeling from the multi-faceted impacts of Cyclone Mocha in May. Against this backdrop, this allocation provides timely funding to scale-up assistance in areas that are difficult to access which have been recently affected by conflict and/or flooding. In particular, townships where people have experienced multiple displacements will be prioritized for urgent assistance to reduce the adoption of negative coping mechanisms and help save lives.    In line with the Humanitarian Coordinator’s (HC) Vision Paper for the Fund, this US$8 million allocation aims to facilitate the delivery of multi-sectoral assistance in difficult to access locations and areas of high multiple displacement by earmarking $3 million in direct funding to local NGOs and promoting sub-granting arrangements as vehicles for amplifying access. Additionally, this allocation will promote disability inclusion and explosive ordnance risk education (EORE), as a lack of capacity and resources continues to limit the mainstreaming of these key cross-cutting issues promoted by the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG) and MHF. Where safe and appropriate, cash responses will be promoted given the preference for cash assistance expressed by communities in areas facing frequent, multiple displacement.

AllocationSummary: Within the context of unprecedented political, socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis, the role of local and national NGOs in Myanmar has become increasingly critical to ensuring a context-appropriate humanitarian response. Recognizing this, enhanced localization will entail meaningful and sustained engagement of local partners in the decision-making and coordination of humanitarian operations through removing language barriers. To do so, the Myanmar Humanitarian Fund (MHF) will allocate funds for continuation of specialized interpretation and translation services that will support the inter-agency coordination of humanitarian efforts. This service will also enhance trust and transparency within the humanitarian community through strengthening data collection, data security and reporting as part of the 2024 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). Additionally, in line with recommendations from the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG), the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) and the recent Peer-2-Peer report, the MHF will allocate funds to support the rollout of Activity Info software to establish a common platform to optimize the reporting process to ensure it is streamlined, consistent across clusters, enhances data security and simplifies procedures for humanitarian partners. The procurement of Activity Info software through this allocation is critical as it will allow for the platform to be rolled out in time to harmonize all monitoring and reporting activities for the 2024 HRP.
Documents: 2023-08-30_MHF Third Reserve Allocation_Trans  Interp Services + Activity Info_Final.pdf##259794##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/MM-AllocDocs_2023_501_849.pdf##3rd reserve allocation strategy paper.

AllocationSummary: Since October 2023, conflict has expanded and intensified across vast swathes of the country, driving new displacement and worsening humanitarian needs. With very little carryover of funds into quarter one of 2024, UN agencies and humanitarian partners are strapped for resources, limiting their capacity to deliver a conflict response at scale or prepare for the disaster season ahead. Lack of funding threatens to propel a further accumulation of unmet needs that will leave affected people extremely vulnerable with the monsoon season just around corner.     Capitalizing on the agility and flexibility of the 48-hour response window, this allocation will enable pre-selected MHF partners to quickly assist people recently displaced by intensified clashes in Saging and Magway and support the procurement and pre-positioning of lifesaving aid in Rakhine to facilitate a rapid scale-up once access and security conditions permit. Amid chronic underfunding, many newly displaced in these locations have yet to receive assistance, making this allocation timely and urgent to help stave off an accumulation of unmet needs that will leave affected people even more vulnerable during the fast-approaching monsoon season. Projects will use a strategic combination of cash assistance and in-kind support to overcome access and logistics challenges where they arise and provide a flexible package of aid tailored to the local response landscape.     Through this timely injection of funding, the MHF will help sustain or potentially expand operational presence in these geographical areas, strengthen area-based coordination structures and improve response preparedness ahead of the monsoon season, adding value by bolstering response coordination and facilitating early action. In line with the Humanitarian Coordinator’s Vision Paper, this allocation will mainstream protection, including awareness-raising on unsafe migration and explosive ordnance risk education, to ensure an accessible and safe response in areas which face high levels of explosive ordnance contamination and displacement.

HRPPlans: Myanmar Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationSummary: As landmine and explosive ordnance (EO) contamination and related civilian casualties reach unprecedented levels in Myanmar, expanding explosive ordnance risk education (EORE) and disability inclusion across the response is critical and urgent. Given that a lack of capacity and resources is currently limiting efforts to mainstream and scale-up programme delivery in these key response-wide priorities, the HC has decided to allocate US$5,150,000 from the MHF to strengthen EORE and disability inclusion programming through a multi-year approach. This allocation will strategically linkup with the activities of the Mine Action Area of Responsibility (AoR) as well as the crucial work areas of the Technical Advisory Group on Disability Inclusion (TAG on DI) outlined in the 2024 Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan (HNRP). Additionally, amid funding shortfalls, this allocation will support the roll out of the next nationwide Multi-Sectoral Needs Analysis (MSNA), providing timely funding to gather and analyze disaggregated data, including on disability, that will inform the 2025 Humanitarian Programme Cycle, including the 2025 HNRP, and Food Security and Nutrition Analysis. This funding will allow the MSNA team to provide a dedicated disability analysis earlier in the HPC process to better inform planning on disability inclusion, and continue to capture EO concerns among affected people.  Through this allocation, the MHF will provide support to partners in delivering response-wide technical guidance and capacity strengthening activities, including for humanitarian organizations, clusters, Area Humanitarian Country Teams (HCTs) and Area Inter-Cluster Coordination Groups (ICCGs). It will ensure a more inclusive, accessible and safe humanitarian response for all, while also providing tailored support to address the differentiated needs of landmine/EO survivors and persons with disabilities. This disability component recognizes that disability takes on many forms including not only physical impairment but also mental, visual, hearing and/or communication challenges. Priorities include setting up and/or strengthening survivor assistance centers, physical rehabilitation and mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) services, as well as inclusive livelihood support including through the use of cash and voucher assistance. It is hoped that this unique allocation will act as a catalyst for more sustained funding for these important, yet chronically under-supported response areas.

HRPPlans: Myanmar Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationSummary: Since October 2023, the rapid spread of fighting across large swathes of the country has propelled a drastic increase in displacement, exacerbating pre-existing needs and raising grave protection concerns. Compounding this situation is the coming monsoon season (expected between May/June and October) which threatens to exacerbate already dire humanitarian needs and vulnerabilities in many areas where displacement is highest.     Against this backdrop, a timely injection of support from the MHF is needed to provide assistance to assist those recently displaced, many of whom are yet to receive any assistance due to significant underfunding and who will soon be exposed during the monsoon season. In line with the overarching strategy and priorities of the 2024 Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan (HNRP), this allocation aims to deliver lifesaving humanitarian assistance and services in areas with the highest levels of new or repeated displacement, prioritizing townships with the most severe needs. The allocation prioritizes flexible multi-sectoral assistance for newly displaced people and those repeatedly on the move, using a mix of cash and in-kind aid tailored local context, shifting access and security environments as well as the accessibility and functionality of markets.     This allocation will help sustain and potentially expand operational presence and access in conflict-affected areas, and improve response preparedness amid the monsoon season. Amid worsening conflict, increased displacement, and expanded landmine and explosive ordnance (EO) contamination, all funded projects will be expected to mainstream protection considerations, including explosive ordnance risk education (EORE), disability inclusion and awareness-raising on unsafe migration, ensuring the principled delivery of aid that is safely accessible by all.

HRPPlans: Myanmar Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationSummary: Heavy rains caused by the monsoon season and remnants of Typhoon Yagi triggered severe flooding across Myanmar, affecting more than 1 million people countrywide. The floods have battered conflict areas with high pre-existing needs, leaving affected people extremely vulnerable and in urgent need of lifesaving aid. Using the 48-hour response modality, this allocation will provide timely funding to select partners, specifically local and international NGOs, who have sustained access and a proven ability to effectively deliver aid in flood-affected areas. In line with the MHF’s commitment to localization, 50 per cent ($2,500,000) of this allocation will be earmarked for direct funding to local partners.     Capitalizing on a joint CERF-MHF strategy development and prioritization process, this allocation strategically complements the recently launched CERF Rapid Response allocation ($4 million), ensuring maximum complementarity between these allocations to expand the sectoral coverage and impact of the flood response delivered through HC-managed pooled funds. This allocation will cover gaps in geographical coverage by targeting townships not covered by CERF and by bolstering response efforts in the hardest hit areas where needs are quickly outstripping the limited resources of partners. With bureaucratic impediments and procurement and logistics constraints making the delivery of in-kind relief supplies challenging, the use of cash-based assistance, including multi-purpose cash, will be prioritized wherever markets are functioning and accessible, promoting a quicker response for affected people that will have the added benefit of helping local markets recover.        In line with the HC’s Vision Paper, this allocation will mainstream the centrality of protection, including the prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse as well as explosive ordnance risk education, as affected populations face heightened protection risks in the aftermath of the devastating floods, including from landmines and explosive ordnance that may have shifted during the floods, placing people on the move at increased risk of a landmine-related injuries or even death.

HRPPlans: Myanmar Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationSummary: On 28 March, a powerful 7.7 magnitude earthquake rocked central Myanmar, killing more than 3,500 people, damaging or destroying scores of homes and cutting off access to crucial services. This devastating quake has significantly exacerbated already high levels of pre-existing needs in many areas already prioritized under the 2025 HNRP, requiring an immediate scale-up of the response to save lives, alleviate suffering and reduce vulnerabilities ahead of the fast-approaching monsoon season.  In support of the Flash HNRP Addendum, the MHF will launch an allocation of US$5 million through the 48-hour response window to support rapid, localized emergency response delivered by pre-selected partners with sustained access and capacity to reach the most vulnerable with multi-sectoral assistance. In line with the Humanitarian Reset, this allocation will prioritize funding for local partners, including lumpsum donations to local frontline responders, and cash-based programming as vehicles for the delivery of a flexible, context-appropriate response. Partners will focus on hard-to-reach areas which are at risk of remaining underserved as access and bureaucratic impediments continue to restrict aid delivery.  As part of a complementary and sequenced OCHA Pooled Fund response, this allocation will build on an additional $7 million reprogrammed towards the earthquake response through the MHF’s first Standard Allocation ($20 million) and other flexibility measures, including the activation of contingency budget lines and cost extensions for ongoing projects. The allocation has also been developed to complement the ongoing $5 million CERF Rapid Response allocation and the forthcoming second round of CERF support, increasing the scale and depth of aid delivered through these HC-managed funding mechanisms.  In line with the HC’s Vision Paper for the Fund, this allocation will support quality programming through earmarked support for AAP, disability inclusion, EORE and PSEA to promote a more inclusive and safe response. Beyond its immediate life-saving impact, the delivery of critical support, including multi-purpose cash, will help increase the resilience of affected people to cope with the compounding impacts of ongoing conflict and the additional threat posed by the looming monsoon season.
HRPPlans: Myanmar Original Humanitarian Needs and Response P##2025

AllocationSummary: This allocation aims to scale-up the delivery of prioritized life-saving humanitarian assistance to crisis-affected people with severe needs in hard-to-reach and underserved areas affected by escalating conflict and recurrent climate shocks. The strategic timing of this allocation will help kick-start aid delivery and resource mobilization efforts against the 2025 Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan (HNRP). The timing of this allocation will also be critical in supporting resilience-building efforts in communities affected by the countrywide floods in 2024, which remain disproportionately exposed to the compounding impacts of enduring conflict and new climate shocks during the 2025 monsoon season (May-October).     This allocation builds on the joint CERF-MHF strategy development and prioritization process which was rolled out for the 2024 CERF Underfunded Emergencies (UFE) window (Round 2), expanding the collective reach and impact of HC-managed pooled funds by covering additional geographical locations and sectoral activities. This includes expanding geographical coverage into underserved conflict areas with extreme or catastrophic levels of intersectoral needs severity according to the 2025 HNRP, such as Kachin and Rakhine, and prioritizing much-needed funding for chronically under-resourced clusters as well as livelihood and resilience-building interventions.    Through the Flexible Localization Envelope (FLEX), this allocation will earmark US$7 million for local partners with limited experience managing international humanitarian grants, including new MHF partners onboarded in 2024, adding value by facilitating access to funding for local organizations. Additionally, this allocation will bolster cash coordination efforts across the response by promoting Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance (MPCA) following its introduction as a stand-alone section in the 2025 HNRP. In line with the MHF’s commitment to quality programming, this allocation will also support the mainstreaming of critical protection interventions, including prevention and response to sexual exploitation and abuse and gender-based violence as well as disability inclusion and explosive ordnance risk education.

HRPPlans: Myanmar Original Humanitarian Needs and Response P##2025

AllocationSummary: Under its third allocation of 2025, the MHF will allocate $11 million in support of the Humanitarian Reset in Myanmar. Flexible funding will be made available through a competitive submission process to NGOs delivering timely, multi-sectoral humanitarian response. As needs show no signs of abating in 2026 and the funding landscape remains constrained, funding will be strategically prioritized through devolved operational decision-making processes to deliver impact in support of those most in need in Myanmar.  Direct support for local partners and equitable partnerships form the backbone of the strategy. Funding will be earmarked for grassroots local organizations, including newly eligible and previously unfunded local partners, through the Flexible Localization Envelope (FLEX) ($3.5 million), with an overall target of 50 per cent of total funding available ($5.5 million) direct to local partners (general and FLEX envelopes). Where funding international NGOs, transparency, resource sharing, capacity support, safety and security of local actors and strong oversight and monitoring will be prioritized.   The allocation approach is strategically aligned with the priorities of the 2026 Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan (HNRP) incentivizing response in hard-to-reach areas of Myanmar with highest severity and unmet needs. MHF’s inclusive consultation processes ensure collectively agreed, locally led response approaches and decentralized decision-making on the use of increasingly limited resources.   This allocation will also support a more inclusive, accountable and innovative response in supporting partners to submit projects mainstreaming critical protection and cross-cutting approaches, including AAP, disability inclusion, EORE, gender and PSEA. Up to $1 million will be available for dedicated submissions from local partners demonstrating innovative  approaches in priority cross-cutting areas in line with system-wide initiatives promoted by the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) and Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG).

AllocationSummary: Mozambique is ranked 28 out of 46 least-developed countries globally. The development situation has been compounded by multiple lingering and emerging humanitarian crises across the country for several years. The Northern province in Mozambique known as Cabo Delgado is the poorest and  has experienced an armed insurgency against State targets and civilians since 2017. The convergence of severe and escalating crises – conflict, climate shocks, and a deteriorating socio-economic situation further compounded the humanitarian situation in the province.   In its 2023 SEA Risk Assessment, the United Nations Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) revealed significant gaps in prevention, reporting, and accountability mechanisms, particularly among local and national NGOs. The global funding suspension further threatens capacity-building efforts for national organizations, which are most in need of support to establish robust SEA investigative frameworks. In its efforts to bridge this gap, UNOCHA has approached UNOPS to support the implementation of the project Building Safe and Accountable Operations: Strengthening the Security and PSEA capacities. The overall objective of the UNOPS project is to enhance the operational security of partners working in the highly complex and volatile districts of Macomia and Quissanga in Cabo Delgado, where elevated security risks threaten the continuity of humanitarian operations and the safety of the aid workers.

AllocationTitle: 1st Reserve Allocation 2021 through NGO Consortium Partnership - 2021- Nigeria
AllocationSummary: The 2021 First Reserve Allocation of US$4.0 million is designed to deliver integrated education, nutrition, and protection services to vulnerable and crisis-affected children and adolescents in the BAY States through the NGO Consortium Partnership Approach.

In this period of rapidly deteriorating food insecurity in North-East Nigeria, The Nigeria Humanitarian Fund 2021 First Standard Allocation of US$23.8 million will deliver essential life-saving services, address non-food needs, and support core pipelines to ensure the viability of frontline activities.  The allocation will provide dignified living conditions for the most vulnerable and crisis-affected people in Borno, Adamawa, and Yobe States. Through a multi-sector approach, the Allocation will ensure the continuity of essential humanitarian assistance provided through the NHF 2020 Standard Allocation and will multiply the impact of the CERF Under Funded Emergency Allocation currently in process.       The Allocation has prioritized funding for all sectors and enablers; Camp Coordination and Camp Management, Early Recovery and Livelihoods, Education, Shelter and NFIs, Food Security, Health, Nutrition, Protection, WASH, and Common Services and Support.

The Durable Solutions' project is envisaged as the first phase of a drive for durable solutions for the long-term displaced. It will put the displaced people at the centre, being driven by the intentions and wishes of the displaced, gauged by intention surveys. It will be an iterative and incremental approach.  Until there is peace and conditions are conducive for large-scale returns or durable solutions, the project will seek to promote durable solutions where there are opportunities, defined by security and resources available.
Documents: NHF 2021 Second Reserve Allocation Strategy Paper Durable Solutions HC Endorsed 14.12.21.pdf##830579##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/NGA-AllocDocs_2021_375_515.pdf##

AllocationSummary: An envelope of US$3.5 million is available under this allocation for the Nutrition Sector. This allocation will ensure the continuity of essential nutrition services provided through the first Standard Allocation of the NHF 2021 (which provided core pipeline support for the health and WASH sectors, rather than nutrition); as well as of the recent CERF 2021 Under Funded Emergency Allocation, which included a RUTF component (10,320 cartons for a total of $580,000).

With (a) the arrival of the rainy season and subsequent flooding and (b) a significant rise in recent malnutrition cases, the NHF plans to release $US 7 million to address immediate life-saving concerns under an Emergency Response Reserve Allocation. The $4.5 million rainy season response will address severe damage to household shelters and NFIs and provide critical water and sanitation support to limit the spread of cholera and waterborne diseases. The $2.5 million malnutrition response will address recent alarming spikes in Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) cases and Inpatient Functional Therapeutic Centre (IFTC) admissions, with the aim of reducing morbidity and mortality.
Documents: 2022 NHF 1st Reserve Allocation Strategy HC Endorsed 17.8.22-1.pdf##397884##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/NGA-AllocDocs_2022_430_681.pdf##

AllocationSummary: With the Nigeria Humanitarian Response plan only 25 per cent funded as of August 2022, the NHF plans to release $13 million to support life-saving humanitarian interventions to improve the protection environment for displaced people in northeast Nigeria. Some $12 million will be allocated to underfunded (sub)sectors to support activities under Strategic Objective 1  by providing life-saving assistance to remedy and avert the most severe threats to life and health. An additional $1 million will be used to pilot innovative interventions under three cross-cutting themes: (i) Disability (ii) Accountability to Affected Populations and (iii) Localization.
Documents: 2022 NHF 1st Standard Allocation Strategy 15.8.22.docx##116855##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/NGA-AllocDocs_2022_431_680.docx##

AllocationSummary: Heavy rains in the past few weeks have caused the worst floods throughout Nigeria in a decade. According to the National Emergency Response Agency (NEMA), as at Nov 1, 2022, some 3.2 million people were affected, with more than 600 dying and 1.4 million displaced. 300,000 houses have been completely damaged, and some 569,000 hectares of farmland have been destroyed. Given the scale of the emergency they have requested all available actors, including United Nations, for immediate assistance.    The scale of the natural disaster is considerable and requires timely interventions to save lives. While the IFRC and Red Cross/Crescent societies have launched an appeal, this is expected only cover 25 per cent of the needs, if fully funded.     The Nigeria Humanitarian Coordinator plans to allocate $5 million under the NHF Reserve modality to provide immediate life-saving assistance in WASH, Health and other critical areas to areas inside the BAY states (Borno, Adamawa and Yobe). These interventions will complement a CERF Rapid Response outside the BAY states. These combined interventions are expected to leverage additional bilateral support to the government through non-traditional donors that have indicated their willingness provide they see a solid commitment from the United Nations.

AllocationTitle: 1st Reserve Allocation 2023: Addressing Food Security Crisis in Borno, Adamawa and Yobe
AllocationSummary: Food security in Nigeria continues to be impacted by persistent conflict in the BAY states, climate change, inflation and rising food prices. This is compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic, fuel price inflation and its knock-on effects on households' income and livelihoods. Millions of Nigerians will be at risk of hunger during the lean season (June and August), with children most at risk of acute malnutrition. In parallel with a $9 million CERF Allocation, the NHF is activating a $11 million Reserve Allocation to rapidly scale up local response to address food access and insecurity.

AllocationTitle: 2nd Reserve Allocation 2024: Pilot Anticipatory Action Allocation: Floods and Cholera in NE Nigeria
AllocationSummary: This funding allocation aims to enhance preparedness and resilience against floods and cholera outbreaks by improving emergency response capabilities. It also introduces an innovative Anticipatory Action approach, using forecasts to initiate predetermined measures to mitigate the severe humanitarian consequences of these crises before they fully develop, thus strategically addressing risks and vulnerabilities.
Documents: 2024 NHF RA2 Floods Cholera Anticipatory Action Allocation Strategy for HC Approved 15.8.24.pdf##380976##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/NGA-AllocDocs_2024_1306_1026.pdf##RA2 2024 - Allocation Strategy Paper

AllocationTitle: 3rd Reserve Allocation 2024: Rapid Response Allocation for Floods in BAY States, Nigeria
AllocationSummary: Following extremely high seasonal flooding throughout Nigeria, the overflowing and collapse of the Alau dam caused some of the worst flooding in the BAY  states of northeast Nigeria in 30 years.  This reserve allocation will spearhead the humanitarian response by addressing the most urgent life-saving needs of flood-affected people in seven of the most affected Local Government Areas (LGAs). Rapid distribution of life-saving essentials including clean water and sanitation, camp management and camp coordination, shelter, and healthcare will be provided as well as bolster disease prevention efforts and minimize the looming threat of waterborne disease.     This NHF allocation, in conjunction with a parallel CERF appeal, will demonstrate the commitment of the United Nations to this response, in an effort to catalyze additional resources.
