PHPF 2019 First Standard Allocation for Drought Response     In January, the Humanitarian Coordinator (HC) invited the members of Pakistan Humanitarian Pooled Fund (PHPF) Advisory Board for a meeting, where OCHA provided analysis of the multi-sector needs assessment for Sindh and Balochistan drought situation for prioritization and decision making in the context of the PHPF’s first Standard Allocation 2019. The composition of PHPF Advisory Board equally represented donors, UN agencies, national and international organizations to provide strategic support to the HC during the allocation process. Government and humanitarian actors were also involved in the needs identification and prioritization process through bilateral and collective consultations.   • For PHPF allocation, Districts Umarkot and Tharparkar in Sindh while Districts Killa Abdullah and Chagai in Balochistan have been prioritized. The selection of these four districts was done on the basis of information and analysis made through various assessments including the NDC assessments in Sindh and Balochistan. The areas prioritized during CERF allocation process were also taken into consideration.     • US$ 4 million was made available for the first standard allocation in 2019.   • The AB agreed to keep the duration of projects between 6-9 months.     Purpose of the Allocation Strategy and linkages to the Government Drought Response   The allocation strategy is in line with drought overall response plan and to seek at least one out of two following strategic objectives of said plan.   1. Augment government efforts to provide immediate, life-saving assistance and life-sustaining assistance to the population affected by drought.   2. Support the restoration of livelihoods of the drought-affected population through resilience-building activities.   The standard allocation taken into the consideration the following key recommendations of drought assessment reports through integrated drought response approach:   • Implementation of minimum initial service packages to ensure access to emergency essential health care   • Support farmers by providing drought resistant crops, inputs, and promotion of climate smart agriculture. Specifically, provide drought resistant seed of cereals, pulses, legumes and vegetables. Cash is proposed as the assistance modality for immediate livelihood recovery support to the targeted households carrying multiple benefits.   • Rehabilitation of water facilities (Tarai /tobas), water conservation and introduction Increase access to improved sources of water for the highly vulnerable areas and priority affected districts/talukas through the repair/rehabilitation of non‐functional water supply systems and water treatment plants   • Provide necessary assistance to supply livestock fodder, feed, water and veterinary care as livelihood of 80 per cent of the total papulation in the drought affected areas is dependent on livestock as their main source of living   • Livestock Protection and Management interventions by engaging the services of all technical agencies and the concerned line department.   • Investment in the establishment of operation and maintenance systems that are community and/or local government owned as relevant and that address long‐term sustainability.   • Sanitation, the access to household level toilets, should continue to be addressed through provision of sanitation kits aimed at eradicating open defecation.   Provision of life saving nutrition services to mother and child, such as screening and treatment of acute malnourished children of 6 to 59 months (severe and moderate usually double then SAM caseload), treatment of malnourished PLW ensuring complete package of CMAM (OTP+TSFP) services in all the drought affected district.
Documents: PHPF 2019 First Standard Allocation Strategy Paper for Drought Response.pdf##832739##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/PAK-AllocDocs_2019_196_134.pdf##

AllocationSummary: 1.	Girls and boys less than five years of age and women with acute malnutrition in drought-affected areas access appropriate acute malnutrition (SAM, MAM, and SC) management services. Mothers and caretakers in targeted communities access skilled support for appropriate maternal, infant and young child nutrition (MIYCN). Girls and boys less than five years of age and pregnant and lactating women in target communities access micronutrients from fortified foods, supplements, or multiple-micronutrient preparations.  2.	Returnee communities of Kuram agency have access to water and sanitation facilities that are culturally and gender-appropriate, secure and user-friendly to ensure a smooth transition to longer-term recovery and development.   3.	Extension and improvement in the provision of primary health care services with more emphasis on MNCH and PSP, to the marginalized community of Baka Khel Camp, especially women & children.   4.	Ensure continued access to health care by the returning population and provide public health response to outbreaks of communicable diseases to curtail preventable morbidity and mortality in South Waziristan Agency of FATA.

AllocationSummary: In the Gaza Strip, Total envelop USD 8.5 million.     Objective 1: Mitigate the impact of restrictions imposed on Gaza Strip as well as the violence in the context of demonstrations at the fence with Israel by:     •	FSS: Support the livelihood of vulnerable Palestinians in ARA (land and sea) and cash-based activities, including unconditional access to food. $2.2 million (26%)    •	Health: Deployment of medical teams to conduct surgeries, to reduce the need for referrals outside of Gaza and reduce the waiting period for patients in need for treatment, Mental health and psychosocial support interventions targeting children and adults $1.5 million (17.5%)      •	WASH: Repair the nonfunctioning of WASH facilities, including recently destroyed facilities in Gaza Strip to maintain existing levels of essential WASH services. Provision of WASH interventions to mitigate and respond to flooding in the Gaza Strip. $1.8 million (21%)    •	 Protection: Child protection case management, including MHPSS, remedial classes,  alternative care arrangements, reintegration into school/vocational training, cash support and referral for specialized services and Sheltering, legal aid, cash support and income generation, and referral for specialized services for GBV survivors. $1 million (12%)      •	Shelter& NFI: Rehabilitation of substandard shelters for most vulnerable living in extreme conditions with a focus on Bedouin families and IDPs using cash modality. $2 million (23.5%)    IN THE WEST BANK: Total envelope USD 3.5 million.     •	Objective 1: Support the implementation of the Hebron ICCG plan with $2 million as follows    •	Education (priorities objectives from the ICCG plan ) $600,000 (16%)  •	Protection (priorities objectives from the ICCG plan ) $500,000 (14%)  •	Health (priorities objectives from the ICCG plan ) $500,000 (14%)  •	WASH (priorities objectives from the ICCG plan ) $400,000 (14%)    •	Objective 2: Support vulnerable Palestinian living in the Jordan valley with $1.5 million as follows:    •	FSS: Rehabilitation and provision of productive assets and inputs, for farmers, herders, breeders, including the promotion of technical capacities and small- scale production units, and using the BBB (Build-Back Better) approach for increased resilience. $750,000 (21 %)    •	Shelter NFI: Shelter rehabilitation/summarization in the communities suffer from protection concerns with a mixed approach between in-kind and cash-based interventions. Provision of protective assets, protective shelter materials and NFIs to vulnerable HHs with a particular focus on temporarily displaced HHs due to military closures in Firing Zones. Stockpiling of emergency Shelter/NFIs for a likely scenario and providing satisfactory reasons for this activity. Also, capacity building for communities to be prepared in case of shocks, whether natural or humanmade. $750,000 (21 %)

AllocationTitle: 3rd Reserve allocation to support COVID-19 Response Plan
AllocationSummary: The COVID-19 Response Plan for the occupied Palestinian territory (oPt) presents the joint strategy of the humanitarian community, including UNRWA, to respond to the public health needs and immediate humanitarian consequences of the pandemic in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip. It is guided by the Health Cluster’s Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan, published on 14 March 2020, which is designed to steer a coordinated effort in support of the Ministry of Health (MoH) and the overall efforts of the Government of Palestine (GoP). The plan seeks to mobilize support to implement the most urgent and critical activities over the next three months. The primary focus of the plan continues to be prevention, preparedness and treatment of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak.   Central to the plan are the following overall objectives:    1. To prevent further transmission of COVID-19 in the oPt;   2. To provide adequate care for patients affected by COVID-19 and to support their families and close contacts; and 3. To mitigate the worst effects of the pandemic.    In consultation with the local authorities, the Humanitarian Coordinator has decided to further release $ US 4.88

AllocationSummary: Improving resilience of most vulnerable communities and enhancing access to basic services in oPt.  The oPt HF will allocate a total of $9 million in funding in response to the urgent needs of the vulnerable under the Shelter, WASH, Protection, Food Security, Education and Health clusters, by responding to two main priority needs emphasized by the Cluster Coordinators:  1. Support and improve the resilience of the most vulnerable people and communities in the oPt (especially in Area C of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip)  2. Enhance vulnerable households' access to essential services.  The allocation aims to alleviate the humanitarian consequences resulting from the prolonged occupation, including Israeli settler violence, increased use of live ammunition by the Israeli Security Forces and settlers, the overall increasing movement restrictions in the West Bank and the blockade on the Gaza Strip. The allocation will support lifesaving and life-sustaining needs prioritized within the oPt Humanitarian Response Plan 2022  The allocation will respond to ongoing humanitarian needs supporting livelihoods and strengthening access to essential services in the oPt, including providing shelter assistance to vulnerable households at risk of or affected by natural hazards in the Gaza Strip and providing urgent shelter rehabilitation, shelter and NFIs to vulnerable groups affected by conflict and/or violation of IHL in the West Bank. Protection activities, such as emergency child protection and psychosocial support, including to GBV survivors, will be provided, as well as improved access to education and learning opportunities through emergency repair of schools and non-formal education services and the provision of school-based psychosocial support to staff and students. The allocation will also improve people's preparedness for the winter season in the Gaza Strip – and improve access to sanitation for the communities not connected to sewer systems and suffering wastewater accumulation.

Ensure inclusive, accessible, coordinated provision of quality basic services for most vulnerable people in emergency situations in the Gaza Strip and West Bank including Area C and East Jerusalem.   3.	Address vulnerable households’ multiple immediate essential needs and improve access to life-saving services through strengthening food security, sustaining livelihoods and providing Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance.

AllocationTitle: Emergency Fleet Augmentation for Enhanced Gaza Aid Delivery
AllocationSummary: This allocation is a strategic response to the critical operational necessities caused by the War in Gaza. The urgency of this allocation stems from the serious security incidents at Gaza's crossings, which have severely impacted the existing United Nations fleet and logistics capabilities. This has created a pressing need for immediate resource injection through the Reserve Allocation modality, a decision influenced by the compromised capacity to distribute vital aid effectively within the Gaza Strip.  This allocation aims to significantly enhance the logistical framework by procuring additional trucks urgently. This reinforcement is a response to immediate operational challenges and a strategic move to alleviate concerns regarding the UN system's capacity to manage increased aid flow into Gaza. This acquisition will directly address the informal gaps imposed on aid entry by authorities, demonstrating a bolstered capacity and advocating for increased aid approval.

AllocationTitle: Emergency Fuel Support for Continuity of Critical Humanitarian Operations and Essential Services in Gaza
AllocationSummary: An allocation of US$ 5,000,000 has been designated to ensure the continuity of critical humanitarian operations and essential services in Gaza by providing emergency fuel support to key actors across multiple sectors. This funding aims to mitigate immediate risks of service disruptions in healthcare, WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene), food production, telecommunications, financial institutions, and logistics during the ongoing crisis. By facilitating coordinated emergency fuel distribution and maintaining infrastructure for storage and transportation, the allocation seeks to establish efficient fuel supply mechanisms. This will enable uninterrupted operations of critical facilities and humanitarian actors, addressing acute needs and maintaining essential services for the affected population.

AllocationTitle: Protection from Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA) Support in Gaza
AllocationSummary: In light of the severely deteriorating conditions across Gaza, with alarming increases in civilian displacement, infrastructure destruction, and threats to civilian protection, this allocation will support the strengthening and scale up of the PSEA Network currently hosted by UNICEF. This network is a critical resource for organizations on the ground committed to preventing sexual exploitation and abuse within an exacerbated protection crisis and where vulnerabilities have escalated substantially, especially among women, children, and displaced persons. The allocation will provide $500,000 for the PSEA network’s core operations in Gaza to ensure access to ongoing protective services. This initiative is a response to recent data indicating increased exploitation risks, compounded by limited humanitarian access, displacement, and diminished support services, necessitating an immediate operational scale-up.

AllocationSummary: The Fourth Reserve Allocation in 2025 is being launched at a moment of profound crisis. Gaza continues to face large-scale destruction, displacement, and the breakdown of essential services, while the recent ceasefire provides only partial and uncertain relief. In the West Bank, escalating protection risks, movement restrictions, and declining humanitarian access have deepened vulnerabilities across affected communities. Field reporting and inter-cluster assessments point to widening service gaps that require a targeted and realistic funding approach.     Given the scale of needs and the limited HF envelope, the allocation adopts a focused strategy. Rather than dispersing resources across all clusters, the Fund concentrates support where it can enable measurable change and where partners can deliver under current operational conditions. This avoids the pattern of small, symbolic contributions that do not meaningfully alter outcomes, and instead channels funding toward clusters where HF resources are capable of strengthening services, filling critical gaps, or restoring essential functions.

AllocationSummary: Adaptive Humanitarian Response for Gaza Strip and West Bank:   The Third Reserve Allocation is being launched in a context shaped by prolonged military occupation, repeated displacement, and restricted access to basic services. Within this reality, the allocation responds to two urgent dilemmas faced by humanitarian actors on the ground. First, how to avoid placing funds with partners who—due to ongoing restrictions—cannot currently operate. Second, how to ensure that funding is not withheld for too long, risking the loss of rare and brief moments when humanitarian access becomes possible. In response, the allocation introduces a dual-track model, which seeks to channel resources responsibly while remaining poised to act immediately when conditions shift.  This model includes a Reserve Track, which supports actions that can proceed under existing constraints, and a 48-Hour Track, which pre-positions flexible funding with capable and locally anchored partners who are ready to respond as soon as access opens. A built-in six-month trigger ensures that funds do not sit idle; if access does not improve, they will be redirected toward interventions that can be delivered in the current context.

AllocationSummary: This $600,000 reserve allocation to assist With the increased demand for field presence of humanitarian organisations and the expected variability of shocks including floods and forced displacement, it is forecasted that logistics requirements will remain high or even become higher. In particular, the expected withdrawal of ATMIS personnel may impact the accessibility of airstrips support for fixed-wing aircraft. Additionally, the El Niño impact has the potential to significantly deteriorate roads and runways, while the Black Lion operation adds to the uncertainty surrounding security conditions in the short term.  These three events can create a new type of triple threat to Logistics Operations. Considering the prioritization exercise from the HRP, efficient logistics capacity provides organisations with the required support to respond to shocks at a moment when the gap between needs and resources is widening. Today, operational readiness remains as important as it was at the peak of the drought response.

AllocationSummary: This $650,000 reserve allocation to the Somalia NGO consortium (SNC) and the International NGO safety organization (INSO) will create an enabling environment for humanitarian non-profit organizations to better fulfill their mandate.      SNC’s allocation of $350,000 will allow the entity to strengthen its role in facilitating the exchange, production, and provision of information to members. This will allow NGOs to make informed decisions on operational aspects and provide a conducive space for NGOs to deliver humanitarian assistance with minimal or no interference. The funding will strengthen SNC’s role in following up on Post Delivery Aid Diversion (PDAD) recommendations. It will also enhance SNC’s work on minority group inclusion in humanitarian coordination and delivery structures.  INSO’s allocation of $300,000 will provide essential security coordination and information services to NGOs that will help to understand the operating environment and reduce the risks confronting NGO staff and operations. The ongoing ATMIS drawdown portends potential security and political shift that can affect NGO operations and may lead to access constraints. Through INSO services, NGOs will gain better information, leading to enhanced access to vulnerable populations and an expanding geographical reach.

AllocationTitle: Reserve Allocation 3 2025  Enabling Programmes - UN RMU
AllocationSummary: This USD 250,000 reserve allocation to United Nations Risk Management Unit (RMU), Somalia will create a critical enabling environment of safe, effective, and accountable humanitarian operations in an environment that is facing an extremely fragile outlook in light of funding challenges, climate shocks, security threats, and the upcoming election cycle—in doing so, it echoes the Somalia Humanitarian Fund (SHF) principles of transparency, accountability, and strategic relevance.  The RMU, from its central role within the Office of the Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator, achieves this by aligning project controls across UN agencies, fostering inter-agency cooperation in procurement oversight, due diligence, and risk harmonisation. The RMU will maintain and upgrade digital risk tools such as CIMS, CIRT, and RiskIQ, while providing risk analysis and advisory services to humanitarian actors. These services form the backbone of safe operations in Somalia’s high-risk environment, reducing systemic risks and operational delays and ensuring aid delivery even in insecure and hard-to-reach locations.

CERF Rapid Response: South Sudan Apr 2025 (Conflict)

AllocationSummary: 1st Round Standard Allocation
2nd Round Standard Allocation
Reserve Allocation 1
1st Round Standard Allocation

On 6 June 2019, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SSHF) Advisory Board endorsed the allocation of US$36 million for the 2019 Second Standard allocation. The allocation’s objective is to provide resources to address priority humanitarian needs in alignment with the 2019 HRP strategic objectives. The allocation will prioritise front-line activities based on their relative time-criticality and an understanding of funding available from other sources.  The allocation will prioritize about 26 counites that have been identified as priority based on the inter-sectoral severity of need analysis. The counites were selected through the ICWG consultations and took into account the inter-sectoral severity of need and gaps humanitarian response.   In line with the World Humanitarian Summit, Grand Bargain commitment to increase funding to local and national responders, the allocation will promote the funding to national as a principled humanitarian action of keeping humanitarian response as local as possible and as international as necessary.   Where applicable, the allocation will promote the Emergency Relief Coordinator (ERC) Thematic Priorities for pooled fund allocations by giving special attention to projects which mainstream the four thematic priorities; (a) support for women and girls, including tackling gender-based violence, reproductive health and empowerment, (b) programmes targeting disabled people, (c) education in protracted crises and (d) other aspects of protection.
Reserve Allocation 1

The primary trigger of the SSHF 2nd Reserve Allocation is the devastating impact of flooding since June 2019 that affected 908,000 people, of whom at least 420,000 people are in need of immediate humanitarian assistance. The projects to be implemented with this allocation are aligned with Strategic Objective one of the South Sudan HRP 2019, to save lives by providing timely and integrated multi-sector lifesaving assistance to reduce acute needs among the most vulnerable people. The rains have resulted in a sharp rise of water levels across some 30 flooded counties. The SSHF funding has been strictly prioritized for life-saving assistance for the flood affected population.
Documents: SSHF_Second Reserve Allocation Strategy.pdf##1504677##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2019_31_2.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The South Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SSHF) First Standard Allocation is allocating US$ 35 million to kick-start time critical, life-saving frontline activities in selected counties in South Sudan, in line with the 2020 HRP needs and strategic priorities through a multi-sector approach (envelope A, $20 million), single sector response (envelope B, $13 million) and GBV response (envelope C, 2 million).

The Humanitarian Coordinator with the launch of a 5 million USD reserve allocation via the emergency response window wishes to support the rapid procurement of PPE through the global COVID-19 Supply Portal, as an immediate measure to kick-start the overall procurement process for South Sudan. The SSHF first reserve allocation will allow for South Sudan to facilitate this very time-sensitive procurement in a setting where accessing this equipment is globally competitive. The Humanitarian’s Coordinator main objective is to ensure that health workers as well as other actors who are needed to perform critical public health functions are able to receive the much-needed PPEs in prioritized locations.

South Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SSHF) 2020 Second Reserve Allocation (SSHF-2020-RA2, US$ 10 million). In line with the current humanitarian situation, the reserve allocation will support time critical, life-saving frontline activities in selected counties in affected by the recent floods in South Sudan

AllocationSummary: This First 2022 Standard Allocation (SA) amounting to US$25 million will provide a significant boost to the   humanitarian efforts in addressing the impact of the increased violence and food insecurity in ten counties of the   four worst-hit states with a convergence of needs: Warrap, Jonglei, Unity and Western Equatoria states.  In line with the 2022 Humanitarian Coordinator’s vision and the 2022 HNO/HRP re-prioritization exercise, through a   people’s centered approach, the allocation aims at:  • Promoting the joint programming for more efficiency of the interventions.  • Maximizing the impact of the SSHF funding by scaling up the response in complementarity with the 2022   CERF allocations in three of the targeted states.  • Addressing the needs of the most vulnerable groups such as the women and girls and people with disabilities.   • Ensuring the centrality of protection in humanitarian action.  • Encouraging the use of cash and voucher assistance – especially multi-purpose cash – where feasible.  • Maintaining the positioning of the Fund as a vital vehicle for localization by seeking to allocate up to 25 per   cent of the allocated envelope to NNGOs partners.

AllocationSummary: The reserve allocation will support common logistics services to the wider humanitarian response in South Sudan. The allocation will be timely in supporting the humanitarian organizations with air cargo transportation to areas inaccessible by road at a time when overall funding to the logistics cluster is limited.   The funding will provide the  much required financial support o enable continued support to air cargo transport capacity and sustain air operations by maintaining a fixed wing aircraft and to support requests for air cargo transport to non-ICCG prioritized locations, emergencies, and more static responses such as Health and Nutrition.
The allocation will support the implementation of flood preparedness activities in Bentiu through the strengthening of dykes and rehabilitation of roads ahead of the rains season.

The reserve allocation will enable the delivery of humanitarian assistance in South Sudan by injecting vital resources to support the South Sudan NGO Forum (SSNGOF) in its coordination and access function on behalf of the humanitarian community in South Sudan. Specifically, the project will support the NGO Forum to engage with national and state level authorities to address both the access and operational issues NGO’s face in delivering humanitarian assistance in South Sudan. The project will support the operationalization of the NGO Act 2016 Review Working Group and engagement with the Ministry of Labour in developing Labour Law Regulations for resolving disputes.   The support will provide critical resources to strengthen the governance and management of the NGO Forum through implementing the recommendations of the 2021 Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) Risk Assessment Report, the 2022 Independent Investigations Report and the Governance and Management Review Report.
Health Reserve Allocation - Early Action

The escalation in tensions and conflict in Tonga County arises in August at the time when the humanitarian situation in South Sudan remains dire, amidst a challenging operational environment comprising of diminished funding to respond the basic needs of the most vulnerable in country.   While the humanitarian community continues to prioritize limited resources, the estimation is that a minimum of $SU 14.4 million will be required to respond to the critical needs of 36,000 people highly affected by the on-going Tonga conflict.  This Reserve allocation of up to US$11.2 million aims at ensuring that the critical emerging needs of the internally displaced persons (IDPs) are met.

AllocationSummary: Following the elevated risk of catastrophic flooding in Unity State due to projected heavy rains, the Humanitarian Coordinator allocated  $11.5 million from the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SSHF) to support the implementation of early action activities before the rainy season.      The allocation will support the improvement of access to basic services for IDPs through the construction of Dykes, rehabilitation of roads and prepositioning of humanitarian supplies before the onset of the heavy rains season. This allocation will ensure complementarity with other logistics interventions by UNMISS and the local government in Unity State.
Documents: Reserve Allocation 2 _ Early Action.pdf##258959##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2023_470_794.pdf##

AllocationSummary: In 2023, Unity state is at risk of another catastrophic flooding. Over the past few years flooding has been fluctuating throughout the area, with peaks seen during the wet season and flood waters receding up until April and May each year. This lack of receding flood waters provided a high baseline level of flood waters that additional flooding in 2023 rainy season built upon.     As we are approaching the rainy season, and until more sustainable and durable solutions would be provided by the development actors, it is crucial that the same type of intervention is secured to prepare for the severe flooding expected during the rainy season in the food-affected areas, particularly Unity and Upper Nile States.     Therefore, based on an extensive consultation with key stakeholders across the coordination forums and the Advisory Board of the SSHF, the Humanitarian Coordinator a.i decided to launch a Third Reserve Allocation with a total budget of US$ 11.9 million from the SSHF as an Early Action intervention in the areas that are projected to suffer a fifth consecutive year of extreme flooding.     The 3rd Reserve Allocation of $ 11.9 million aims at providing multi-sectoral lifesaving assistance to vulnerable people in Rubkona and Bentiu of Unity State and in Malakal of Upper Nile State. The allocation will focus on the following:      1.	Addressing the various Early Action frontline activities under Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), Food Security and Livelihood (FSL), Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Protection (General protection, Child Protection (CP) and Gender Based Violence (GBV)), Health, and Nutrition sectors ($ 9.35 million);     2.	Maximizing the utilization of cash modality, particularly the multi-purpose cash (MPC), when feasible ($ 1.4 million); and    3. 	Contribution to the health/protection clusters’ core pipeline (US$ 1.15 million).
Documents: SSHF_EA_ Strategy _RA_Final.pdf##310079##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2023_475_801.pdf##

AllocationSummary: South Sudan continues to face overlapping crises, including floods, conflict, and food insecurity – all of which continue to negatively impact the resilience and vulnerability of people across the country. Approximately 6.6 million people, or over half of South Sudan’s population (54%), risk experiencing high levels of acute food insecurity, classified in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse between October and November 2022. Of those, 2.2 million people are experiencing worse conditions in Emergency (IPC Phase 4) acute food insecurity, and an estimated 61,000 people in Catastrophe (IPC Phase 5) acute food insecurity in Fangak, Canal/Pigi and Akobo of Jonglei State; Pibor County in the Greater Pibor Administrative Area. The most food insecure states between October and November 2022, where more than 50% of their populations are facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse acute food insecurity, are Jonglei (68%), Unity (66%), Northern Bahr el Ghazal (62%), Upper Nile (58%), Warrap (57%), and Lakes (57%).     According to the April Needs Analysis Working Group classification, the severity of the inter-sectoral need is the highest in the 5 IPC, 4 counties where the October 2022 IPC analysis projected some pockets of IPC5 during the 2023 lean season (Akobo, Fangak, Canal/Pigi, Leer and Mayendit), while in Kapoeta East, three years of severe drought have wiped out the crops on which the population's food security depends. The multifaceted effects of the crises contribute to persisting high levels of malnutrition that remain above the emergency threshold of 15 per cent (very high acute malnutrition level- WHO classification) at 16.0% (15.4 -16.7) in a lean season starting in 2019. High food insecurity, lack of hygiene, health, environmental sanitation services, and inadequate maternal and child carer are the main drivers of malnutrition in South Sudan. Staggering 31 counties in four states (Jonglei, Unity, Warrap, and Upper Nile) have Global Acute Malnutrition (GAM) prevalence above the emergency threshold of 15 per cent. Food insecurity is high in Canal/Pigi, Fangak, Akobo, Mayendit, Leer, and Kapoeta East, with all falling under IPC phase 4 for acute food insecurity, posing a risk of worsening the nutrition situation unless urgent actions are undertaken.      When food insecurity arises, women and children are the most at risk of malnutrition, hunger, and associated rights violations, as no crisis is gender and age neutral. The complex challenges contributing to the famine situation amplifies GBV risks for women and girls, particularly those already vulnerable to violence. Income insecurity, often combined with exponential increases in the cost of basic commodities, sparks and heightens violence, particularly intimate partner violence, sexual violence, exploitation, and abuse, leading families to adopt negative coping strategies such as child and forced marriage. The impact of hunger, reduced incomes, and the skyrocketing cost of living create immense stress on households, and devastatingly, women and girls bear the brunt.    Given the high levels of severe acute food insecurity in South Sudan, there is a need for immediate scale-up of multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance to save lives and prevent the total collapse of livelihoods in the affected counties, particularly those with a high share of populations in Emergency (IPC Phase 4) and Catastrophe (IPC Phase 5) acute food insecurity.
Documents: SSHF Reserve Allocation Strategy_Anti famine_final.pdf##1008994##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2023_479_808.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Since the escalation of conflict in Sudan on 15 April 2023, an estimated 127,710 people have been registered by UNHCR and IOM at several points of entry along the border with South Sudan as of 20 June 2023. Actual numbers may be higher, as some people could have entered the country without registration. The situation at the border entry points is worsening due to the lack of basic services and limited onward transport options.   This allocation of US$10 million will facilitate the onward movement of people to the final areas of destination for Sudanese refugees and South Sudanese returnees. The allocation will scale up access to basic services including food, healthcare, protection, shelter/NFIs, and WASH in the transit sites, and provide multi-sectoral assistance in areas of return.  This allocation will complement the $8 million allocated through the CERF Rapid Response window for scaling up response activities in the UNHCR and IOM-led South Sudan - Emergency Response for the Sudan Crisis
Documents: Reserve Allocation Round 5 _ Sudan crisis_Revised Final.pdf##243644##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2023_487_851.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The increase in returnees and refugees arriving in South Sudan from Sudan has exacerbated the already dire humanitarian situation, particularly at the border entry points, temporary transit sites, and areas of final destination. An estimated 255,211 people have been registered at several points along the border Sudan-South Sudan border.   Recognizing this, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund will release $5 million to support the onward transportation of returnees to help decongest the transit sites and ease pressure on existing facilities. Further, the allocation will support the provision of basic services in areas of final destination and avoid the deterioration of already existing vulnerabilities and limited basic service provision, especially in areas where the returnees have integrated with Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Upper Nile and Unity States. Specifically, the allocation will facilitate onward transportation assistance of returnees to decongest transit areas and ports of entry and enhance essential and lifesaving services in areas of final destination for returnees and Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). This allocation will complement recent funding from the CERF Rapid Response of $10 million for the Sudan Crisis.
Documents: Reserve Allocation Round 6_ Sudan crisis.pdf##221981##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2023_502_853.pdf##

AllocationSummary: As of 22 December, 453,800 individuals have been recorded at the entry points in South Sudan since the crisis in Sudan started in mid-April 2023. 85 per cent of arrivals were recorded at the Joda crossing point, close to the town of Renk in the Upper Nile State in South Sudan. With the deterioration of the situation in Sudan since 19 December, the average daily arrival via Joda is 1,526 individuals.   The Humanitarian Coordinator for South Sudan, with support from the SSHF Advisory Board, launched a Reserve Allocation of $6 million in response to the mounting humanitarian needs of refugees and returnees crossing into South Sudan from Sudan because of the conflict. The allocation supports the scale up of assistance and provision of equitable access to high-quality, gender-responsive, and inclusive life-saving services to the most vulnerable crises-affected people in Renk in line with strategic objective 1 of the 2024 HRNP.  This allocation will facilitate onward transportation assistance of returnees and refugees to decongest transit areas and ports of entry and enhance essential and lifesaving services in areas of final destination for returnees, refugees and Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Renk. This allocation complements ongoing projects funded under the CERF Rapid Response of $10 million for the Sudan Crisis and the SSHF reserve allocation 6 of US$ 5 million in September 2023.
Documents: Reserve Allocation Strategy round 1_ Sudan crisis_Final Version.pdf##284672##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2024_528_920.pdf##
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2024

AllocationSummary: In response to the escalating floods in South Sudan, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SSHF) has allocated an additional $5 million through its Reserve allocation mechanism to scale up urgent interventions in Health, Shelter/NFIs, and WASH services for 215,590 of the most vulnerable people in five of the worst-affected counties: Aweil East, Nasir, Rubkona, Mayendit, and Fangak.                           This Reserve allocation is critical to bolstering the South Sudan Flood Preparedness and Response Plan by enabling the immediate implementation of life-saving activities in these three key clusters. It complements the $10 million allocation from the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) in September, collectively bringing $15 million in pooled funds for the flood response. This additional funding will enhance response capacity, extending essential service packages in the targeted counties and improving conditions for 670,000 people facing severe risks of disease outbreaks, displacement, and deteriorating access to clean water, sanitation, and hygiene facilities.
Documents: SSHF Reserve Allocation Strategy- Floods Response - Final.pdf##255776##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2024_1341_1082.pdf##
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2024

AllocationSummary: On 28 September 2024, WHO reported the first suspected cholera cases in Renk, and a month later, the Ministry of Health declared a cholera outbreak in Renk, rapidly spreading to nearby Counties. Consequently, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund launches an $8 million Reserve Allocation to support a multi-sectoral response, effectively addressing the interlinked factors contributing to cholera transmission in areas with high population movement between Sudan and South Sudan, including Renk, where the outbreak started. It supports coordinated response efforts, bringing together health, water, sanitation, and hygiene, risk communication and community engagement, and logistics assistance to address both immediate cholera risks and long-term vulnerabilities.     The allocation supports priorities in the multi-sectoral response plan including early and/or rapid case detection and treatment, prevention measures, crucial water sanitation and hygiene infrastructures, and improved access to safe drinking water, nutrition, and awareness campaigns. The plan focuses on implementing swift priority actions in areas experiencing active cholera outbreaks, organized around ten technical pillars. It aims to provide tailored support to key locations identified as having high population movement between Sudan and South Sudan, while also addressing the fragility of the local health systems. By concentrating resources and interventions where they are most needed, the plan seeks to effectively mitigate the outbreak's impact, enhance response capacity, and ensure that vulnerable populations receive the necessary care and support to prevent further spread of the disease. This effort will build on preparedness and lessons learned from previous outbreaks. The plan outlines control and prevention measures to contain the outbreak and limit further disease spread while mobilizing necessary resources to reduce morbidity and mortality.
Documents: SSHF Reserve Allocation Strategy- Cholera Response -$8 million.pdf##349938##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2024_1374_1174.pdf##
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2024

AllocationSummary: Following the expansion of the Sudan conflict to Sudanese states bordering South Sudan and with fears of increased number of people crossing into South Sudan, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SSHF) has allocated $3 million through the prepositioning of funding for 48-hour response in three priority entry points [in Aweil East and Aweil North, Rubkona].   The allocation will provide immediate life-saving assistance including essential health care services, disease detection and investigation, emergency shelter, non-food items, safe water access and latrine construction, and protection services - GBV response, dignity kits and reunification of separated children.  The allocation targets an estimated 27,000 people in the first three months of the emergency. In addition, the allocation will support host communities in the target locations to ensure smooth reintegration of returnees.    Through the prepositioning of funding for 48-hour mechanism, humanitarian partners will be able to provide quick response once people start crossing into South Sudan in large numbers. This will provide rapid response to critical saving needs as the humanitarian system mobilizes response.  In this context, the activation of the 48-hour response mechanism is critical for effective humanitarian action as it allows rapid deployment of resources to address the emergent needs of returnees and refugees at border crossing points.
Documents: SSHF Reserve Allocation Strategy Final Version31Dec24.pdf##259815##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2024_1387_1232.pdf##
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2024

AllocationSummary: In response to the escalating humanitarian crisis, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund has launched the First Standard Allocation of US$20 million. This allocation aims to contribute to delivering an integrated life-saving humanitarian assistance to approximately 294,248 individuals who are among the most vulnerable people in four counties including Aweil East (Bahr El Ghazal), Nasir (Upper Nile), Pibor (Jonglei), and Rubkona (Unity) which are facing the most acute levels of need.    The allocation will provide assistance and avert further deterioration of living conditions for the targeted populations. This is particularly critical in August onwards, just emerging from April -July lean season.  when the effects of lean season are expected to manifest in malnutrition and food insecurity indicators.   Contributing factors include economic downturns, the ongoing conflict's repercussions from Sudan, internal conflicts, and climatic shocks, as indicated by the most recent Integrated Food Security Phase Classification projections (IPC, November 2023).  Additionally, the allocation will support the reintegration of those returning to their homes and fortify community empowerment. As part of contributing towards increased empowerment of targeted communities, the allocation gives particular emphasis on adequate community participation in identifying their own priorities. It ensures that the activities chosen not only to respond to urgent life-saving needs but also to contribute to the improvement of their livelihood’s capabilities.

HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2025

AllocationSummary: The relentless crisis in Sudan continues to have a growing humanitarian impact on South Sudan. Over 100,000 new arrivals have crossed into South Sudan through Renk since January 2025.  The influx of displaced populations has resulted in deteriorating sanitation and overcrowding, fueling the spread of infectious diseases, including cholera. The already strained healthcare infrastructure now faces an increased demand for prevention, treatment, and disease surveillance.   Acknowledging the worsening situation in Renk, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund has allocated $3 million to enhance humanitarian support by focusing on inclusive life-saving services for the most vulnerable populations in prioritized locations in Renk in Joda, East, and West corridors. As the crisis worsens, humanitarian assistance remains crucial.
Documents: SSHF_RA2_Strategy_FV.pdf##367298##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2025_1430_1299.pdf##SSHF Reserve Allocation 2
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2025

AllocationSummary: The escalating complexity of the crisis continues to worsen the already severe humanitarian situation in South Sudan. Overall reduction in donor contributions, ongoing cholera outbreaks, conflict-induced displacement, and anticipated flooding during the upcoming rainy season are expected to further aggravate conditions in Rubkona and Malakal, particularly in the Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) camps, IDP sites, and Malakal Protection of Civilian (PoC) sites. Recognizing these challenges, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund, has allocated US$2,800,000 to provide water and sanitation management and health services to approximately 280,000 people, aiming to mitigate further risks. This essential funding will prevent interruptions in life-saving humanitarian services in Bentiu and Malakal IDP camps and PoC sites for the next six months. The settlements are already overcrowded, and displacement worsens the risks posed by the cholera outbreak, strains water supplies, and places significant stress on already overstretched health services.
Documents: SSHF_Reserve Allocation 3_Strategy_RA3_FV.pdf##975745##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2025_1449_1363.pdf##
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2025

AllocationSummary: The emerging food and nutrition crisis in South Sudan, compounded by flooding, conflict, and disease outbreaks, demands urgent and coordinated action. To reduce the risk of food insecurity and improve nutrition outcomes, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund is launching a US$12 million Reserve Allocation for the delivery of integrated life-saving assistance to affected people. The response will focus on improving food security, reducing acute malnutrition among vulnerable groups, restoring essential health services, and ensuring access to safe water and sanitation in the most affected counties Abyei (Abyei Administrative Area), Canal-Pigi, Duk, Fangak, Pibor (Jonglei) Baliet, Longochuk, Luakpiny/ Nasir, Ulang (Upper Nile) and Rubkona (Unity).
Documents: SSHF_Reserve Allocation 4_Strategy Final.pdf##533823##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SSD-AllocDocs_2025_1517_1529.pdf##
HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2025

AllocationSummary: The humanitarian crisis in Western Equatoria, South Sudan, has reached an alarming level, driven by escalating insecurity and localized violence that has displaced over 225,000 people in urgent need of assistance. To address urgent humanitarian priorities, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund is triggering a US$4 million Reserve Allocation to deliver integrated, life-saving assistance to 28,000 vulnerable people in the most affected counties Tambura, Mundri East, Mundri West, and Ibba. This strategic intervention will focus on essential health and nutrition services, emergency shelter and non-food items, protection support, and safe access to water and sanitation, ensuring a coordinated response that mitigates the impact of worsening conditions and restores dignity for displaced populations.

HRPPlans: South Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2##2025

AllocationSummary: Following the escalation of conflict, compounded by disease outbreak, floods, increased violence and food insecurity, the South Sudan Humanitarian Fund launches the First Standard Allocation of $20 million to strengthen humanitarian efforts in addressing needs in eight priority counties of five worst-hit states/regions with intersectoral severity of needs: Jonglei, Upper Nile, Unity, and Northern Bahr el Ghazal States, and Abyei Region. The allocation will provide lifesaving assistance and avert further deterioration of living conditions for the targeted populations. This is particularly critical due to the eruption of violence in Nasir in March 2025, aerial bombardment in several counties, including Nasir Fangak, and forecasted floods expected to result in malnutrition and food insecurity.

AllocationTitle: 2021 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (End of year allocations- Anticipatory approach _Drought)
AllocationSummary: There was substantially less rainfall recorded in Sudan in 2021, particularly affecting a belt south of Khartoum, in the states of North Darfur, North Kordofan, and Kassala. This has caused a reduction in flooded areas used for agriculture, and a lowering of groundwater table. This is expected to result in reduced agricultural outputs and reduced access to drinking water, which will affect the population directly and indirectly due to lack of fodder and drinking water for livestock. As a result, food insecurity is expected to increase and livelihoods are at risk. The allocation of $3.9 million is targeting interventions that will anticipate these impacts and have as objective to reduce the impact on the population. The interventions focus on livelihood activities, in particular keeping livestock alive, WASH interventions (access to water) and to a lesser extend nutrition activities to address the undernourishment that is already apparent.
Documents: End of year allocations _Sudan HF.pdf##237248##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2021_378_455.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2021 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (End of year allocations- Conflict and displacement)
AllocationSummary: The allocation of $6.1 million in total covers urgent critical needs resulting from intercommunal violence. The allocations to Jebel Moon, West Darfur ($1.3 million) and the Eastern Corridor, South Kordofan ($2 million) address mass displacement due to intercommunal violence in recent weeks and focuses on WASH, shelter and NFI, health and protection interventions. The allocations to Kindrig camp, West Darfur ($0.7 million) and Sortony, North Darfur ($1.72 million) will allow for secondary displaced people to return to their IDP camps. Kindrig camp was affected by heavy intercommunal violence in January 2021, while Sortony camp was the center of fighting between government forces and non-state armed actors. The allocation to Melloi in East Darfur ($0.4 million) provides support to a small group of IDP’s and their host communities that have hosted them for over a year, since they were displaced from the neighboring state of South Darfur after intercommunal violence. All these allocations will focus on providing IDPs access to lifesaving humanitarian services in WASH, health, shelter and protection.
Documents: End of year allocations _Sudan HF.pdf##237248##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2021_376_456.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2021 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (End of year allocations- Covid 19)
AllocationSummary: In November 2021, Sudan is witnessing a sharp increase in COVID 19 cases needing medical care represented by high occupancy of isolation centers beds. While Khartoum remains, as with previous waves, in the epicenter of the epidemic, other states, and in particular River Nile, White Nile, West Kordofan, Sennar, Gezira, and East Darfur are now seeing considerable increase in cases. The isolation centers are overflowing. Oxygen supplies and personal protection equipment (PPE) are running critically low, laboratory services are overwhelmed and there are few resources for case management as well as for surveillance. The SHF responds through ERRM allocations ($0.2 million) as well as through this RfE allocation of ($0.8 million and will cover operational costs of isolation centers, case management, Infection and prevention control (IPC), assure oxygen, medical and PPE supplies and training of medical staff).
Documents: End of year allocations _Sudan HF.pdf##237248##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2021_377_457.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2021 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (End of year allocations- Newly Accessible Areas)
AllocationSummary: At the end of 2021, some areas in Sudan became for the first time since long accessible or saw increased accessibility. SHF’s flexibility allows to utilize these opportunities immediately while it can build upon OCHA’s capacity to give proper guidance in access issues. In recent year, these areas witnessed armed conflict between government forces and armed non-state actors. Cut-off from the Sudan humanitarian architecture and from basic services provided by the government during the armed conflict, critical needs in education, health, WASH, protection and food security emerged but could not be properly addressed.  The allocation will cover areas in 4 states with an amount of $9.4 million will provide renewed access to these most urgent basic services to which the targeted population has been excluded for almost two decennia.

AllocationSummary: The MSNA proposed and led by IOM (under the CCS sector) would address urgent information gaps on humanitarian needs and vulnerabilities, providing a robust evidence-based analysis of needs and severity during the HNO and HRP processes in Sudan. Sectors covered would include education, protection, gender-based violence (GBV), mine action, health, WASH (water, sanitation, hygiene), shelter and non-food items, food, security and livelihoods, nutrition, and accountability to affected populations (AAP).     IOM’s capacity, position as the lead agency for displacement data in Sudan and experience in the 2020 MSNA, coupled with the SHF’s potential funding support (estimated at 1,000,000 USD), would ensure the timely implementation of this critical MSNA for 2021 – and its resulting benefit for humanitarian response planning and programming across all sectors going forward.
Documents: RfEP case for funding - common services MSNA.pdf##147499##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2021_331_358.pdf##Case for funding document

AllocationSummary: The standard allocation of 2022 prioritizes:  - life-saving core humanitarian interventions  - localities with the highest humanitarian needs  - 40% of the funding will be allocated to underfunded priorities - including GBV, child-protection, general protection and education in emergencies  - Accountability to Affected Populations (AAP) and Protection against Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA)  - localization  - anticipatory funding through the Emergency Rapid Response Mechanism (ERRM)

AllocationTitle: 2022 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (End of year allocation- Hard to Reach Areas in Sudan)
AllocationSummary: This allocation targets the hard-to-reach areas in Sudan, which have an acute lack of basic services, across all sectors, and which have seen very little humanitarian assistance over the last decade.   Since two years, when the areas became accessible again, SHF has allocated substantial amounts. It is continuing its engagement through this allocation, now that operations funded through last year’s allocation is running to its end. Furthermore, in the identified areas in Central and South Darfur, as well as in the south of the country, tensions between the parties in the protracted conflicts are on the increase. This allocation will allow timely services to address the most basic needs before access might be too constraint. Likewise, if the protracted conflicts escalate in the coming months, much needed funds and operational partners will be readily available.    Due to the limited numbers of partners that can operate in the area, the allocation uses  the reserve modality, with programming done through a consultative area-based approach with clusters and operational partners together. One third of the allocation covers protection services, health and nutrition receive each a quarter, and smaller amounts are allocated to nutrition, education, livelihood and shelter services. Around 25% of the funding will be implemented through national partners.

AllocationTitle: 2022 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Intercommunal violence in South Kordofan and Blue Nile)
AllocationSummary: In the fourth quarter of 2022, intercommunal violence erupted in several locations in Blue Nile, displacing 31,000 people and in Lagawa, South Kordofan, displacing 65,000 people. The $3 million allocation will alleviate the most urgent needs of the people displaced following these conflicts with a focus on WASH (50% of the allocation), health and nutrition (25%) and protection and education (25%). Over a quarter of the funding will be implemented by national NGOs.

AllocationTitle: 2022 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Prepositioning of Stock)
AllocationSummary: In anticipation of the annual floods season and associated disease outbreaks, and later the likelihood of intercommunal violence, the allocation funds the prepositioning of life-saving supplies for new or deteriorating emergencies. Last year’s SHF grants for the prepositioning of stock, managed by lead Agencies, are renewed once critical levels of depletion are reached. As such, SHF assures a continued availability of WASH, health and NFI items as well as dignity kits which are critical for an effective emergency response. In particular, the allocation supports other SHF emergency allocations, by providing SHF partners, implementing SHF emergency projects, access to the prepositioned stock.

To reach a 20% allocation to NNGO’s in 2022, SHF will have inject a $3 million allocation to NNGO’s to balance out past allocations as well as maintain 20% allocation for local partners in its upcoming reserve allocations.
Documents: Localization allocation - 2022.pdf##190359##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2022_438_652.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2022 - SHF response to intercommunal violence across Sudan
AllocationSummary: Over the first half of 2022, intercommunal violence erupted in several locations in West Darfur, causing displacement of people inside West Darfur and to North Darfur and an overall operational insecure environment. The situation calmed down in June-July allowing needs assessments to take place. Intercommunal violence erupted as well in Blue Nile state, causing displacement inside the state and to Sennar. This allocation of $4.5 million targets the displaced people of these conflicts and covers seven sectors, with the WASH sector being the largest (33%) and a quarter going towards protection and education in emergencies. Nine partners, of which three national NGO’s will provide first-line emergency response to address the urgent needs in Blue Nile and Sennar, as well as remaining gaps in essential services in West Darfur and North Darfur. With this allocation, among others, sanitation services will be provided in the overcrowded IDP camps in Geneina town, West Darfur, during the rainy season, temporary learning spaces and child-friendly spaces provided for IDP’s in North Darfur and  children under five will be treated for malnourishment in Sennar and Blue Nile.

This allocation responds to the urgent needs stemming from the deteriorating security and food security due to conflict and dry spell in West Darfur. Intercommunal violence has flared up considerably since November 2021, in Jebel Moon, Sirba and Kreneik localities. The failed 2021 rainy season has put considerable pressure on the agricultural and water resources, and compounds the economic crisis due to high inflation, all in a context of inter-communal tensions and a tense political situation in Sudan. The Arab nomads’ perceptions that their communities are discriminated and marginalized from humanitarian assistance is driving tensions among communities, requiring that humanitarian response is conflict sensitive by being inclusive of the vulnerable among IDPs, host residents and nomads.  The humanitarian response has to continue to respond to the over 100,000 IDP’s who still remain gathering sites in Geneina, displaced since the violent attacks on the Krindig and Abuzar camps and Al Jebel Area in January and April 2021.    This case for funding seeks to directly address the consequences of the failed rain seasons and harvest failure through nutrition, WASH, and livelihood activities in Foro Baranga, Kreneik, Sirba and Jebel Moon.      The allocation of $3.98 million (of which $1.3 million for dry-spell response) will provide a critical injection of resources to livelihoods, WASH, health, nutrition, S/NFI, child protection and GBV interventions in Kreneik, Kulbus, Jebel Moon, Sirba and Foro Baranga localities. The interventions will target sedentary communities and Arab nomads alike, to address some of the frustrations stemming from perceived exclusion from humanitarian support and compliment the limited ongoing response, as well as planned further allocations by CERF.
Documents: 2022 SHF_ Sub‐national Conflict.pdf##445065##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2022_399_550.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2022- SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Countrywide Nutrition Response)
AllocationSummary: Subsequent to the dry spell and crop failure in Sudan, acute malnutrition among under five-year-old children has severely increased and continues to increase. Stabilization centres report considerably higher admissions of severe acute malnutrition and require urgent humanitarian support to be able to continue and increase their critical services till the end of the lean season.   In Sudan, 115 localities in 14 states have been identified as the most affected by the dry spells and crop failure. In these localities, 79 stabilization centers (SCs) are functional with only 34 centers supported by humanitarian partners and remaining 45 are not supported. As such, all the 79 stabilization centers in 115 of the most affected localities will continue to provide minimum services till the end of the year.      In addition, funding gaps for vector control will lead to larger disease outbreaks after the lean season, affecting an already weakened population. The proposal will also enable WHO to effectively and timely respond to the ongoing circulation of dengue fever in Red Sea state and increased vector control in West Darfur and Kassala.
Documents: RfEP case for funding- WHO - Nutrition- Vector control - Final.doc##221184##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2022_419_557.doc##|||RfEP Abyei nutrition case for funding FINAL 16_12_2022.pdf##260512##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2022_419_711.pdf##Case for Funding_ GAH_ Abyei

AllocationSummary: The failing economy, prolonged dry spells and erratic rainfall in the 2021 rainy season have resulted in shortages and high cost of agricultural inputs and labor, reduced harvests and a decrease in cultivated area. Further, the crop production in the 2021 cropping season was impacted by economical inflation, diseases, and pest infestation. This significantly reduced crop and livestock production up to 50 percent in 14 states across Sudan. Also, the below-average rainy seasons have caused a shortage of water for domestic use and livestock, impacting livelihoods and access to drinking water. The prolonged dry spell and subsequent crop failure are expected to exacerbate humanitarian needs and increased the risk of conflict due to the early migration of pastoral communities. Urgent and multi-sector lifesaving services are needed to prevent further deterioration of the humanitarian situation.    At the end of 2021, SHF already allocated $3.6 million in the response to the impact of these dry spells on WASH and nutrition needs and on people’s livelihoods, in Kassala, North Kordofan and North Darfur states. In addition, a West Darfur allocation in 2022 includes a $1.3 million dry spell component. The 2022 dry spell allocation, includes responses to Red Sea, South Darfur, East Darfur, Central Darfur and Gedaref, for an amount of $6.2 million, bringing the SHF’s total response to $11.1 million in the 9 most affected states. The projects target WASH, nutrition and livelihood sectors, with activities ranging from provision of fodder, urgent veterinary services, distribution of drought resistant seeds, emergency water supply, rehabilitation of shallow wells and animal water points and distribution of supplementary food supplies and plumpy nuts. The interventions aims to avoid the loss of livelihoods, increase food security, decrease malnourishment and reduce the likelihood of conflict.
Documents: 2022 SHF _Drought Response.pdf##1025845##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2022_398_551.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2023 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Displacement and returnees’ response)
AllocationSummary: This Reserve Allocation designed to support people newly displaced in Sudan following natural disasters and inter-communal violence was launched only four weeks before fighting erupted between the Sudan Armed Forces and the Rapid Support Forces on 15 April 2023. While the crisis was quickly deteriorating, humanitarian partners across all of Sudan were facing increasing challenges to design and implement projects as foreseen under this allocation due to access and procurements impediments as well as restrictions of movement. With guidance for a prioritized response from the Humanitarian Coordinator and following consultations with the humanitarian partners on the ground, it was decided to pursue only two projects initially proposed under this allocation strategy (see list below) and subsequently launch a different allocation tailored to new and evolving needs in view of the crisis. Further information can be found in the linked allocation strategy.
Documents: 25102023 Allocation Strategy RfE displacement and returnes_final draft_revised for GMS.pdf##224749##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2023_465_872.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2023 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Flexible life-saving response to conflict-affected people in Sudan)
AllocationSummary: Following the outbreak of hostilities in mid-April between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Force (RSF), humanitarian needs have dramatically increased. The allocation of US $48 million takes maximum advantage of the Fund’s diverse partnerships and positioning to respond flexibly providing funding to grassroots entities through networks with established partners that have direct access to vulnerable communities in areas of active fighting, pre-positioning of funding through cluster consortia for rapid response activities in hotspot areas of Khartoum and Darfur once access is restored and addressing the urgent needs in stabilized locations and hot-spot areas with a high number of IDPs such as Wadi Halfa, Medani, Port Sudan. This allocation represents components 1 (micro-grants to voluntary-based grassroots entities), 3 (IDP projects in stabilized locations and hot-spot areas) and 4 (pipeline support) under this Reserve Allocation.
Documents: SHF RA strategy Sudan crisis - 48m revised.pdf##282469##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2023_478_878.pdf##

AllocationTitle: 2023 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Lifesaving Urgent Response to Sudan Crisis in hard-to-reach areas and Cholera Outbreak)
AllocationSummary: Following the outbreak of hostilities in mid-April 2023 between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Force (RSF), the situation continues to worsen. The Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SHF) has allocated its second reserve funding this year in response to this crisis, with a focus now on addressing the cholera outbreak and meeting the needs in hard-to-reach areas.  This allocation will enable health actors to sustain their cholera response, which was at risk of suspension due to insufficient funding, for the next three months. Furthermore, while the initial allocation in 2023 primarily addressed the needs in more accessible regions, this current allocation places significant emphasis on the hard-to-reach areas, which are still experiencing active conflict. Many SHF partners have now gained access to these challenging regions. The programming approach involves field-based consultations, facilitated by OCHA sub-offices, resulting in area-specific, multi-sectoral programs designed collaboratively by the humanitarian actors. Localization and protection remain top priorities.

AllocationTitle: 2023 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Prepositioning of Stock)
AllocationSummary: In 2022, over 418,000 people were internally displaced due to localised violence, floods and other emergencies. Additionally, Sudan continues to welcome refugees – mainly from South Sudan, Eritrea and Ethiopia. These elements are likely to remain in 2023. Inter-communal conflict has already been experienced in several locations in 2023 resulting in causalities, destruction of property and displacements.  The immediate and most urgent needs of displaced people are generally centered around shelter, items to cook and access to water and health services. The prepositioning of items, such as plastic sheets for shelter, mosquito nets, jerry cans and cooking sets are essential to quickly respond to the needs of the affected population.   This allocation will allow UNHCR to procure 11,500 NFI kits for rapid distribution to partners responding to these sudden onset emergencies, covering the needs of almost 60,000 people. Together with UNHCR’s other funding streams that maybe allocated to prepositioning of stock (additional 13,500 NFI kits based on 2022 figures) and other actors prepositioning NFI items, the allocation will cover the needs of a large part of the displaced people expected in 2023. The allocation is in time to procure and preposition the items before the flood season (July-September). The allocation complements SHF’s other rapid response mechanisms that can cover the distribution costs of these items, as well as provide complementary rapid humanitarian services. Overall, it contributes to strengthening the overall humanitarian rapid response approach in Sudan.

AllocationSummary: Some areas in the south of Sudan are hard to reach, as such that the usual annual multi-sector needs assessment conducted in the rest of Sudan, and funded by the Agencies, cannot be implemented. Instead, an adapted implementation approach is required which allows as well to adapt the assessment methodology to be more relevant for the context.  Therefore, in close coordination with the local communities in these areas, SHF supports a specific, smaller multi-sector needs assessment in an area with limited to no humanitarian presence, fit for purpose to better programme future humanitarian interventions. The results of the MSNA are used to programme SHF’s allocation by the end of the year in these hard-to-reach areas (last two years - $5M). As few actors are operational in the area, and due to time pressure because of the upcoming rainy season, SHF allocates these funds through its Reserve modality.

The programming approach involves field-based consultations, facilitated by OCHA sub-offices, resulting in area-specific, multi-sectoral programs designed collaboratively by the humanitarian actors. AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Early Action Food Response to Sudan Food Security Crisis in Darfur and Kordofan)
AllocationSummary: SHF is releasing $38 million in its first allocation of 2024. Of this $38 million, $31.5 million aims to provide an early response to mitigate the looking food crisis. The allocation is a multi-cluster, area-based food response closely coordinated with a CERF Rapid Response allocation of $15 million. This response will allow NGOs to cover logistics and distribution costs and related operational costs - for items procured by UN agencies through the CERF Rapid Response and the $20 million CERF Underfunded Emergency allocations. In addition, as part of the multi-cluster consortium, the allocation will be used to fund essential complementary interventions such as WASH, health and agricultural support.   The second component of the allocation will provide funding to community-based organizations working often-times in places that no other humanitarian actor can reach. This $6.5 million allocation builds on the success of the $3 million SHF grant allocated in 2023 to grassroot organizations that have been central in reaching isolated communities and is expected to be depleted by April 2024.

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Empowering Women and Girls: Addressing Nutritional Needs in Sudan's Crisis)
AllocationSummary: As Sudan heads inexorably towards a major famine situation, coming on the back of widespread conflict that has exacerbated the already present food insecurity, meeting the nutritional shortfalls of both IDP and non-IDP populations will be primordial. Bearing in mind that women and girls are likely to be disproportionately affected, especially those with specific health issues because they are pregnant, breastfeeding, or responsible for the primary care of many children, there will be a specific requirement to ensure that these women and girls are pre-identified, prioritized, and have their nutritional situation regularly monitored. Failing to do this will have far-reaching nefarious consequences for the women and girls’ personal development but also for the future development of the country on top of failing women and girls’ fundamental human rights.  UN Women intends to work alongside the primary UN Agencies involved in the frontline of the current food distribution plan under the CERF facility. It will select the intervention zones after consulting with relevant sister Agencies (ia. FAO, UNICEF, UNHCR, IOM) based on need and accessibility. It will work with local partners and provide priority needs assessments, training to key aid workers, and nutritional monitoring services.

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Lifesaving response to displacement and famine in Sudan)
AllocationSummary: Within the ongoing broader crisis in Sudan, specific humanitarian needs continue to emerge. In the past month, additional humanitarian needs arose in Sennar and El Fasher due to shifting conflict lines and further displacement is very likely in other areas. Also, deportees are arriving back to Sudan in increasing numbers and many IDPs are moving to areas contaminated by explosive ordnances. The food crisis is also expected to worsen beyond the lean season as agricultural activities will likely be curtailed due to the conflict. Therefore, a timely area-based allocation, which allows lifesaving services to start up once the rainy season ends in September 2024, is vital to reach the people in famine hot-spots, in active conflict areas, as well as to reach the recently displaced people and deportees.  SHF is launching an area-based allocation, programmed by actors on the ground. The Allocation prioritizes areas at risk of famine, which have faced or are likely to face further conflict and displacement, contaminated with explosive ordnances where IDPs move to and entry points for deportees. The response, programmed through decentralized consultation meetings and engagements with communities, will address the most urgent humanitarian needs specific to the localities most in need, targeting over 250,000 people who find themselves in life threatening situations.
Documents: IDP and famine allocation Sudan 7th Reserve allocation_FINAL..pdf##410428##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2024_1300_1116.pdf##
