AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Prepositioning of funds: SHF 48hrs response and Funds to Multual-Aid Groups)
AllocationSummary: Envelope 1: A rapid response mechanism is an essential tool for the SHF to effectively address urgent needs. The 48-hour response grants are enabling humanitarian partners to respond to sudden needs or new operational opportunities within days.These quick interventions will allow partners to respond immediately with the most needed services while preparing for longer, larger-scale interventions potentially funded by other SHF allocations.  Envelope 2: continues to support Mutual Aid Groups (MAGs), focusing on the work implemented by grassroots organizations such as the Emergency Response Rooms (ERRs) and building on the 2023 and 2024 SHF allocations in support of these types of actors. The allocation prioritizes a bottom-up approach that integrates feedback from grassroots volunteers while ensuring consistency across international partners working with community-led organizations. The allocation will continue to strengthen coordination mechanisms with structured collaboration maintained to ensure an adaptive and effective humanitarian response to changing needs and aid gaps.
Documents: Allocation strategy 9 EoY prepositioning.pdf##409799##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2024_1370_1220.pdf##
HRPPlans: Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Prepositioning of Stock)
AllocationSummary: The ongoing conflict in Sudan since April 2023 has created an unprecedented large-scale forced displacement of more than 10 million people, many of whom have been displaced multiple times. In June 2024, displacement figures increased substantially again as the conflict reached El Fasher in North Darfur and Sennar States. These displacements are taking place when the country is at the brink of famine with almost 800,000 people at-risk, annual floods are expected to be more severe than previous years and the socio-economic situation in the country has further deteriorated, making it increasingly difficult for people to purchase basic commodities and items needed for survival.  The distribution of non-food items such as kitchen utensils, mosquito nets and jerry cans are essential to quickly respond to the needs of newly and multiply displaced people. Such assistance is vital especially during a food crisis, when food and water contamination and an increase in water- or vector-borne diseases like malaria can become deadly for the a population whose health status has been severely weakened by over one year of conflict. With this allocation, UNHCR will distribute up to 12,000 NFI kits to newly or multiply displaced households to prevent further catastrophe in the displacement locations.

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Rapid funding to newly emerging humanitarian needs 4)
AllocationSummary: On 25 August 2024, the Arba’at Dam, located approximately 38 km northwest of Port Sudan in Al Ganab locality, Red Sea State, Sudan, sustained extensive damage because of heavy rains, resulting in a critical humanitarian situation in the affected areas. At least 20 villages, with a population of approximately 10,000 people, have been severely impacted by the flooding. Local authorities have confirmed 30 fatalities, though the actual number of casualties may be significantly higher. Amid this acute humanitarian crisis, the primary objective of this allocation is to ensure a swift and effective response in WASH,  and ESNFI sectors, aiming to maximise reach and impact.

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Rapid funding to newly emerging humanitarian needs 5)
AllocationSummary: The humanitarian situation in Al Jazirah State, particularly Al Managil, has deteriorated significantly due to ongoing conflict and instability. Recent reports from UNOCHA and IOM indicate severe disruptions in basic services, especially healthcare, with escalating vulnerabilities due to food insecurity, displacement, and a strained healthcare infrastructure. The health system is at risk of collapsing without immediate support. This makes it critical to allocate resources now through the CBPF Reserve Allocation to prevent a complete breakdown in healthcare services in Al Managil.  The presence of a cholera outbreak, along with increased risks of other outbreaks due to flooding, inadequate WASH services, and limited vaccination efforts, highlights the urgency to strengthen emergency preparedness and response. This allocation will not only help maintain essential healthcare services but also enhance the capacity to respond to emerging public health crises. Securing this funding will enable Relief International to stabilize the healthcare system in Al Managil, mitigate the impacts of the ongoing conflict, and address urgent health risks in the region.
Documents: Rapid Funding Response to new emergencies in areas - 8th all (1 to 5) _FINAL.pdf##536994##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2024_1347_1126.pdf##
HRPPlans: Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (SHF 48h response [Rapid funding to newly emerging humanitarian needs in the wider Sudan humanitarian crisis] )
AllocationSummary: The humanitarian situation in Sudan is dire, marked by widespread conflict, displacement, and food insecurity. Ongoing violence, particularly in Darfur and the Kordofan states, has now displaced over 10 million people, leaving many without access to basic necessities such as food, water, and shelter, including at least 1.8 million women and girls in need of reproductive health services. The economic crisis exacerbates the situation, leading to soaring inflation and scarce resources. Health services are overwhelmed, and malnutrition rates are alarmingly high, especially among children.  Within this broader crisis, specific humanitarian needs continue to emerge suddenly. For example, in the past month, additional humanitarian needs arose in Sennar and El Fasher due to shifting conflict lines. Access issues make forward planning of service provision challenging, leading to sudden funding needs.  In this context, a rapid response mechanism like the 48-hour response is an essential tool for the SHF to effectively address urgent needs. The 2023 pilot of the 48-hour response grants has been widely acclaimed by stakeholders for enabling humanitarian partners to respond to sudden needs or new operational opportunities within days. This new allocation will continue the now-depleted 2023 48-hour response, ensuring services quickly reach newly emerging hotspots in Sudan and promptly alleviate humanitarian needs. These quick interventions will allow partners to respond immediately with the most needed services while preparing for longer, larger-scale interventions potentially funded by other SHF allocations.
Documents: Allocation strategy 48h response 2024 final.pdf##326395##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2024_1295_1024.pdf##
HRPPlans: Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationTitle: 2024 - SHF Reserve for Emergencies (Sustaining Lifesaving Healthcare: Supporting the Salam Centre Amid Sudan's Crisis)
AllocationSummary: Amid the ongoing violence and conflict throughout the country, the Salam Centre is one of the few specialized health facilities that remained operational and free of charge and is the only one in Khartoum with a functioning diagnostic department, blood bank, and oxygen reserves. Power outages, dwindling availability of fuel, and soaring prices have presented significant operational challenges to the Centre. Without continued support, the Centre will have to scale back services, in turn depriving the communities of essential healthcare. Patients with acute medical needs will be affected the hardest. To this, the injection of $4 million from the Sudan Humanitarian Fund is timely and vital in maintaining this healthcare lifeline on the ground.  The primary objective of this allocation is to secure healthcare services in Khartoum, where all infrastructure has collapsed amid an acute humanitarian crisis.

HRPPlans: Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2024##2024

AllocationTitle: 2025 -  SHF Reserve Allocation (Mutual Aid Groups (MAGs) Allocation)
AllocationSummary: The humanitarian crisis in Sudan continues to deteriorate, fueled by widespread conflict, mass displacement, and escalating food insecurity. Nearly 13 million people — over a quarter of the population — are now displaced, many without reliable access to food, clean water, shelter, or healthcare. Malnutrition rates are rising, and essential protection and health services remain critically under-resourced.    The situation is especially volatile in Darfur and the Kordofan states, where access constraints and active hostilities make traditional humanitarian delivery difficult. In North Darfur alone, over 100,000 people were recently displaced from El Fasher  following the RSF’s capture of the city, underscoring the speed and scale at which new emergencies are unfolding.    In this context, SHF is urgently allocating $12 million to reinforce grassroots-led action under the MAG mechanism. These funds will enable immediate partner-led response to sudden-onset emergencies and maintain the operational continuity of trusted community-based actors. This mechanism has proven critical in accessing hard-to-reach populations, especially where international agencies face movement restrictions or security risks.

AllocationTitle: 2025 - SHF Reserve Allocation (Anticipatory cholera response in high-risk states ahead of the 2025 rainy season)
AllocationSummary: Sudan has experienced consecutive cholera outbreaks in 2023 and 2024, pointing to an emerging pattern of endemic transmission. The current wave, declared in August 2024, has already resulted in over 57,000 suspected cases and 1,534 deaths by March 2025. Critically, the outbreak has persisted through the dry season — with White Nile, Gedaref, Aj Jazirah, and Kassala among the hardest hit — indicating elevated baseline risk and the strong likelihood of further spread with the onset of rains.  This $5 million Reserve Allocation enables anticipatory, high-impact intervention in four of the most affected states over the past two years. Informed by the 2025 Cholera Response Plan, the allocation prioritizes urgent supplies for diagnostics and case management, strengthens surveillance and coordination, boosts infection control in health facilities and communities, and supports life-saving WASH and risk communication activities. Targeted localities were selected based on recent outbreak trends and the presence of operational partners.  The strategic value of this allocation lies in its speed, precision, and forward-looking posture. By acting ahead of the rainy season, it enables partners to contain transmission risks before they escalate. Rather than waiting for a full-scale outbreak to unfold, this anticipatory approach channels resources now — when they can still prevent avoidable illness and deaths.
Documents: Cholera allocation 2nd RA 2025.pdf##402753##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2025_1434_1319.pdf##
HRPPlans: Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2025##2025

AllocationTitle: 2025 - SHF Reserve Allocation (Emergency Shelter Response to displacements from ZamZam camp)
AllocationSummary: On 11 April, RSF forces attacked Zamzam camp, killing over 400 civilians—including 12 medical workers from Relief International—and forcibly taking control of the site. According to IOM, about 80,000 households were displaced, many fleeing toward El Fasher and Tawila. With El Fasher largely inaccessible, the IDP influx into Tawila is growing rapidly as well as in Jebel Marra. New arrivals are sheltering in open spaces without basic household items or protection from the elements.  While health, water, and sanitation services are under strain, they are partially supported by the latest SHF 48-hour allocation and ongoing projects. However, emergency shelter and NFI support remains a critical gap. Local markets are unable to meet demand, and planned MPCA distributions will only partially help. SHF partners report urgent needs for direct in-kind assistance.  This Reserve Allocation will provide emergency shelter and NFIs for 13,000 households ahead of the rainy season. It builds on active frontline engagement by ERRs and NGOs and fills a life-threatening gap in the response. The timing is critical: no other funding is currently available to meet these immediate needs, and standard allocation timelines would arrive too late. The allocation reinforces SHF’s role in enabling fast, field-anchored, and lifesaving response.    Solidarites International (SI), the International Rescue Committee (IRC) and the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) have been identified as the most pertinent partners to deliver this response.
Documents: ESNFI ND allocation- 4th RA - final.pdf##335423##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/SUD-AllocDocs_2025_1435_1295.pdf##
HRPPlans: Sudan Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan 2025##2025

AllocationTitle: 2025 - SHF Reserve Allocation (Enabling Safe Civilian Return and Humanitarian Access Through Emergency Mine Action in Conflict-Affected areas - Sudan)
AllocationSummary: This SHF Reserve Allocation of USD 4 million responds to a critical window of opportunity created by recent shifts in territorial control. Following the Sudanese Armed Forces’ recapture of key areas, including Khartoum in March 2025, spontaneous and organized returns are accelerating into urban zones heavily contaminated by explosive ordnance (EO). These hazards now block safe civilian return, endanger aid workers, and obstruct access to infrastructure such as roads, hospitals, and schools. Without urgent action, growing population movements will outpace the operational capacity to manage these life-threatening risks.  This allocation builds on two earlier CERF-funded phases: one that pre-positioned mine action equipment (Nov 2024), and one that launched initial survey and clearance operations (Mar 2025). The SHF now enables a full-scale deployment: eight multi-task and two clearance teams will clear EO from priority infrastructure; four mobile “EORE Plus” teams will deliver risk education and map hazardous areas; victim assistance activities will identify and support EO survivors; and targeted training—including for female deminers—will strengthen national surge capacity.  This allocation is timely, needs-driven, and catalytic. It translates readiness into action and delivers protection at scale, enabling safe return, humanitarian access, and early recovery in some of Sudan’s most dangerous and operationally consequential environments.

AllocationTitle: 2025 - SHF Reserve Allocation (Prepositioning of funds for local and rapid response)
AllocationSummary: The humanitarian crisis in Sudan continues to deteriorate, fueled by widespread conflict, mass displacement, and escalating food insecurity. Nearly 13 million people — over a quarter of the population — are now displaced, many without reliable access to food, clean water, shelter, or healthcare. Malnutrition rates are rising, and essential protection and health services remain critically under-resourced.  The situation is especially volatile in Darfur and the Kordofan states, where access constraints and active hostilities make traditional humanitarian delivery difficult. In North Darfur alone, over 400,000 people were recently displaced from Zamzam camp, underscoring the speed and scale at which new emergencies are unfolding.  To respond to such shocks, the SHF has relied on its 48-hour response window and the Mutual Aid Group (MAG) mechanism. However, the 48-hour window has now been fully depleted following the recent $2.5 million allocation to the El Fasher emergency. Meanwhile, the $7 million MAG envelope is nearing exhaustion after a series of microgrants to community-based groups across multiple states.  In this context, SHF is urgently allocating $12 million to replenish the 48-hour response window and $13 million to reinforce grassroots-led action under the MAG mechanism. These funds will enable immediate partner-led response to sudden-onset emergencies and maintain the operational continuity of trusted community-based actors. Both mechanisms have proven critical in accessing hard-to-reach populations, especially where international agencies face movement restrictions or security risks.

AllocationTitle: 2025 - SHF Reserve Allocation (Sustaining Conflict Response and Stabilising Cholera Interventions in the South of Sudan)
AllocationSummary: Communities in Sudan’s southern border areas are facing a rapidly escalating humanitarian crisis. The compounding effects of conflict, mass displacement, a growing cholera outbreak, and a sharp decline in funding have pushed an already fragile situation to the brink. Since April 2023, an estimated 1.88 million internally displaced persons have arrived in areas that originally hosted 2.15 million people—placing extraordinary strain on overstretched health, WASH, and protection systems.  This $7 million Reserve Allocation from the Sudan Humanitarian Fund comes at a critical time. The lean season is intensifying food insecurity and disease risks, while humanitarian access remains constrained. A recent cholera outbreak has exposed major gaps in health and WASH infrastructure, with local capacity further weakened by the withdrawal of major funding sources since January 2025.  This allocation prioritizes life-saving support through multi-purpose cash assistance (MPCA), health, WASH, and protection interventions, reaching vulnerable populations in hard-to-access, underserved areas. It supports integrated, community-driven approaches that allow for swift scale-up of existing activities and reinforce local response capacity. Through timely and targeted disbursement, the SHF strengthens its role in safeguarding humanitarian space, sustaining minimum service delivery, and preventing further deterioration in an increasingly fragile operating environment.

AllocationTitle: 2025 - SHF Standard Allocation (Allocation to the most underfunded localities)
AllocationSummary: The Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SHF) is launching this US$ 33 million allocation at a critical juncture marked by escalating conflict, mass displacement, recurrent disease outbreaks, and large-scale spontaneous returns. Since April 2023, Sudan has become one of the world’s largest displacement crises, with more than 13 million people uprooted. Recent spikes in displacement from El Fasher and the increased intensity of conflict in the Darfurs and Kordofans underscore the urgency of action.    From the 17 priority localities endorsed by the HCT, identified by the ICCG as having the highest convergence of displacement, food insecurity, protection risks, and operational feasibility, the SHF selected 9 localities for this allocation. This refinement was based on a comparative review of existing funding streams, including the most recent SHF area-based allocation and the ongoing $20 million CERF Rapid Response allocation. Localities that had already received substantial support through either mechanism were deprioritized, while those with acute needs but limited coverage were elevated for inclusion. As a result, the selected 9 localities represent the areas where gaps were most pronounced. The final selection ensures that SHF funding fills the most critical shortfalls, strengthens operational continuity, and maximizes the combined impact of SHF and CERF interventions across the Darfurs, Kordofans, Khartoum, and Al Gezirah.

AllocationTitle: 2025-Lifesaving NFI, WASH, and Logistics Support in Response to Displacement in and from conflict-affected zones in Sudan
AllocationSummary: The recent escalation of conflict in Al Fasher has triggered large-scale displacement, creating an urgent need for immediate humanitarian support. Almost 100,000 people fled between 26 October and 13 November with little or no belongings, leaving them exposed to harsh conditions without adequate shelter or basic relief items. This sudden surge in needs cannot wait for the longer timelines of a standard allocation, making the Reserve Allocation modality essential to ensure a rapid response.    The USD 2,000,000 allocation to IOM will enable swift transport of existing stocks and in-kind support from other funding sources through cross-line and cross-border deliveries to Common Pipeline partners in the Darfur and Kordofan regions, as well as any other emerging conflict-affected displacement locations, ensuring items reach those in need in the shortest possible time, while also allowing IOM to replenish depleted stocks to respond to this and other crises across Sudan. Acting now ensures that relief reaches displaced populations before conditions deteriorate further, saving lives and preventing secondary crises associated with inadequate shelter and WASH provisions, such as disease outbreaks and protection risks.

AllocationSummary: In order to prioritize and guide the response to the new situation, OCHA is working with all relevant partners to finalize a concise ‘Emergency Response Plan’ that analyzes the critical needs and gaps in the response and identifies priority activities, within the existing Humanitarian Response Plan, for meeting these needs in the short term.   The present allocation is aimed at supporting the ongoing response from within Syria, as an integral part of that plan, in close coordination with actors using all modalities of assistance. The allocation aims to support those humanitarian partners within Syria with the capacity and access to make the greatest difference for the most vulnerable people, as quickly as possible.     The allocation is guided by the strategic direction set by the Humanitarian Country Team, which has identified the following key priorities, inter alia, to guide the humanitarian response:    1.	Assisting the newly displaced, particularly those in collective shelters and residing with host community members;  2.	Maintaining support in existing IDP camps, sites and settlements, as well as in host communities (1.8 million people in need in the NES, including 1 3 million people in SDF-held areas)  3.	Maintaining crossline missions. These have so far included the 14 families 84 individuals evacuated from Mabruka camp on 24 October, and the ongoing work to repair and maintain the Alouk water station. Planning is underway for an inter-agency assessment and convoy to Ein Issa and to assess the significant number of returns taking place in Operation Peace Spring areas, particularly Tal Abiad and Suluk sub districts in Ar Raqqa.  4.	Ensuring minimum continuity of services to populations living in areas shifting control and/or who are currently being assisted through cross-border modalities, including in situations where that assistance may be disrupted by changing security and administrative dynamics.     In accordance with the above priorities, the allocation is designed to support projects implemented via two distinct modalities: regular programming and cross-line interagency missions in NES.     Regular programming activities will be focused on the delivery of critical services including Health, WASH, Shelter, Food and Agriculture and Protection, in affected areas that accessible by partners working from within Syria in NES. The geographic focus of regular programming activities will depend on the evolution of needs in the coming weeks and the continuity of service provision in collective shelters.  Should current patterns of return and service provision continue, it is likely the greatest added value will be in focusing the allocation on supporting response in camps and affected communities, rather than in collective shelters.     Inter-agency missions will complement this regular program support, and will provide critical assistance to areas that are more difficult to access via regular programs. They will be focused in an initial phase on Tabqa and Ein Issa in Ar Raqqa governorate, and subsequently will aim to expand to Menbij and Ein Al-Arab in Aleppo governorate. On 29 October 2019, the United Nations received approval from the Government of Syria to conduct cross-line interagency missions areas in Ar Raqqa and Aleppo. The UN will continue to engage at high levels to advocate for an expansion of inter-agency missions wherever feasible. The inter-agency missions will include both needs assessment to inform planning as well as provision of assistance and protection services.

AllocationSummary: The Syria Humanitarian Fund (SHF) plans to allocate US$40 million through a Standard Allocation. This Standard Allocation intends to (1) address humanitarian needs in underserved areas, as based on the severity of needs and the current humanitarian response. In addition, the allocation will (2) support mitigation of the socio-economic impacts stemming from economic and financial crisis in addition to restrictive measures to prevent COVID-19. Finally, it will (3) prepare for an enhanced response for medium-term COVID-19 interventions based on the HRP and the Syria Preparedness and Response Plan for COVID-191.  The Inter Sector Coordination (ISC) group in Syria undertook a detailed prioritization exercise, involving a multi-factor analysis of levels of need with an emphasis on highest severity need; population movement with a focus on locations of a high concentration of IDPs and / or returnees; presence and functionality of basic services including but not limited to water, electrical, sewage, health and education facilities; and current coverage of people reached with sustained programming, based on a response analysis.  The geographic scope of underserved locations is primarily focused on, but not limited to, rural Aleppo, northern rural Hama, eastern rural Homs, northern rural Lattakia, among other locations identified in Rural Damascus, Deir-ez-Zor, Ar-Raqqa, Dar’a and As-Sweida.

AllocationSummary: The allocation serves to foster preparedness to the COVID 19 COVID-19 pandemic to reinforce the Syria public health system and improve health awareness and preventative mechanisms.    The preparedness and response planning for COVID 19 will be focused on reinforcing comprehensive, multi-sectoral preparedness and mitigation measures to prevent further transmission. At the same time, the allocation will also focus on protecting, assisting and advocating for the most vulnerable, including IDPs, refugees and Palestine refugees and host communities particularly vulnerable to the pandemic. Due to the many unknown factors about this new virus, it has been challenging to provide accurate predictions of the case in Syria. Based on the epidemiological pattern and modelling of COVID-19 in other countries, the current action is for immediate critical activities to be implemented in the next three to a maximum of six months.     The allocation shall be provided to partners, with full flexibility in geographic coverage while maintaining emphasis on a needs-based coordinated response. Guided by the global preparedness and response to COVID-19 as well as the operational plan being developed by the inter-sector coordination, five main priorities are identified:  1)	Enhancement of surveillance capacity with a critical need to expand laboratory capacity to test for timely detection; and support case management and contact tracing  2)	Ensure infection prevention and control in healthcare facilities to protect health care workers from infection by COVID-19 and amplification of events in the healthcare facilities and communities  3)	Risk mitigation and community engagement through awareness raising and risk communication  4)	Address immediate gaps in logistics and transportation for humanitarian programming due to access restrictions    5)	Protection of the most vulnerable population such, the elderly, women-headed household and people with disabilities, refugees.     As per the COVID-19 Operational Response Plan, the response to the COVID-19 outbreak must be multi-sectoral in nature to be effective. The following sectors will be covered: Health, WASH, Protection and Logistics. The health sector will take on procurement of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) on behalf of the Health sector for humanitarian community.

AllocationSummary: The First Standard Allocation aims to support the 2021 Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP), in particular, with provision of lifesaving and sustainable assistance in underserved areas, including the newly assessed ones based on needs and specifically towards the most vulnerable population. A total of US$35 million is available under this allocation.  Seven programmatic priorities have been identified to guide this allocation:     1.	Multisector humanitarian response to newly assessed areas  2.	Alleviation of the impact of the current economic crisis  3.	Strengthening resilience of communities through food security, agriculture, and livelihoods interventions  4.	Support to IDP in camps and informal settlements  5.	Provision of essential services including water and sewage networks, education and health   6.	Alleviation of the impact of poor rainfall and reported drought conditions through strengthening resilience of drinking water supply systems  7.	Continuous support to the COVID-19 pandemic response while mitigating further impact.

AllocationSummary: The main objective of this Reserve Allocation (RA) is to support immediate scale up of efforts in response to the impact of the water crisis as well as bolster provision of winter appropriate assistance. A total of 20 million USD is available under this allocation to meet the most critical needs of affected population. Two specific programme responses are being prioritized:   (1)	Provision of immediate multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance to address consequences of water crisis in Syria. This is in line with the Water Crisis in Northern and Northeast (NES) Syria Immediate Response plan where sectors, namely: Early Recovery and Livelihoods (ER&L), Food Security and Agriculture (FSA), Health, Nutrition, Protection, WASH and Education will continue to implement and scale up a number of critical response activities over the course of the next six months (September 2021 – February 2022).  (2)	Provision of winter appropriate assistance in areas of highest needs to protect the most vulnerable people from harsh winter conditions. This is in line with the NFI sector Winterization Response Strategy September 2021- March 2022.

AllocationSummary: The Reserve Allocation aims to ensure continuation of the United Nations Humanitarian Air Services (UNHAS)   in Syria. The amount of up to US $1 million has been made available to ensure the continuity of humanitarian   air services, including for medical evacuations, enabling timely, coordinated and efficient delivery of aid to   most affected communities.  BACKGROUND  • UNHAS started operating in 2020 in Syria to ensure safe, reliable and sustainable air access to beneficiaries   for the humanitarian community mainly in those parts of Syria that are not easily accessible by road. UNHAS   Syria monthly operational expenditure is US $450,000. In 2021, donor contributions to its operations in  Syria amounted to US $5.5 million from eight donors. UNHAS facilitated efficient and timely delivery of   assistance to North-East Syria and Aleppo. Additionally, UNHAS is exploring ways to operate to Deir-ez-Zor.   A monthly average of 350 humanitarian workers uses UNHAS services - from primarily Red Cross,   international and national NGOs and UN agencies. UNHAS ships humanitarian cargo as well with monthly   average of 3.16 million tons (MT). Moreover, UNHAS provides the required capacity for medical and   emergency evacuation.   • UNHAS is a critical enabler for the Sustainable Development Goals as it facilitates humanitarian access and   provides an effective humanitarian response during times of emergency. Since January 2021, UNHAS has   carried some 2,609 passengers supporting the response and access for the humanitarian community   operating inside Syria. UNHAS is currently available to 36 organizations whose work spans across the Food   Security, Nutrition, Health, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) sectors with passenger and light cargo   transport. UNHAS also provided critical medical and security evacuation services for humanitarian staff.   • The humanitarian cost of the disruption of UNHAS services, even if only temporary, is 3.5 million people in   need in Al-Hasakeh and Aleppo being put at risk of not receiving essential humanitarian assistance.   Moreover, the opportunity for air operations in Deir-ez-Zor may be lost. UNHAS conducted the technical   assessment for Deir-ez-Zor in October 2021 and the request to obtain approval to operate to Deir-ez-Zor   was submitted to authorities on 16 November 2021. Finally, the logistical impediments if UNHAS stops its   air transportation services are significant. If the service exits the country due to a lack of funding, it will take   World Food Programme (WFP) about seven months to continue operations if allowed by local authorities   to do so. WFP anticipates bilateral funding to be received by mid-March 2022 and has identified a critical   gap period between mid-January to mid-March 2022.   CBPF Syria Allocation Strategy Paper | 2  About Country-based Pooled Funds (CBPFs):  CBPFs allow donors to pool their contributions into single, unearmarked funds to support local humanitarian efforts. This enables humanitarian   partners in crisis-affected countries to deliver timely, coordinated and principled assistance.  http://www.unocha.org/our-work/humanitarian-financing/country-based-pooled-funds-cbpfs  • To manage the above-mentioned risks, the SHF allocates US $1 million to ensure the continuity of   humanitarian air services, including for medical evacuations, enabling timely, coordinated and efficient   delivery of aid to most affected communities and essential access for the humanitarian community to   affected areas across the country.

AllocationTitle: 4th Reserve Allocation for Support to Medical Supplies - WHO
AllocationSummary: The Reserve Allocation aims to address acute emergency needs in health facilities through procurement of   life-saving medicines and vital medical supplies including ventilators, equipping COVID-19 case   management centers and strengthening diagnostic capacity of national laboratories. An amount of US $3   million has been made available for this allocation to ensure immediate needs are met in complementarity  with other funding sources that WHO is exploring.  BACKGROUND  • Acute shortages of life-saving medicines across all public health facilities in Syria, especially related   to hospitalized patients’ case management, are observed1  . This is due to the ongoing COVID-19   pandemic, and its recent (highest and longest) 4th wave that continues devastating health sector   capacity to respond. Currently, the national stock for medicines in public warehouses stands low at   alarming level - only 20 per cent of the needs for 2022 are available2  , including six per cent of certain   types of anticoagulants (blood thinners) and anaesthetic medicines where other specific antibiotics   and IV fluids are available.   • Due to the extreme limited vaccine coverage (as of 7 December 2021, only around five per cent of   the population vaccinated in government-controlled areas and North-East Syria (NES) due to delays   in vaccines supplies), some 95 per cent of the population are at risk of infection, of which at least 20   per cent are likely to be at risk of hospitalization in the upcoming COVID-19 surges3  . This is one of   the factors that are going to keep the needs for medicines high alongside with economic factors and   overall market deficits for certain types of COVID-19 related medicines.

AllocationTitle: Saving lives through averting further deterioration of the nutritional situation and strengthening resilience of the most critically affected people
AllocationSummary: The prioritization for this allocation builds on the priority needs expressed in the recent Multi-sector Needs Assessment, and the 2022-2023 Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). The prioritization for this allocation was also informed by the outcomes of extensive consultations with the humanitarian community and analysis of other funding flows to Syria. To bridge some of the identified critical gaps in response, this allocation prioritizes a multi-sectoral response to the deteriorating nutrition situation, and strengthening the resilience of vulnerable people in areas with high severity needs and poor response reach.    Within its first priority, the allocation will support the strengthening of a comprehensive multi-sector nutrition response through joint nutrition, food security, health, WASH, and Protection interventions.  Considering the high number of malnourished children under five years of age and pregnant and lactating women (5.5 million), and the continuing drastic deterioration of the nutrition situation in Syria; this allocation will focus on supporting the provision of specialized treatment and management of malnutrition cases and averting the anticipated further deterioration of the situation in areas with the highest severity needs and poor nutrition response reach. The allocation will have additional strategic added value by boosting the currently limited nutrition response capacity and strengthening multi-sector programming to enable the humanitarian system to address the needs and risks holistically.       Within its second priority, the allocation will contribute to strengthening the resilience of the most critically affected people in the areas with high needs and poor inter-sector response and reach. It will prioritize projects focusing on improving the protection environment, tailored food assistance to the vulnerable families, livelihood opportunities, and sustained access to critical basic services. This approach is in line with the 2022-2023 HRP priorities and will enable the humanitarian community to address some of the critical humanitarian needs more effectively, efficiently, and sustainably. Eleven years into the Syrian conflict, investing in resilience programming is critical to prevent a larger and more protracted crisis, and to ensure sustainability of humanitarian operations. The allocation will have a long-term added value countering the increasing needs with assistance that empowers people to meet their basic needs autonomously.      Within both priorities, the allocation will put specific emphasis on the SHF’s areas of effective programming, namely Accountability to Affected Populations, promoting the centrality of protection, preventing Gender-based Violence, and preventing Sexual Exploitation and Abuse as well as an area-based approach which responds to the whole population living in need in a specific geographic area by improving their overall living conditions.

AllocationSummary: The United Nations Humanitarian Air Services’ (UNHAS) plays a critical role in enabling humanitarian access in Syria. Since 2020, it serviced 520 flights, over 12,000 humanitarian workers/passengers, 82 metric tons of humanitarian cargo, and 29 medical evacuations. In July, UNHAS is facing a critical funding shortage, where if not secured, it will discontinue its operations in Syria past July 2023. UNHAS is the only authorized airline for humanitarian agencies in Syria and a disruption of operations will have an immediate, negative impact on the response.  This Reserve Allocation of $1.5 million is launched to ensure the continuity of humanitarian air services by providing safe, timely and free of charge flight services to 53 registered users, including INGO, NNGO and UN Agencies, and transporting relief items. This allocation will support UNHAS operations for five months as a last resort while WFP continues funding mobilization efforts to secure longer term funding.

AllocationTitle: SA1-2023_Mitigate the impact of winter conditions on underserved areas encompassing a multisectoral approach to early recovery/resilience in areas of high need
AllocationSummary: The allocation focuses on the following sub-objectives: 1. Provision of rapid life-saving assistance in support of mitigating the impact of winter conditions in underserved areas (indicative amount $10 million); 2. Enhancing the resilience of communities to winter conditions and households in underserved areas through livelihoods opportunities, housing/adequate shelter, and service delivery (indicative amount $20 million).   Within its first sub-objective, the allocation will support strengthening of an immediate and rapid winterization response through comprehensive multi-sector interventions. The allocation will have additional strategic added value by boosting the currently limited winterization response capacity and strengthening multi-sector programming to enable the humanitarian system to address the needs and risks holistically.  Within its second sub-objective the allocation will contribute to strengthening the resilience to winter conditions of the most vulnerable communities and households in the areas of highest needs and low level of sector response and reach. It will focus on boosting the early recovery response by enhancing livelihoods opportunities and reinforcing sustained access to critical basic services.  This allocation will have a long-term added value countering the increasing needs with assistance that empowers people to meet their basic needs autonomously. Within both priorities, the allocation will put specific emphasis on the SHF’s areas of effective programming, namely Accountability to Affected Populations, promoting centrality of protection, preventing Gender-based Violence and Sexual Exploitation and Abuse.

AllocationSummary: As of 25 October 2024, some 440,000 people (Lebanese, Syrians and third-country nationals) are estimated to have crossed from Lebanon to Syria since the escalation of hostilities in Lebanon . The influx occurs against the backdrop of a prolonged humanitarian crisis in Syria, ongoing since 2011. Compounded by a significantly underfunded  humanitarian response plan, the increased need for assistance has put additional pressure on already stretched humanitarian budgets across the humanitarian system .     Given the existing challenging humanitarian situation in Syria, and the additional pressure added by the influx from Lebanon, the Syria Humanitarian Fund (SHF) will release a $12 million Reserve Allocation to support vulnerable communities with co-occurrence of multiple acute humanitarian needs. This allocation will focus on those with a high severity of needs, underserved, and hosting those displaced from Lebanon (Lebanese and Syrian returnees under adverse circumstances), and will provide lifesaving assistance through multi-purpose cash, NFI and protection services, and provision of essential health, WASH and education basic services.     In line with the Humanitarian Coordinator’s (HC) vision, this allocation will promote cash and voucher assistance (CVA), aiming to channel $ 3.5 million, through multi-purpose cash.

AllocationSummary: The allocation released by the Syria Cross-border Humanitarian Fund (SCHF) and Syria Humanitarian Fund (SHF) represents a strategic, unified response to the acute and evolving humanitarian needs across Syria. In the aftermath of the government dissolution in 2024 and amid persistent conflict, seventy percent Syrians require urgent assistance, with displacement, returns, and continued instability reshaping the humanitarian landscape. While the current Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) targets eight million people and is only than 11 percent funded, this allocation ensures resources are directed where they are most impactful.  The strategy targets displaced populations, vulnerable host communities, and returnees in areas facing the most severe needs, while including contingency planning to enable rapid, principled response to new or escalating emergencies. By prioritizing multi-sectoral, integrated intervention, the allocation’s primary goal is to both save lives and stimulate resilience, supporting sustainable transitions for affected communities.  Aligned with the one Syria  vision, this allocation advances the consolidation of a renewed pooled fund and contributes to a unified, inclusive, and coordinated humanitarian response structure. By prioritizing streamlined collaboration, it enables more effective decision-making, with the full transition targeted for completion by 30 June 2025. The balanced contributions from the two Funds reflect operational capacities, reach, and complementarity in leveraging existing partnerships to ensure continued engagement with affected populations.

AllocationSummary: Al- Rastan Bridge on Homs-Hama M5 Highway is severely damaged during the war in December 2024. The bridge is a critical ‘node’ on north-south transport axis.   The severe damage of this installation is affecting delivery of humanitarian assistance as convoys have to undertake a detour of about 90 kms. Assistance to more than one third (5 million) of people who require assistance passes on this road. It is a major supply chain for the humanitarian response in Aleppo, Hama, Idleb and Coastal governorates of Tartus and Latakia.  In view of the above and in consideration of the primary objective of the emergency rehabilitation of the bridge, to facilitate humanitarian access and facilitate humanitarian operations, the HC has decided to release a total of US $ 2.5 million towards the rehabilitation of the Al-Rastan bridge.  The allocation for emergency rehabilitation of the bridge, is proposed to facilitate humanitarian access and facilitate humanitarian operations in Syria.

AllocationSummary: The abrupt freezing of US funding has forced 38 NGOs operating in Northeast Syria (NES) to halt operations, leaving 90 per cent of humanitarian activities in the region paralyzed. This funding shortage has caused massive disruptions in humanitarian programmes in NES including the provision of life-saving assistance to at least 2.5 million people, that include those in internally displaced people (IDP camps) as well as coordination efforts.  Protection services are among the most severely impacted alongside services and assistance pertaining to camp coordination and camp management (CCCM), health, shelter and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH). Five camps have been identified as most affected and are facing severe disruptions in essential services including Al Hol, Roj, Washokani, Areesha, and Mahmouli.  The crisis is unfolding amid a humanitarian scale-up declaration for Syria and an ongoing review of coordination structures. Compounding the situation, the NES Forum, which has played a critical coordination role, will cease its operations by 6 March 2025, further jeopardizing response efforts.  The Syria Humanitarian Fund (SHF) will release $ 8 million to help sustain life-saving essential services for a minimum of three months, while advocating for additional funding.

AllocationSummary: This allocation strategy has been developed in line with the 2019 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) and the Readiness and Response Plan for North West Syria that has been updated and activated. Results from the most recent data collection exercise (multi-sector Rapid Needs Assessment (RNA), July 2019) have also been taken into account in the prioritization exercise.    This reserve allocation is anchored in the first two objectives of the HRP; to provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people to alleviate suffering, and to respond to protection needs with an emphasis on those in areas with high severity of needs. Cluster Strategic Objectives to which this allocation will contribute to are identified under each sector strategy.

AllocationSummary: This allocation strategy has been developed in line with the 2019 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) and the Response Plan for North West Syria issued in October 2019. Results from the most recent multi-cluster data collection exercise (Multi-Sector Needs Assessment (MSNA), September 2019) under the 2020 Humanitarian Needs Overview process in addition to several cluster consultations have also been considered during the prioritization exercise.    The objectives of this standard allocation are covering all three objectives of the HRP: to provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people to alleviate suffering; to respond to protection needs with an emphasis on those in areas with high severity of needs; and to increase the resilience of affected communities by improving access to livelihood opportunities and basic services, especially among the most vulnerable households and communities. Cluster strategic objectives to which this allocation will contribute to are identified under each strategic objective.

AllocationSummary: It is the first reserve allocation organized by the Syria Cross-border Humanitarian Fund to support cross-border actors operating in North East Syria. The principal purpose of this reserve allocation is to support and maintain the emergency response in most affected areas as well as support critical activities in hosting locations, accessible directly cross-border from Iraq and where the response from within Syria has been limited, with an emphasis on the following strategic objectives:    •	Assisting the newly displaced, particularly those in collective centres, camps and residing with friends/ family in host communities in Hassakeh and Raqqa governorates:  o	Providing RTEs to newly displaced households and eventually general food rations/ cash for food for people facing longer-term displacement as well as kitchen kitsm;  o	Providing winterization assistance including winter kits, heaters/ fuel and access to adequate shelters.  o	Establishing health services including through static capacity in new/ reactivated camps and mobile medical unit (MMUs) for IDPs in collective centres;  o	Ensuring sustained delivery of safe/ potable drinking water to IDPs / host communities, particularly in areas where supplies are under considerable strain’;  o	Expanding access to adequate and dignified sanitation, through latrine installation, rehabilitation (in collective centres) and maintenance;  o	Providing psycho-social support and psychological first aid to newly displaced persons.   •	Enhancing support to host communities, and areas of returnees particularly in relation to the delivery of basic services such as health, water and sanitation and waste management:  o	Maintain support to health facilities and delivery points, including frontline hospitals and some critical Primary Health Care facilities (PHCs),;  o	Provide mine risk education for people living in contaminated areas and scale-up mine clearance operations in Raqqa city and surrounding areas where operations have faced severe disruptions;  o	Support urgent school repair activities as part of winterization efforts - ensuring children have access to safe and productive learning environments;  o	Enhance child protection interventions for vulnerable children through distribution of PSS kits, awareness raising activities (including safe identification and referral) and provision of recreational activities;  •	Expanding partnerships and engaging in capacity building as part of individual NGO strategies to ensure continuity of response and enable a shift in modality should partners lose access or international staff presence be reduced.    This reserve allocation will be focused on the provision of assistance through cross-border operations from Iraq, ensuring complementarity with other response modalities focusing on a) specific sectoral emergency activities which are critical and either not met or not able to be fully addressed by other response modalities e.g. ERW clearance, sustained support to medical facilities, provision of heaters and fuel b) geographic locations where NGO partners have greater proximity and ease of operating e.g. newly established camps, c) areas and camps where there remain unmet needs despite joint effort from all modalities especially in health, WASH, protection and other winterization efforts in all other camps where gaps have been identified e.g. Deir Ez Zor, Raqqa and Menbij Programmatically, the allocation will prioritize the provision of emergency multi-sectoral assistance to new IDPs as well as support to maintaining on-going response given reprioritization and redirection which has resulted from the emergency - including, winterization assistance, support to basic healthcare provision and protection, including mine risk education as well as mine clearance and, relatedly, school repairs for winter preparedness and urgent restoration of safe learning environments.  •	Under each strategic objective the projects must have a strong emphasis on:  o	Wome

AllocationSummary: This emergency allocation will address the immediate needs as outlined below and, considering the very volatile environment, aims to be flexible in responding to the immediate and urgent needs on the ground for relocation, newly displaced persons and scale-up services in camps and overburdened host communities. Interventions will aim to scale up and complement the ongoing response, including ongoing reprogramming of existing interventions that have been affected or interrupted by the ongoing violence. This strategy has been developed based on the most recent figures and numbers and locations in the readiness and response plan and will be updated during proposals as the situation rapidly evolves.    As such, the allocation will align with the three objectives of the humanitarian readiness and response plan:  1.	Allocation Strategic Objective (ASO) 1: Protection of civilians  	Protection services: will be implemented through an emergency response model that relies on expanding the capacity of static service points (community centers, child-friendly spaces, and women and girls’ safe spaces) and mobile outreach teams. Due to the dynamic nature of the Syrian context, this approach supports affected populations with multiple entry points to protection services and allows cluster members to continue the delivery of services in rapidly-changing circumstances to respond to existing gaps and anticipated growing needs. Procurement and provision of dignity kits are also included;  	Safe Relocation: of people to save areas by provision of transportation services. This includes relocation support and facilitation of routes for people to move safely away from hostilities and to safe destinations.  2.	Allocation Strategic Objective (ASO) 2: Provision of safe reception centers and shelters in and out of camps   	CCCM and emergency shelter: Expansion of existing and establishment of new camps to increase emergency shelter capacity for the newly displaced IDPs, provision of camp management and coordination in the newly established and extended camps and provision of protection and mainstreamed multi-sectoral lifesaving assistance in these sites  and procurement of emergency shelter;   	WASH: Procurement and provision of critical Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) supplies and services to people in newly established and extended camp and out of camp locations  with priority to locations that are overwhelmed with new arrivals;  3.	Allocation Strategic Objective (ASO) 3: Provision of emergency services in and out of camps;  	Food assistance and livelihoods: Prepositioning and distributing of ready-to-eat-rations (RTER), food baskets, support to mobile kitchens and cooked meals to respond to the basic needs of newly displaced IDPs;    	Health: Procurement and provision of medical supplies, including trauma and surgical kits/supplies, anesthetics drugs and supplementary medicines, support to ambulance services, mobile clinics in IDPs sites and facilities in targeted locations that are overwhelmed with new arrivals;  	Non-Food Items (NFIs) and emergency shelter: Procurement and provision of core pipelines (Non-Food Items (NFIs) and shelter materials that are considered indispensable for the delivery of the frontline response;   	Common Services: increased logistic support to humanitarian partners through coordinating transshipment services and delivery of humanitarian cargo from Turkey into northwest Syria via the Bab Al-Hawa and Bab Al-Salam border crossings;   	Nutrition: scale-up of nutrition services to respond to increased needs where acute malnutrition of children 6-59 months has almost double one out of each three mothers and children in NWS is acutely malnourished and /or potentially anemic.

AllocationSummary: While displacement becomes more protracted, needs with longer-term impacts are increasing in prominence; this standard allocation aims to address both these sets of needs through immediate and slightly longer-term interventions to respond to high vulnerability level of a large part of the population living in northwest Syria. In doing so, it will also focus on strengthening elements of the preparedness and response to the COVID-19 pandemic as well as to adapt the response modalities to ensure the continuation and expansion of the humanitarian response.  The allocation will focus on the continuity of essential life-saving services and efforts to ensure dignified living conditions for the most vulnerable people in northwest Syria in both place of displacement, and in places of origin in cases where people have returned. Interventions will be prioritized based on the most recent needs assessments while ensuring the integration of doing no harm principles to mitigate vulnerabilities and build some element of sustainability into certain services such as WASH and Education. This allocation is also forward-thinking with the inclusion of winterization plans. These will start in August, given the lead times on the administrative and procurement processes.   The latest HNAP assessment conducted in March 2020 reported the priority needs are shelter (63%), basic services (59%) and food (55%). Accordingly, this allocation will align its response to meet these needs and ensure the continuation of basic services prioritizing most vulnerable people and have a strong emphasis on women and girls, people with disabilities and older persons and protection.  The allocation supports integration across all the clusters to better address needs and provide a comprehensive response. It strives to enhance coordination and collaboration between clusters and partners, and aspires to be more than just the simple inclusion of multiple cluster elements within a project, but rather support an integrated approach that combines mutually supportive programme elements, either within a single cluster or a multi-cluster, to achieve a common result. For example, for the establishment of new camps, WASH, CCM and S/NFI clusters will coordinate form very early planning stages to ensure that comprehensive services are provided.   Information on the humanitarian situation in northwest Syria is difficult to obtain, and access to affected communities remains the main challenge. The frequency and quality of current information flow are not consistent, while there are many sources of information are only accessible from the ground. This allocation will also support relevant common service that supports the wider humanitarian community.  In this context of increased uncertainty caused by several factors, the allocation will prioritize interventions factoring inflexible and responsible programming to rapidly adapt to changes to continue the provision of adequate basic services. The OCHA Humanitarian Financing team will continue working closely with partners to reprogramme should the need arise. Prioritized projects will propose a suitable risk management plan with a clear identification of internal and external risks and mitigation measures.  Interventions will be implemented according to cluster guidance and international humanitarian standards. New working modalities that include remote services and adjusted activities due to COVID-19 are supported and encouraged. Proposed interventions will be complementary to other SCHF ongoing projects (from the reserve, standard and COVID-19 allocations) and CERF grants, including the SCHF funding allocated at the beginning of the year to support the emergency response through the funding of the Preparedness and Response Plan for North West Syria issued in October 2019.

AllocationSummary: This standard allocation aims to address two specific objectives: critical and life-saving gaps in the response to COVID-19 and the most urgent winterization needs of people, prioritizing underserved and high-needs areas. Considering the large amount of funding allocated by the SCHF during 2020 (US$166 million) and the limited funding available under this allocation, priority will be given to projects with strong emphasis on critical life-saving interventions that directly link with the allocation objectives. This allocation will call for strong integration and complementarity to ensure an efficient coverage of and response to emergency needs. These strategic objectives aim to provide timely seasonal assistance and support the continuity of essential life-saving interventions for vulnerable people in northwest Syria affected by displacement and in places of origin in cases where people have returned. Considering the approaching winter season and COVID-19 pandemic, projects with an ability to start implementation immediately will be prioritized, conditional on having a strong risk management in place and a robust strategy to ensure accountability to the affected population throughout the project cycle. Winterization assistance funded under this allocation will take a people-centred approach including ensuring community and individuals are wholly addressed. The prioritized list of activities has been listed in the section below. COVID-19 sensitive programming should be applied across the projects implemented under the different sectors and should become a part of regular programming. During the allocation process, final decisions on RCCE-related interventions will also include a review and evaluation from a representative of the relevant clusters. Interventions will be implemented according to cluster guidance and international humanitarian standards. New working modalities that include remote services and adjusted activities due to COVID-19 are supported and encouraged. Geographical locations prioritized under this allocation are in line with the most recent needs assessments, critical gaps and overburdened communities' analysis and clusters’ inputs. The allocation decision-making process will review locations prioritized in each and across clusters to ensure complementarity and avoid duplications, including with previous SCHF allocations. Interventions targeting high-needs and underserved areas in complementarity with other activities on the ground will be prioritized. The maximum duration possible is 12 months for projects funded under this allocation. Projects contributing to winterization should start as soon as possible and demonstrate a feasible and realistic implementation plan. Winterization projects should start distribution as soon as possible upon budget clearance to ensure a timely delivery of aid. Project funded under this allocation must demonstrate strong cost-efficiency, taking into consideration currency fluctuation, market prices and, where applicable, other ongoing projects funded by SCHF including already funded support costs. The budgets submitted must demonstrate coherence and relevance of the logical framework, proposed activities, and value for money.

AllocationSummary: The Allocation aims to rehabilitate and strengthen the physical access to ensure that the IDPs and host communities' in Northwest Syria, such as in Afrin and Azaz, continue to receive an uninterrupted supply of humanitarian assistance transported through Bab-Al Hawa (BAH) crossing point. The project also addresses the risks identified by the Logistics and Early Recovery clusters of further deterioration of already poor-conditions roads that are/will be used for the shipment of humanitarian supplies by clusters' partners, given that these roads will share the load of additional humanitarian traffic that used to go through Bab Al Salama (BAS) border crossing.     In view of the urgency, before winter arrives, the project has prioritized the rehabilitation of Al Ghazawiya to Afrin's northern entrance through eastern bypass section for immediate rehabilitation at various points whose specific rehabilitation needs have been identified in consultation with ERL, Log clusters and the two implementing partners on the ground. At these points, the road is in extremely poor conditions- containing many pits, being not paved, and lacking flood drainage systems. The total length of the rehabilitated road will be 20 km, and it will include the following work:  a. Rehabilitation, upgrade, and new construction of flood drainage systems such as culverts, channels, manholes, pipelines, storm-drain, etc.  b. Rehabilitation and upgrade of the current roads, including removal of the Asphalt layer, repair the sub-base and base layers, and re-asphalting works.  c. Road marking, traffic signage, road crash guard barriers, and street lighting in the most critical and crowded locations such as road intersections, curves, slopes,  d. Paving works (curbstone and interlocking tiles).  At the same time, considering the already dire situation affecting IDPs and host community members living in northwest Syria has been further exacerbated by the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak and economic fragility, the project will also collaterally contribute to provide livelihood opportunities to address protection needs stemming from severe economic vulnerability.     Under the overall management responsibility of UNDP, the project will be carried out over a period of four months (Sep-Dec 2020) by two ERL Partners, Bonyan Organization and Imaar Organization, with proven highly-technical record in the rehabilitation and reparation of roads and drainage systems, as well as in the creation of livelihood opportunities. The estimated cost is USD 1.5 million.    The rehabilitation of key sections of this route will therefore ensure that humanitarian aid continues to reach areas previously served via BAS and maintain an uninterrupted supply chain of life-saving items to those areas. It will directly benefit 645,963 individuals in need of assistance in Aleppo (316,524 women and girls and 329,439 men and boys) -this figure corresponds to the number of PiN in the subdistricts served previously by BAS as reported in HNO 2019.

AllocationSummary: The surge in COVID-19 cases has had a significant impact on the overall humanitarian situation in North-West Syria, deteriorating a weak health system and exacerbating the socioeconomic conditions of vulnerable communities. This strategy has been developed based on the evolution of the humanitarian context, urgent need to scale up lifesaving activities and priorities  identified by the Health Cluster and COVID-19 Taskforce.    The Syria Cross border Fund (SCHF) is releasing $1.5 million to expand the health response to the pandemic and provide urgent medical supplies to hospitals treating COVID-19. The funding will be prioritized to procurement and delivery of urgent health supplies that will help care for vulnerable communities affected by COVID-19. Given the urgency of the situation, $1.5 million will be allocated to a project submitted by the World Health Organization (WHO) who is the best placed for rapid procurement of the below mentioned priorities.

AllocationSummary: The 2021 1st Reserve Allocation includes two interventions:  1-	Funding to support cross-border logistical operations:  The logistic cross-border support will aim at enabling improved humanitarian access for actors responding from Turkey to the needs inside Syria through the improvement of the Cross-Border facilitation services, and the provision of training and outreach activities aimed at increasing the know-how and technical capacity of humanitarian organizations undertaking the delivery of Cross-Border humanitarian relief supplies into Syria.  This project is vital in ensuring that the total amount of humanitarian assistance is facilitated to date. The humanitarian organizations will be encouraged to use humanitarian channels when delivering assistance to beneficiaries in Syria. These services enable the keeping of a comprehensive record in regard to the type and amount of humanitarian relief supplies delivered. These records are kept under a strictly confidential status by the implementing partner, thus ensuring the privacy of the relevant humanitarian organization. Data regarding the total amount of humanitarian relief supplies delivered are used as a guide to filling existing gaps in the delivery of the humanitarian relief supplies.    2-	Funding to support Field Officers project:  The Field Officers is designed as a project for the whole humanitarian community and fills an important gap in information gathering, coordination, and support to the overall humanitarian operation, and as such is a critical enabler that fits into the scope of the SCHF funding;  The Field Officers Project plays a critical role in providing regular humanitarian information which forms the basis of the daily information provided to the humanitarian community and donors. They also play a key role in liaising with stakeholders in emergencies, monitoring HF projects, and engaging with the Syrian community. This project contributes to strengthening the accountability of the response.
HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 20##2021

AllocationSummary: •	The 2021 First Standard Allocation (SA1) strategy was developed based on the latest information from humanitarian partners and clusters’ consultations. It utilizes information from various sources including weekly situation reports, various rapid assessments, and tracking tools. At the time of launch, humanitarian partners in Syria are in the process of finalizing the 2021 Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). To that end, this allocation strategy has been developed, following closely the 2021 HRP objectives and multi-sector response priorities as outlined in the 2021 Needs and Response Summary shared at the Senior Officials Meeting in February 2021. The objectives identified under the 2021 HRP are as follows:     o	Strategic Objective 1: Provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on those in areas with high severity of needs.  o	Strategic Objective 2: Enhance the prevention and mitigation of protection risks and respond to protection needs through supporting the protective environment in Syria, by promoting international law, International Humanitarian Law (IHL), and International Human Rights Law (IHRL) through quality, principled assistance.    o	Strategic Objective 3: Increase the resilience of affected communities by improving access to livelihood opportunities and basic services, especially among the most vulnerable households and communities.     •	To align with the humanitarian needs within the specific context, the strategy was also developed with inputs and consultations with all clusters operating in northwest Syria. Alongside this, the SCHF continues to work closely with the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG) to ensure alignment with current needs, funding gaps, and analysis regularly. At the time of launching this allocation, a funding gap analysis exercise at the ICCG level is ongoing and is expected to inform the funding decision.

AllocationSummary: The objective of this allocation is to ensure the effective use of SCHF resources and capacity to carry out reserve allocation to achieve a minimum level of readiness and preparedness through the prompt prepositioning of humanitarian items and assistance to enable effective response to the most vulnerable people in northwest Syria. This strategy has been developed taking into considerations the humanitarian context, complex and high level of needs and operating realities on the ground.   The efforts undertaken in this allocation will complement existing interventions funded under the SCHF as well as follows closely the priorities outlined in the 2021 First Standard Allocation (Strategic Objective 2: Life-saving humanitarian assistance and protection to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on underserved areas with high severity of needs). Specifically, this allocation will focus on prepositioning of life-saving relief commodities, which are managed by UN specialized agency on behalf of the sector partners and considering as well UN agencies role as a provider of last resort.

AllocationSummary: The SCHF second Standard Allocation (SA2) launched by the Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) in consultation with the SCHF Advisory Board (AB), presented to the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG), aims to set the SCHF funding priorities to address key life-saving humanitarian assistance in underserved areas in northwest Syria (NWS).    An estimated US$ 50 million is available under this allocation. The strategy outlines the allocation’s strategic direction and priorities, the rationale for the prioritization, and a timeline and procedure for the allocation process.    The allocation is aligned with and will contribute to the first and third strategic objectives referred to in the 2021 Needs and Response Strategy1:  SO 1. Provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on those in areas with high severity of needs.  SO 3. Increase the resilience of affected communities and early recovery by improving access to livelihood opportunities and basic services, especially among the most vulnerable households and communities.    The allocation is structured around two strategic objectives, focusing on two envelopes, which include:  1. Envelope 1: Provide life-saving humanitarian assistance in 24 underserved and frontline areas through the provision of COVID-19 response, WASH services and Shelter and NFI activities (indicative amount US$ 30M)  2. Envelope 2: Increase the resilience of affected communities and early recovery by improving access to livelihood opportunities and basic services, through integrated activities in selected areas of NWS (indicative amount US$ 20M)    Seasonality and timing of the prioritized activities will dictate the duration of the interventions. Within the estimated U$ 50 million, this allocation seeks to support multi-cluster programming where possible, with project duration of up to 12 months and complying with the requirements outlined in this strategy paper.    Proposals focusing on front-line and SCHF-underfunded locations, and IDP camps/sites that are in particularly poor condition, will be prioritized during project proposal review and selection. The DRHC would like to ensure via SCHF funding that all districts, especially those which have received less humanitarian assistance from 2021 allocations. SA2 will support those people living in districts close to the frontline areas, which face high security risks in addition to the mounting humanitarian needs. The COVID-19 specific objective will also contribute to the Global COVID-19 HRP launched in 2020.

AllocationSummary: The priorities under this allocation will focus on provisions for winter needs and measures to limit flood damages and address current emergency needs and critical gaps identified. This allocation is critical to ensure the most vulnerable individuals in northwest Syria are provided with timely and appropriate humanitarian assistance. Furthermore, this allocation should serve as a gap-filling, focusing on the most specific, urgent, and critical gaps already identified.  The funding for this allocation and per cluster has been pre-determined based on identified needs on the ground, donors’ consultations, and other funding opportunities. Implementing partners were also pre-identified by the respective clusters based on the criticality of needs, past performance with SCHF, access to target locations, technical expertise, and absorption capacity.   The clusters involved in the allocation are Camp Coordination and Camp Management, Education, Emergency Shelter, Non-Food Items, Food Security and Livelihoods, Health, Protection and Water and Sanitation. Locations to be covered under this allocation will focus on high and medium severity areas to ensure assistance is directed to the most vulnerable populations in northwest Syria.
HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 20##2021

AllocationSummary: Allocation Priority Description:    Under Priority 1, pre-identified UN Cluster Lead Agencies covering six sectors – Food Security, Health, Nutrition, Protection, WASH, will (i) procure, (ii) tranship, (iii) preposition, and (iv) distribute or handover essential core relief items to ensure the humanitarian community is able to provide life-saving assistance to all to PIN and IDPs including in northwest Syria in the event of potential displacements, hostilities, or changes to the operating circumstances     Under Priority 2, Inter-cluster response through Cash and Voucher Support (CVA) in response to winterization, and emergency WASH and other acute and lifesaving needs through Multipurpose cash assistance (MPCA)
