AllocationSummary: Launched by the Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) in consultation with the SCHF Advisory Board and presented to the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG), this 2022 first Standard Allocation (SA1) intends to avail an estimated US$ 50 million to address acute needs in underfunded and high-needs sectors in north-west Syria. Upon endorsement of the DRHC and the SCHF Advisory Board, any new donor contributions received before the allocation process may be included to increase funding for qualified proposals. The two strategic envelopes are:     Launched by the Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) in consultation with the SCHF Advisory Board and presented to Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG), this 2022 first Standard Allocation (SA1) intends to avail an estimated US$ 50 million to address acute needs in underfunded and high-needs sectors in north-west Syria. Upon endorsement of the DRHC and the SCHF Advisory Board, any new donor contributions received before the end of the allocation process may be included to increase funding for qualified proposals. The two strategic envelopes are:     •	Envelope 1: Provision of shelter support and/or integrated services leading to dignified and safer living conditions in 22 underserved and high-needs areas, through completing and/or integrating with dignified shelter solutions and education services (indicative amount US$ 36 million)    •	Envelope 2: Increase the resilience of affected communities by improving access to livelihood opportunities and basic services, through integrated multisectoral activities (indicative US$ 14 million)    •	Envelope 2: Increase the resilience of affected communities by improving access to livelihood opportunities and basic services, through integrated multisectoral activities (indicative US$ 14 million)

AllocationSummary: Building on previous allocations and achievements of the Fund, the SCHF second Standard Allocation for 2022 intends to release US$25 million to address acute needs in underfunded and high-need sectors of northwest Syria. The vision of the Deputy Resident Humanitarian Coordinator a.i. for this allocation is to ensure access to equitable lifesaving and life-sustaining integrated services guided by existing ICCG-approved response plans for Northwest Syria (NWS). The underfunded response plans for Winterization, Widows’ camps and Cholera Response aim to provide lifesaving and life-sustaining humanitarian aid to the most vulnerable people and communities in NWS by improving access to basic services, through integrated single and multisectoral activities. The allocation will focus on the following envelopes:  •	Envelope 1: Ensure access to equitable lifesaving and life-sustaining services through existing and underfunded ICCG-approved response plans focusing on Winterization, Widows’ camps, and Cholera Response (indicative amount US$ 15,7 million)  •	Envelope 2: Provision of lifesaving humanitarian aid to the most vulnerable people and communities by improving access to basic services, through integrated single and multisectoral activities (indicative US$9,3 million)

AllocationSummary: Launched by the Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) a.i. (on surge) in consultation with the SCHF Advisory Board and presented to Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG), the SCHF first Reserve Allocation (RA1 - Phase 1) intends to avail an estimated US$ 30 million to rapidly scale up and sustain the Earthquake Emergency Response in Northwest Syria.
Documents: 2023_RA1_Allocation Strategy.pdf##598344##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/TUR-AllocDocs_2023_460_737.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The devastating earthquakes at the beginning of the year combined with the ongoing, protracted conflict have impacted millions of Syrians, in need of humanitarian assistance for their survival. With the onset of winter, their needs and protection risks are expected to increase, at a time when funding is declining, and the Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) is 72 per cent underfunded.  The SCHF Standard Allocation will provide targeted multi-sectoral support to IDPs, returnees and other conflict-affected people at risk of eviction after the earthquake, residing in areas directly impacted by the earthquake and ongoing hostilities. The allocation aims to protect the population in need from foreseeable risks associated with the upcoming winter, including risks related to heavy rainfall, widespread flooding, and harsh low temperatures, and conflict related risks and displacement. In addition, funding will be provided to increase resilience of affected communities by ensuring access to basic services through integrated multisectoral activities. The allocation prioritises persons with disabilities, older persons and vulnerable women and children and those most at risk, in areas with high concentration of IDPs, areas severely impacted by winter conditions and flooding every year, and areas close to the frontlines.   The allocation aligns with SCHF’s commitment to advance localization and promotes participation and capacity strengthening of local and national partners, organizations of persons with disabilities and women-led and women’s rights organizations with access to hard-to-reach locations and ability to deliver principled and context-sensitive assistance. In addition, the allocation will promote cross-cutting priorities including gender and age considerations, disability inclusion, protection mainstreaming, and accountability in all partner programming.
HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 20##2023

AllocationSummary: Launched by the Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) in consultation with the SCHF Advisory Board and the relevant stakeholders, the SCHF Second Reserve Allocation intends to avail an estimated US$ 460,000 to Ensure effective Accountability to Affected Population and address PSEAH related risks and to Strengthen coordinated risk management in northwest Syria the aftermath of the earthquake.  Both initiatives support the DRHC leadership and decision-making regarding North-west Syria.   Considering that these services are under the Coordination and Support Services (CSS) cluster, and both administratively managed by IOM, for this allocation the same partner is best placed and thus pre-selected to apply   Coordination and Support Services (CSS1) - support the system-wide PSEAH complaint and feedback mechanism and expansion of the existing Hotline	  Coordination and Support Services (CSS2) - Strengthen coordinated risk management in northwest Syria the aftermath of the earthquake

Launched by the Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) in consultation with the SCHF Advisory Board and presented to the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG), the SCHF third Reserve Allocation (RA3) avails an estimated US$ 60,7 million to sustain and scale the Earthquake Response in Northwest Syria, and prepositioning of key relief items and Provision of lifesaving and life-sustaining humanitarian aid to the most vulnerable people and communities. The below charts provide an overview of the different envelopes and the indicative amounts per envelope and per cluster:  1.	Ensuring access to lifesaving and life-sustaining integrated services by supporting the transition from emergency to a sustainable response  2.	Prepositioning of core relief items to support resilience in line with the UN business continuity plan  3.	Provision of lifesaving and live sustaining humanitarian aid to the most vulnerable people and communities by improving access to basic services, through integrated single and multisectoral projects

AllocationSummary: Between 5 and 18 October 2023, approximately 123,000 individuals from 91 communities have been displaced following a significant escalation of hostilities that impacted more than 1,400 locations across southern Idleb and western Aleppo, with shelling and airstrikes that continuing almost daily, representing the most significant escalation in the area since 2019. In summary, the displacement situation in Idleb and western Aleppo remains fluid, with a significant number of IDPs still living in displacement sites or with host communities. While some returns have been observed, the majority of IDPs remain displaced. The main pull factors for returns are security and family ties. In consideration of the resource deployed and programmed, following data collection and analysis and coordination with the clusters, SCHF proposed to launch a focused Reserve Allocation (RA4, 2023) to support additional and urgent needs, that cannot be covered by the current grants or standard Allocation to support “additional or medium-term needs” intended in this context, related to:     1.	Protracted displacement response of the approx. 123k newly displaced people or the portion that cannot go back (proposed US$400K – CCCM)    2.	Supporting the return of the displaced people, including rehabilitation of damaged public structures, access basic and emergency services (Education and WASH)  2.1.	Rehabilitation of water stations and water network (US$ 1 million - WASH)  2.2.	Restoring quality Education services in the areas affected by the hostilities (US$ 600K - Education)  3.	Supporting essential Health facilities and services to population impacted by the hostilities (US$ 600K - Health)    The allocation is open for Cluster recommended partners only.
HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 20##2023

AllocationSummary: The humanitarian crisis in northwest Syria has worsened due to ongoing conflict and economic hardship, exacerbating the needs of 4.2 million people (out of 5.02 million in total). With limited access to essential services and infrastructure, northwest Syria faces severe shortages in healthcare, education, protection, food security, water, sanitation, and shelter, among others.   Through the first Standard Allocation (SA1), the SCHF aims to provide a coordinated multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance to vulnerable internally displaced persons (IDPs) and other conflict-affected people in northwest Syria, with prioritized activities under the forthcoming 2024 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). As funding gaps widen, with the HRP being 85 per cent underfunded, the ability of humanitarian partners to meet the critical needs of the most affected populations is hindered. This allocation aims to ensure continuity of the most critical services, being at risk of closure due to funding constraints. Priorities include access to basic health and education, community-led protection, infrastructure for flood mitigation, and life-saving food support. Key interventions involve emergency cash assistance, nutrition for children and mothers at risk of malnutrition, and WASH services in high-need areas. Increasing resilience by fostering social cohesion, access to dignified shelter solutions, food, and livelihoods support.   The SCHF’s will continue its commitment to foster meaningful local partnerships through promoting participation and capacity strengthening of Syrian organizations laying the foundation for long-term resilience and recovery in northwest Syria. The Standard allocation will be aiming to address the compounded needs of people with disabilities, vulnerable women, and children, especially in hard-to-reach areas, closest to the frontlines of conflict, areas with high concentration of IDPs, and other conflict-affected people in need of assistance.

HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 20##2024

AllocationSummary: The humanitarian response for northwest Syria remains alarmingly underfunded. As funding gaps widen for 2024, concerns about the ability of humanitarian partners to meet critical needs continue to grow. With less than two months left until the new year, the humanitarian response remains severely underfunded. As of 31 October, the 2024 Humanitarian Response Plan for Syria has received only over a quarter of the funding needed. Consequently, humanitarian activities and facilities have continued to be suspended in north-west Syria on a weekly basis.  At the same time, over 5 million people in northwest Syria are bracing for another cold winter season of unpredictable flooding, rainstorms and snow. Nearly 70 per cent of this population live in over 1,500 camps and informal settlements, often in overcrowded conditions and lacking basic amenities like sewage drainage, electricity, and water supply. After more than 13 years of conflict and displacement, 800,000 individuals, primarily women and children, are still living in tents. Last year, more than 1,000 shelters were damaged due to flooding, with 70 per cent of all displacement sites lacking basic care and maintenance.  The Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC) through the launch of SCHF first Reserve Allocation (RA1), aims to provide timely and flexible winter assistance while ensuring uninterrupted access to critical and lifesaving services to enhance the resilience of vulnerable individuals and groups, particularly internally displaced persons (IDPs) and other conflict-affected populations. The allocation priorities include access to basic health and education services, flexible emergency multipurpose cash assistance, and waste management to mitigate health hazards, while providing multisectoral assistance in accordance to the Winterization Plan to help families cope with freezing temperatures and hash weather.  The SCHF is committed to promoting localisation by prioritizing direct funding, participation, and capacity strengthening of Syrian organizations, laying the foundation for long-term resilience and recovery in northwest Syria. This allocation aims to address needs of people with disabilities, vulnerable women, and children, particularly in underserved, most in need and hard-to-reach areas close to conflict frontlines and in high concentrations of IDPs.

HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Plan 20##2024

AllocationSummary: The Menbij subdistrict in eastern Aleppo faces a complex crisis following the withdrawal of the authorities previously controlling the areas following the escalation of hostiles in November and December 2024, and the subsequent takeover by new authorities. This transition, marked by escalating and continued hostilities—such as car bomb attacks and ongoing clashes—has severely affected approximately at least 410,000 people in Menbij and Ain Al-Arab (estimates vary between 320,000 and 500,000 people in over 140 localities). This allocation prioritizes life-saving interventions in health, shelter/CCCM, food security, protection, and multi-purpose cash assistance. These priorities address the most critical needs identified through assessments and consultations with clusters and partners.
Documents: RA1 2025_Concept Note_Menbij_Draft_05_03_25.pdf##902290##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/TUR-AllocDocs_2025_1407_1252.pdf##
HRPPlans: Syrian Arab Republic Humanitarian Response Priorit##2025

AllocationSummary: The allocation released by the Syria Cross-border Humanitarian Fund (SCHF) and Syria Humanitarian Fund (SHF) represents a strategic, unified response to the acute and evolving humanitarian needs across Syria. In the aftermath of the government dissolution in 2024 and amid persistent conflict, seventy percent Syrians require urgent assistance, with displacement, returns, and continued instability reshaping the humanitarian landscape. While the current Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) targets eight million people and is only than 11 percent funded, this allocation ensures resources are directed where they are most impactful.  The strategy targets displaced populations, vulnerable host communities, and returnees in areas facing the most severe needs, while including contingency planning to enable rapid, principled response to new or escalating emergencies. By prioritizing multi-sectoral, integrated intervention, the allocation’s primary goal is to both save lives and stimulate resilience, supporting sustainable transitions for affected communities.  Aligned with the one Syria  vision, this allocation advances the consolidation of a renewed pooled fund and contributes to a unified, inclusive, and coordinated humanitarian response structure. By prioritizing streamlined collaboration, it enables more effective decision-making, with the full transition targeted for completion by 30 June 2025. The balanced contributions from the two Funds reflect operational capacities, reach, and complementarity in leveraging existing partnerships to ensure continued engagement with affected populations.

AllocationTitle: UHF COVID-19 Allocation for Eastern Ukraine
AllocationSummary: The Ukraine Humanitarian Fund emergency allocation of $2 million will respond to COVID-19 in eastern Ukraine.  The allocation will help ensure that elderly people who are self-isolating, receive home-based care and assistance, including the delivery of COVID-19 messaging and risk mitigation items. The allocation will also pilot a collaboration between civil society and the health authorities on contact tracing. All interventions will be implemented within appropriate do-no harm practices and in a short 2-3 month timeframe.

AllocationSummary: An envelope of $3 million is dedicated to GCA and will prioritize activities that address the most urgent and time-critical priority needs, including winterization activities, of the most vulnerable people while supporting durable solutions where possible. In GCA, priority will be given to multi-sectoral community-based approach and aimed at community empowerment and durable solutions in affected communities.

AllocationSummary: On 8 August, humanitarian partners in Ukraine released the revised Flash Appeal to respond to the Ukraine emergency for the period covering March to December 2022. The revised Flash Appeal identifies urgent humanitarian needs to be addressed by end of 2022.   This First Standard Allocation of the Ukraine Humanitarian Fund of up to $70 million will aim at providing targeted, time-critical support to internally displaced persons including evacuees, returnees and other conflict-affected people residing in the areas directly impacted by the military hostilities, including areas outside of Government control and newly accessible areas in Ukraine. In particular, the allocation will aim at supporting people with disabilities, elderly and vulnerable women in areas with high concentration of IDPs, including areas where people are expected to move during the winter months, areas with high concentration of returnees, hard to reach areas including non-government-controlled areas (NGCA).  The allocation will continue to pursue UHF’s commitment on localization through promoting participation and capacity-strengthening of national and local partners, including small civil society organizations (CSOs), community-based organizations (CBOs), volunteer groups, organizations of persons with disabilities (OPDs) and women-led and women’s rights organizations with access to hard-to-reach locations and ability to deliver contextually relevant assistance. In addition, the allocation will promote cross-cutting priorities including gender and age considerations, disability inclusion, protection mainstreaming, and accountability in all partner programming.

AllocationSummary: On 1 July 2022, humanitarian partners in Ukraine released the 2022-2023 Winterization Plan: Winter priority procurement and repair plan, which identified urgent winter procurement and repair activities targeting vulnerable IDPs and people living in sub-standard housing affected by the escalation of conflict since February. This Ukraine HF Reserve Allocation of up to $25 million will support the following time-critical, high-impact elements of the Winterization Plan:  insulation of sub-standard dwellings and damaged homes and provision of heating appliances and solid fuel in remote and rural areas of eastern and northern oblasts.  The reserve modality has been selected to allow for an expedited proposal vetting and review processes and rapid disbursement of funds to ensure the timely implementation of prioritized activities before the onset of the winter season. The tight sectoral and geographic focus complements ongoing and planned interventions by other donor and international agency initiatives addressing winterization needs and their concurrent programming under the Ukraine Flash Appeal.  This allocation will support the continued pursuit of UHF’s commitment on localization through promoting participation and capacity-strengthening of national and local partners, including small civil-society organizations with access to hard-to-reach locations and ability to deliver contextually relevant assistance. The allocation will also promote other cross-cutting priorities including gender and age considerations, disability inclusion, protection mainstreaming, and accountability in all partner programming.

AllocationTitle: UHF 2022 Second Reserve Allocation_Upscaling humanitarian aid
AllocationSummary: The security situation across Ukraine, including in the two pre-existing conflict-affected Donetska and Luhanska oblasts (regions), deteriorated rapidly. The intense hostilities – both in the ‘traditional’ hotspots along the “contact line” and new areas throughout Ukraine, including in Kyiv, have resulted in the loss of life, injuries and mass movement of the civilian population throughout the country and to neighboring countries.     The ongoing military offensive and rapidly deteriorating security environment throughout the country has put hundreds of thousands of people’s lives at risk. The expansion of the insecurity to the areas previously unaffected by hostilities is projected to create new humanitarian needs among millions of Ukrainians. This allocation is adapting to the newly unfolding situation.    Therefore, the humanitarian coordinator will release US$18 Million from the UHF to: (1) Provide timely lifesaving multisectoral assistance to displaced and non-displaced persons, who are affected by the escalation of hostilities, (2) Protect conflict-affected people and civilian infrastructure regarding international humanitarian law, norms, and standards, (3) Support provision of basic services in areas impacted by the escalation of hostilities.

AllocationTitle: UHF 2022 Third Reserve Allocation_Responding to humanitarian needs as a result of the military offensive in Ukraine
AllocationSummary: The security situation across Ukraine has rapidly deteriorated since the start of the military offensive on 24 February 2022.The ongoing military offensive and rapidly deteriorating security environment throughout the country has put millions of people’s lives at risk, mostly women and children. The expansion of the insecurity to the areas previously unaffected by hostilities is creating new humanitarian needs among tens of millions of Ukrainians. This allocation is adapting to the newly unfolding situation.    Therefore, the Humanitarian Coordinator will release US$50 Million from the UHF to:    1.	Address the immediate lifesaving and life-sustaining needs of the most vulnerable men, women boys, girls and minority groups through: ($45 million)  a.	Sustaining humanitarian activities in areas under threat through the provision of relief items and critical supplies limited to Donetska Oblast (GCA and NGCA); Luhanska Oblast (GCA and NGCA); Kharkiv, Kherson, Zaporizhzhia.   b.	Scaling up the delivery of humanitarian supplies and services in conflict affected accessible areas including in Kyiv Oblast: Irpin, Bucha, other Kyiv suburbs, Chernihiv Oblast: Chernihiv and surrounding areas, Sumy Oblast: Sumy and surrounding areas.   c.	Supporting the IDP response through the provision of Multi-Purpose Cash assistance in Western and Central Oblasts, areas with high concentrations of vulnerable IDPs.     2.	Enable actors to deliver an effective, efficient, accountable, gender-responsive and dignified response for crisis-affected people through the provision of common services (ETC, logistics and AAP/PSEA only) ($5 million)

AllocationSummary: This highly prioritized, accelerated allocation of the Ukraine Humanitarian Fund (UHF) to a limited number of pre-identified humanitarian partner projects will support conflict-affected people located in the eastern and southern oblasts of Ukraine, found   with the greatest severity of needs, with sectoral assistance with the largest number of people in need, as identified in the 2023 Humanitarian Needs Overview.The allocation will provide the first source of funding to kickstart the most urgent, time-critical activities under the 2023 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) with an emphasis on direct assistance wherever relevant. Specifically, the allocation will fund an inter-agency initiative linking demining, agricultural land rehabilitation and livelihood assistance; tailored emergency shelter and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) support to address differentiated needs in rural settlements of newly accessible areas and urban centres; specialized protection assistance targeting vulnerable individuals including persons with disabilities, women, children, elderly, the displaced and those separated from their families; provision of comprehensive primary healthcare services including mental health and psychosocial support and pre-positioning of medicines; and complementary multi-sectoral cash assistance (MPCA).

AllocationSummary: On 15 February, humanitarian partners in Ukraine released the 2023 Ukraine Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) to respond to the needs of 11.1 million people identified in the 2023 Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO) as in urgent need of humanitarian assistance and protection. This includes 6.3 million internally displaced people (IDPs) located throughout the country, 6.9 million people who remain at their homes, and 4.4 million returnees.  The allocation aims at providing targeted multi-sectoral support to internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees and other conflict-affected people residing in the areas directly impacted by the military hostilities in Ukraine. In particular, the allocation will aim at addressing compounded needs of people with disabilities, older persons and vulnerable women and children in areas with high concentration of IDPs, areas with high concentration of returnees, and accessible areas close to the frontlines.  The allocation will continue to pursue UHF’s commitment to local partnership through promoting participation and capacity strengthening of national partners, including national and local NGOs, small civil society organizations (CSOs), community-based organizations (CBOs), volunteer groups, organizations of persons with disabilities and women-led and women’s rights organizations with access to hard-to-reach locations and ability to deliver principled and contextually relevant assistance. In addition, the allocation will promote cross-cutting priorities including gender and age considerations, disability inclusion, protection mainstreaming, and accountability in all partner programming.

AllocationSummary: In August 2023, the OCHA and the ICCG developed a winter response plan which prioritized activities in three sectors (WASH, Shelter NFI and FSL/Agriculture) under the 2023 Ukraine Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) to support the winter needs faced by vulnerable IDPs and people living in sub-standard housing affected by the escalation of conflict. This UHF Reserve Allocation of up to $55 million will support the following time-critical, high-impact activities of the winterization response identified in the plan.    The reserve modality has been selected to allow for an expedited proposal vetting and review processes and rapid disbursement of funds to ensure the timely implementation of prioritized activities before the onset of the winter season. The tight sectoral and geographic focus complements ongoing and planned interventions by other donor and international agency initiatives addressing winterization needs and their concurrent programming under the HRP.    This allocation will support the continued pursuit of UHF’s commitment on localization through promoting participation and capacity-strengthening of national and local partners, including small civil-society organizations with access to hard-to-reach locations and ability to deliver contextually relevant assistance. The allocation will also promote other cross-cutting priorities including gender and age considerations, disability inclusion, protection mainstreaming, and accountability in all partner programming.

AllocationSummary: In June 2024, the ICCG developed a winter response plan under the 2024 Ukraine Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan to support vulnerable IDPs and those in collective centers. The UHF Reserve allocation will prioritize critical winter heating needs, expedite funding through experienced partners, and promote localization, gender, disability inclusion, and protection in partner programming.

AllocationSummary: This Ukraine Humanitarian Fund (UHF) Reserve Allocation of US$20 million will support the continuation of evacuation support by national actors, based on the Guidance on Humanitarian Evacuations by the Protection Cluster and Child Protection AoR, at the frontline and a comprehensive service package for evacuees upon arrival, with particular focus on people with disability and older people in need of social care services.

AllocationSummary: In June 2025, under the strategic guidance of the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT), and in consultations with different stakeholders, including the Government of Ukraine, donors, clusters, and partners, the Ukraine Winter Response Plan 2025-2026 was developed prioritizing life-saving winter-specific assistance for vulnerable populations facing severe energy insecurity, housing damage, and displacement across conflict-affected oblasts. Building on this, this UHF Reserve Allocation of up to $40 million will aim to support time-critical winter interventions targeting internally displaced people (IDPs), returnees, and conflict-affected communities, especially those living in or near the front line and in collective sites. The allocation will fund pre-selected partners with demonstrated technical and operational capacity, ensuring fast-track disbursement and timely delivery before winter peaks.

AllocationTitle: CERF Rapid Response: Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of) Oct 2025 (Floods)
CERF Underfunded Emergencies: Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of) 2025 (Socio-economic disruption)

AllocationSummary: La asignación es lanzada por un valor de US$3.5 millones y se centra en la prestación de asistencia directa a los siguientes grupos vulnerables priorizados: mujeres y adolescentes en edad reproductiva, embarazadas y/o en periodo de lactancia; personas adultas mayores en situación de riesgo y, de forma complementaria a ambos grupos, niños, niñas y adolescentes (NNA) en riesgo, en los estados Amazonas, Anzoátegui, Bolívar, Delta Amacuro, Distrito Capital, Falcón, Miranda, Sucre y Zulia.  La asignación será repartida en sobres asignados por grupo vulnerable.
Documents: VHF_Documento de estrategia de la primera asignación ordinaria_21SA1.pdf##1218599##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/VEN-AllocDocs_2021_315_301.pdf##

AllocationSummary: La asignación es lanzada por un valor de US$8 millones y se centra en la prestación de asistencia directa a los siguientes grupos vulnerables priorizados: comunidades indígenas en los estados Amazonas, Bolívar, Delta Amacuro y Zulia; niños, niñas y adolescentes vulnerables, incluidos NNA fuera y/o en riesgo de dejar la escuelas en el contexto del retorno clases presenciales en los estados de Apure, Amazonas, Delta Amacuro; y personas afectadas en zonas que han visto enfrentamientos armados en zonas urbanas (Distrito Capital). La asignación será repartida en sobres asignados por grupo vulnerable.
Documents: FHV - Estrategia Segunda Asignación Ordinaria 2021 - GMS.pdf##477018##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/VEN-AllocDocs_2021_361_428.pdf##

AllocationSummary: La asignación es lanzada por un valor de US$4 millones y se centra en la prestación de asistencia directa a adolescentes y jóvenes en situación de vulnerabilidad en los estados Apure y Bolívar y sobrevivientes de cualquier forma de violencia, especialmente asociados a la movilidad humana en los estados fronterizos Apure, Bolívar y Zulia.
Documents: FHV Estrategia Primera Asignación Ordinaria 2022_FINAL.pdf##538992##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/VEN-AllocDocs_2022_416_555.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Asistencia directa multisectorial centrada en las personas adultas mayores, mujeres en edad reproductiva, y niños, niñas y adolescentes con necesidades de atención integral en salud, protección, nutrición, seguridad alimentaria y medios de vida, y agua, saneamiento e higiene en tres estados priorizados del HRP: Amazonas, Apure y Sucre.
Documents: FHV Estrategia Segunda Asignación Ordinaria 2022_FINAL.pdf##507374##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/VEN-AllocDocs_2022_445_673.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Asistencia multisectorial centrada en personas retornadas y comunidades de acogida; jóvenes y adolescentes, mujeres en edad reproductiva, y niños y niñas en dos estados priorizados del HRP: Miranda y Delta Amacuro.

Asistencia multisectorial para la mejora de servicios esenciales de salud, el fortalecimiento de la resiliencia de la comunidad a través del apoyo a los medios de subsistencia, la igualdad de género y el empoderamiento de las mujeres, el apoyo a actividades de educación en emergencia y la prestación de asistencia y servicios de protección en complementariedad con fondos CERF en 13 municipios de 5 estados fronterizos: Bolívar, Delta Amacuro, Falcón, Sucre y Zulia.
Respuesta humanitaria multisectorial a las necesidades más críticas, en los estados de Delta Amacuro, Miranda, Apure, Bolívar y Zulia, bajo un enfoque de salvar vidas y de Derechos/Protección.

AllocationSummary: Respuesta integrada a las necesidades emergentes de protección en municipios severamente afectados.

AllocationTitle: Primera Asignación de Reserva 2024-2024 Respuesta 48 Horas
AllocationSummary: A fin de estar preparados ante cualquier emergencia súbita que pudiera agravar las condiciones de vida de poblaciones vulnerables, el Coordinador Humanitario propone una asignación de reserva del Fondo Humanitario de Venezuela (FHV), como ente catalítico y de respuesta inmediata. Esta asignación por un millón de dólares (US$1M) se enfocará en proporcionar una asistencia humanitaria vital a los más vulnerables, frente a una emergencia sobrevenida que pudiera profundizar brechas de acceso a servicios básicos y humanitarios para poblaciones vulnerables.  Con este objetivo, y teniendo en cuenta su presencia operativa a nivel nacional y su capacidad a acceder a las áreas difícil de acceso, se propone preposicionar el monto total de la asignación a la Federación Internacional de Sociedades de la Cruz Roja y de la Medialuna Roja (IFRC), a través del mecanismo de 'respuesta en 48 horas' (como consta en Manual Operativo de los CBPF´s 2023, páginas 26-27)

Respuesta integrada multisectorial para el restablecimiento de servicios críticos de Salud Sexual y Reproductiva, respuesta a la Violencia basada en Género y protección de la niñez en las áreas más afectadas de los estados Bolívar, Sucre, Táchira y Zulia, en complementariedad con la asignación UFE del CERF.

AllocationSummary: YHF Reserve Allocation to urgently provide $3.86 million to UNICEF for fuel provision to the Local Water and Sanitation Corporation and $1.58 million to WHO for fuel provision to health facilities.

The overall objective of the first YHF Standard Allocation is to ensure that all vulnerable groups in Yemen are adequately assisted and their needs adequately reflected in humanitarian programmes. In leaving no one behind, YHF partners will concentrate their response in under-severe and most in need areas which observe the highest level of severity. Clusters will ensure synergy in approach and integrated response based in the comparative advantage of each cluster and partner. This allocation will focus on 4 main priorities as follows:    - Priority 1: Upgrading of living conditions and access to assistance and protection for PWD, minority groups and persons with other specific needs (including female-headed households, vulnerable children exposed to neglect, abuse, violence and exploitation, women and girls at risk including child marriage).     - Priority 2: Provision of life-saving integrated response for people in acute needs in hard to reach, frontlines and under-served areas with high severity of needs.      - Priority 3: Provision of emergency, life-saving assistance and protection to the most vulnerable IDPs, refugees, migrants and host communities most at risk due to recent displacements and conflict and in acute vulnerability and need.      - Priority 4: Provision of life-sustaining services and protection to the most vulnerable people in acute needs to improve their resilience.

AllocationSummary: This allocation is to cover RRM immediate activities listed below:    1. The procurement and distributions of Basic Hygiene kits (BHK),   2. Immediate Ready Ration (IRR) and Transit kits (TK)  3. Transportation of the above mentioned kits to the RRM distribution sites.

The YHF Second Standard Allocation 2021 (SA2 2021) is issued on 9 November by the Humanitarian Coordinator (HC), in consultation with the Clusters and Advisory Board of the Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). Its main objective is to enhance dignified living conditions for thousands of displaced persons in sites at a time when 5 million vulnerable people are just one step away from famine. A total of US$45m will be available to YHF partners who are kindly asked to submit their proposals by 25 November 2021.    The SA2 will focus on three priorities:    Priority 1: Improving dignified living conditions for the most vulnerable IDPs in under-served IDP sites and supporting partners’ interventions in new sites lacking services in prioritized sub-districts.    Priority 2: Supporting durable interventions through innovative programming and localized solutions in Al Ashah district in Amran governorate, Al Qahirah and Al Mudhaffar sub-districts in Taiz governorate, Al Zuhrah in Hudaydah governorate, Al Maton and Al Hazm districts in Al Jawf governorate.    Priority 3: Supporting affected communities’ movements and access to services through mine action clearance and RRM.
Supporting UNHAS operations.
4th Reserve Allocation  2021

This allocation is for UNICEF to ensure that 3.6 million people have access to water and sanitation services across 37 locations in Yemen through fuel support to Local Water and Sanitation Corporations (LWSCs). Ensuring access to potable water and adequately treating wastewaters is critical, particularly within the context of the vulnerability to cholera and other waterborne diseases. This will also have an impact on the concerningly high prevalence of malnutrition among children.

AllocationSummary: The YHF First Standard Allocation 2022 (SA1 2022) is issued on 05 July by the Humanitarian Coordinator (HC), in consultation with the Clusters and Advisory Board of the Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). Its main objective is to enhance dignified living conditions for thousands of displaced persons in sites at a time when 5 million vulnerable people are just one step away from famine. A total of US$44 M will be available to YHF partners who are kindly asked to submit their proposals by 25 July.      This allocation has a two-pronged approach. First, as the food insecurity and nutrition crisis deepen in Yemen, an integrated famine response will target frontline and under-served areas with the highest severity of needs in a context where millions face immediate risk of famine or avoidable diseases. Second, to ensure the continuity of life saving service provision and improving dignified living conditions by targeting districts where the living conditions in IDP sites are below standard.    This allocation is coming at a time when the funding levels to Yemen are at an all-time low. According to FTS, the HRP is only 26.3% funded. Through this allocation, clusters will be able to sustain provision of essential services to the most vulnerable. The allocation will target some 1.7 million people.    5.	The SA1 will focus on two priorities:    •	Priority 1 ($14.5 million): Aims to prevent famine and mitigate hunger by increasing access to food and other lifesaving supplies and services through the Integrated Famine Rapid Response (IFRR) package. YHF partners will provide multi-sectoral response in 14 districts with pockets of IPC 5 populations as identified in the table below. The clusters identified are FSAC, HEA, NUT, and WASH. Partners are expected to consider in the design of their projects the specific needs of persons with disabilities, minorities, women, and children at risk.     •	Priority 2 ($29.5 million): Provision of emergency, life-saving assistance, and protection (CCCM, PRO, WASH, EDU, ETC, RRM, RMMS) to the most acutely vulnerable IDPs, refugees, migrants, and host communities most at risk due to recent displacements and conflict. YHF partners will consider programming continuation of lifesaving services, as well as going beyond emergency assistance, and considering more durable interventions. Partners are expected to consider in the design of their projects the specific needs of persons with disabilities, minorities, women, and children at risk.

AllocationSummary: This $30 million allocation is a multi-sectoral response to reduce protection risks and  improve humanitarian conditions
Documents: Annex 2 - YHF Budget Preparation Guidelines.pdf##389303##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2022_456_715.pdf##|||Annex 3 - Guidance for developing YHF proposals.pdf##296864##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2022_456_716.pdf##|||YHF 2022 3rd Reserve Allocation_FINAL.pdf##471674##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2022_456_717.pdf##

AllocationSummary: This Reserve Allocation will support the flood response through a two-pronged approach. First, it aims to enhance the preparedness for and mitigate the impact of flooding by strengthening the response capacity. Second, it will pilot the first-ever collective, multi-sectoral Anticipatory Action approach for floods, coordinated by OCHA and implemented with funding from the YHF. Rather than responding after the flood-related needs have manifested, this anticipatory action intervention will use forecasts to trigger pre-agreed actions to prevent or reduce the acute humanitarian impacts of the floods before they fully unfold, and thereby effectively acting on risk and vulnerability.
Documents: Allocation Strategy_2023 First Reserve Allocation_FINAL_20230504.pdf##1094523##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2023_468_789.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Protracted conflict, displacement and economic deterioration in Yemen have led to an increased number of people facing multiple vulnerabilities, including food insecurity, unsafe and poor living conditions, and acute WASH needs, forcing people into harmful negative coping mechanisms, resulting in exacerbated protection risks. With the continuation of the UN-brokered truce, there is an overall reduction in fighting, increased availability and movement of supplies, and increased access to hard-to-reach areas. The improved humanitarian situation presents an opportunity to scale-up humanitarian assistance with a focus on the centrality of protection and increase the geographical coverage of the humanitarian response.      This allocation takes a three-pronged approach:  a) To minimize protection vulnerabilities by investing in a multi-sectoral response that reduces protection risks and improves resilience.  b) To provide safe and dignified living conditions for the most vulnerable in IDP sites with sub-standard living conditions, and acute WASH needs, that are driving humanitarian needs.    c) To scale-up humanitarian assistance in hard to reach, newly accessible and underserved areas.    The YHF is injecting US$45 million to provide immediate lifesaving support in locations with the highest protection risks and needs, to reduce vulnerabilities; and, to the most vulnerable people in hard-to-reach and underserved areas.

AllocationSummary: This $1.75 million reserve allocation will establish a new humanitarian hub in Ta’iz to improve humanitarian actors' access to affected populations in remote and hard-to-reach field locations. In addition, it will scale up the geographic coverage of assessments which will help to inform the 2024 HNO and HRP processes.

AllocationSummary: UNHAS Yemen remains the only non-commercial way to travel in, within and out of Yemen for humanitarian actors. Its ability to not only carry personnel and cargo but also serve for medical evacuations, makes it an essential asset for the international humanitarian community operating in Yemen. This $2.35 million allocation will sustain the entire service for an additional month of operation to ensure reliable access for humanitarian actors, transport of light cargo and an option for medical or emergency evacuations; and it will enhance Aden airport facilities to improve the transit section for the passengers.

AllocationSummary: This allocation will provide support to the Floating Storage and Offloading (FSO) vessel Safer, to prevent the oil from spilling into the Red Sea.

AllocationSummary: This allocation aims to enhance the preparedness and response for emergency rescue operations including floods and humanitarian disasters as a result of climate change in the target areas, and hence reduce the mortality from future climate-related hazards. The project will support preparedness efforts for 300 frontline personnel and community networks of the Civil Defence Authority in Sana’a through the provision of PPEs and emergency rescue operation equipment, which will benefit about 6,713 persons annually.     In line with the Yemen HRP’s Strategic Objective 2, this $800k will improve the resilience of crisis-affected vulnerable people through increased safe, dignified and adequate access to multi-sectoral response and durable solutions.

AllocationSummary: This allocation will improve the capacity of existing sites for up to 800HHs to host IDPs who volunteer to move from Al Haymah sub-district, where there are safety concerns for those who live less than 500 metres from the frontline, and where there is restricted humanitarian access.     This $1 million will support the Voluntary Relocation of IDPs with safety concerns such as threats of forceful relocation and increased military activities frequent overflights of drones, exchange of fire across the frontline, and occasionally artillery shelling, and is designed for a proper and dignified response to IDPs willing to relocate to Al Khukhah, and is aimed to aid and protect the IDPs following the Guiding Principles on Internal Displacement and the International Humanitarian law.
Documents: YHF RA6 2023 - Al Khukhah IDP Site Improvement Plan.pdf##218748##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2023_497_919.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The security situation in the Yemen has improved significantly after the UN-brokered truce, However, victims of land mines and explosive remnants of war (ERW), including unexploded ordnance (UXO) have increased by 160 per cent, and continues to be a major threat to civilian and humanitarian movements. Yemen remains one of the most contaminated countries in the world.      The improved humanitarian situation presents an opportunity to scale-up mine action activities to reduce the potential casualties and expand access for the delivery of humanitarian assistance.     This $2.4 million reserve allocation will aim at scaling-up urgent mine action programming in most affected areas by reducing the impact of ERW but also providing immediate lifesaving support to the victims and populations at risk, through increased ERW awareness raising activities, mine clearance and assistance to victims.
Documents: Allocation Strategy_2023_.pdf##222517##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2023_512_871.pdf##

AllocationSummary: Ongoing floods and disease outbreaks in several parts of Yemen have compounded the humanitarian situation with already over 2 million children under five and an estimated 1.3 million pregnant and breastfeeding women acutely malnourished.     In response the worsening situation, the Yemen Humanitarian Fund has launched a $26 million reserve allocation to support the provision of health, nutrition and WASH services including, 1) Scale up assistance in underserved areas; 2) support primary health care, reproductive health, mental health, treatment of MAM and SAM cases, and procure essential pipeline supplies, and 3) Strengthen disease outbreak prevention and improve  preparedness, detection, and response and support access to safe drinking water.

AllocationSummary: To increase access of fresh drinking water to Al Mokha by supporting the construction of a water pipeline which greatly improve public health, sanitation and living conditions in this underserved area.
Documents: YHF RA 9 2023 - Mokha Water Project.pdf##1869312##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2023_524_915.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF) is launching a $30 million allocation to address the worsening malnutrition, compounded by increasing food insecurity, widespread outbreaks of communicable diseases, limited access to safe and clean water, protection risks and inadequate living standards for displaced-affected communities. Ahead of the looming lean and winter season, this allocation will provide timely assistance to mitigate the risk of people slipping further into catastrophic emergency status, which will be difficult to reverse.     In parallel, the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) has allocated $20 million to complement this YHF allocation. The combined $50 million allocation will respond to the needs in the top 32 districts that are most severely affected, where the inter-sectoral severity score is 4 and above.
Documents: First Standard Allocation Strategy-Endorsed-Updated Final.pdf##629328##Allocation Type##https://onegms.unocha.org/pubdocs/Allocationsdocs/YEM-AllocDocs_2024_1344_1143.pdf##

AllocationSummary: The Humanitarian Coordinator has decided to launch a YHF emergency reserve allocation of up to $6 million to support NGOs deliver already available nutrition supplies from UNICEF and WFP to mitigate the impact of the paused distributions and an already dire malnutrition situation. YHF funding will complement $7 million allocated under CERF to WFP to kickstart targeted food distributions to 9.5 million most vulnerable Yemenis, including those living in the same prioritized districts under this allocation.      This allocation will specifically target malnutrition among children, and pregnant and breastfeeding women, emphasizing the need for immediate nutritional support to mitigate the risk of morbidity and mortality resulting from malnutrition-related complications. It will focus on 34 districts across 5 Governorates (Ad Dali’, Al Hodeidah, Hajjah, Ta’iz and Raymah) identified and agreed upon jointly through a mapping exercise by the Food Security and Agriculture (FSAC) and Nutrition clusters as those areas presenting the highest convergence of needs.

AllocationSummary: This emergency allocation of $1.5 million has been launched to counter the worst humanitarian impact of the airstrikes on the electricity system in Al Hodeidah Governorate. The funds will be used to procure fuel, emergency supplies, medical equipment, and pharmaceuticals to bolster the operational capacity of essential healthcare facilities, enabling them to deliver emergency care and manage mass casualties effectively.
